paccayanidāno.translation_1: Resolution face-to-face has conditions as its source, its origin, its birth, its arising, its production, its origination.
paccayanidāno.example_2: tiṇavatthārako paccayanidāno, paccayasamudayo, paccayajātiko, paccayapabhavo, paccayasambhāro, paccayasamuṭṭhāno.
paccayanidāno.translation_2: Covering over as if with grass has conditions as its source, its origin, its birth, its arising, its production, its origination.

paccayajātiko.meaning_2: born (from conditions); produced (by conditions); arisen due to conditions
paccayajātiko.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given contexts, 'paccayajātiko' describes phenomena such as resolution, covering, or effort as 'born from conditions' or 'produced by conditions,' paralleling terms like 'paccayanidāno' (having conditions as source) in a series emphasizing conditional origination.
paccayajātiko.example_1: sammukhāvinayo paccayanidāno, paccayasamudayo, paccayajātiko, paccayapabhavo, paccayasambhāro, paccayasamuṭṭhāno.
paccayajātiko.translation_1: Resolution face-to-face has conditions as its source, its origin, its birth, its arising, its production, its origination.
paccayajātiko.example_2: tiṇavatthārako paccayanidāno, paccayasamudayo, paccayajātiko, paccayapabhavo, paccayasambhāro, paccayasamuṭṭhāno.
paccayajātiko.translation_2: Covering over as if with grass has conditions as its source, its origin, its birth, its arising, its production, its origination.

paccayapabhavo.meaning_2: arising (from conditions); production (from conditions); origination (from conditions)
paccayapabhavo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'paccayapabhavo' describes one of the aspects of conditional origination, specifically the 'arising' or 'production' due to supporting conditions (paccaya), parallel to terms like paccayasamudayo (origin) and paccayasamuṭṭhāno (origination). It emphasizes the causal emergence from prerequisites.
paccayapabhavo.example_1: sammukhāvinayo paccayanidāno, paccayasamudayo, paccayajātiko, paccayapabhavo, paccayasambhāro, paccayasamuṭṭhāno.
paccayapabhavo.translation_1: Resolution face-to-face has conditions as its source, its origin, its birth, its arising, its production, its origination.
paccayapabhavo.example_2: tiṇavatthārako paccayanidāno, paccayasamudayo, paccayajātiko, paccayapabhavo, paccayasambhāro, paccayasamuṭṭhāno.
paccayapabhavo.translation_2: Covering over as if with grass has conditions as its source, its origin, its birth, its arising, its production, its origination.

paccayasambhāro.meaning_2: production; assembly of conditions; preparation through conditions
paccayasambhāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'paccayasambhāro' denotes the 'production' or 'assembling' aspect of conditions that give rise to phenomena like resolution, covering, or effort, paralleling terms such as source, origin, birth, arising, and origination.
paccayasambhāro.example_1: sammukhāvinayo paccayanidāno, paccayasamudayo, paccayajātiko, paccayapabhavo, paccayasambhāro, paccayasamuṭṭhāno.
paccayasambhāro.translation_1: Resolution face-to-face has conditions as its source, its origin, its birth, its arising, its production, its origination.
paccayasambhāro.example_2: tiṇavatthārako paccayanidāno, paccayasamudayo, paccayajātiko, paccayapabhavo, paccayasambhāro, paccayasamuṭṭhāno.
paccayasambhāro.translation_2: Covering over as if with grass has conditions as its source, its origin, its birth, its arising, its production, its origination.

paccayasamuṭṭhāno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound used in the Vinaya context to denote something having conditions as its origination, paralleling terms like 'paccayasamudayo' (origin from conditions). The base 'samuṭṭhāno' is the nominative singular of the adjective 'samuṭṭhāna', functioning nominally here.
paccayasamuṭṭhāno.example_1: sammukhāvinayo paccayanidāno, paccayasamudayo, paccayajātiko, paccayapabhavo, paccayasambhāro, paccayasamuṭṭhāno.
paccayasamuṭṭhāno.translation_1: Resolution face-to-face has conditions as its source, its origin, its birth, its arising, its production, its origination.
paccayasamuṭṭhāno.example_2: tiṇavatthārako paccayanidāno, paccayasamudayo, paccayajātiko, paccayapabhavo, paccayasambhāro, paccayasamuṭṭhāno.
paccayasamuṭṭhāno.translation_2: Covering over as if with grass has conditions as its source, its origin, its birth, its arising, its production, its origination.

paccayanidānā.meaning_2: having conditions as source; conditions as origin; having conditions as foundation; conditions as cause
paccayanidānā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given contexts, 'paccayanidānā' functions as a compound instrumental plural describing entities (such as penalty, expectation, or non-expectation) that have 'conditions' (paccaya) as their 'source/origin' (nidāna). It parallels similar compounds like paccayasamudayā, emphasizing conditional arising in Buddhist doctrine.
paccayanidānā.example_1: tassapāpiyasikā paccayanidānā, paccayasamudayā, paccayajātikā, paccayapabhavā, paccayasambhārā, paccayasamuṭṭhānā.
paccayanidānā.example_2: āsā ca anāsā ca paccayanidānā, paccayasamudayā, paccayajātikā, paccayapabhavā, paccayasambhārā, paccayasamuṭṭhānā.
paccayanidānā.translation_2: Expectation and non-expectation have conditions as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

paccayajātikā.grammar: adj, in comps, from paccaya jāti
paccayajātikā.meaning_2: born from conditions; arisen from conditions
paccayajātikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given sentences, paccayajātikā forms part of a series of synonymous terms describing phenomena (like penalties or expectation) as originating from conditions (paccaya). It parallels paccayanidānā ('having conditions as source') and paccayasamudayā ('arising from conditions'), emphasizing conditional genesis. The feminine nominative plural ending -ā agrees with the implied plural subject in both contexts.
paccayajātikā.example_1: tassapāpiyasikā paccayanidānā, paccayasamudayā, paccayajātikā, paccayapabhavā, paccayasambhārā, paccayasamuṭṭhānā.
paccayajātikā.example_2: āsā ca anāsā ca paccayanidānā, paccayasamudayā, paccayajātikā, paccayapabhavā, paccayasambhārā, paccayasamuṭṭhānā.
paccayajātikā.translation_2: Expectation and non-expectation have conditions as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

paccayapabhavā.meaning_2: arising from conditions; produced by conditions; originating from supporting conditions
paccayapabhavā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'paccayapabhavā' describes 'āsā ca anāsā ca' (expectation and non-expectation) as arising or produced from conditions, paralleling terms like paccayanidānā (having conditions as source). The form is feminine nominative plural to agree with the dual subject, functioning as a bahuvrīhi compound emphasizing origin from paccaya (conditions).
paccayapabhavā.example_1: tassapāpiyasikā paccayanidānā, paccayasamudayā, paccayajātikā, paccayapabhavā, paccayasambhārā, paccayasamuṭṭhānā.
paccayapabhavā.example_2: āsā ca anāsā ca paccayanidānā, paccayasamudayā, paccayajātikā, paccayapabhavā, paccayasambhārā, paccayasamuṭṭhānā.
paccayapabhavā.translation_2: Expectation and non-expectation have conditions as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

paccayasambhārā.meaning_2: collection of conditions; assemblage of requisites
paccayasambhārā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the contextual sentences, 'paccayasambhārā' is one of a series of synonymous terms describing the foundational basis of phenomena, such as penalties or mental states like expectation, emphasizing the gathered or collected nature of supporting conditions in dependent origination.
paccayasambhārā.example_1: tassapāpiyasikā paccayanidānā, paccayasamudayā, paccayajātikā, paccayapabhavā, paccayasambhārā, paccayasamuṭṭhānā.
paccayasambhārā.example_2: āsā ca anāsā ca paccayanidānā, paccayasamudayā, paccayajātikā, paccayapabhavā, paccayasambhārā, paccayasamuṭṭhānā.
paccayasambhārā.translation_2: Expectation and non-expectation have conditions as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

paccayasamuṭṭhānā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in a series of parallel terms describing dependency on conditions, as seen in the contextual sentences where it parallels terms like paccayanidānā (having conditions as source) and paccayasamudayā (arising from conditions). In the first sentence, it relates to a penalty dependent on conditions; in the second, to expectation and non-expectation.
paccayasamuṭṭhānā.example_1: tassapāpiyasikā paccayanidānā, paccayasamudayā, paccayajātikā, paccayapabhavā, paccayasambhārā, paccayasamuṭṭhānā.
paccayasamuṭṭhānā.example_2: āsā ca anāsā ca paccayanidānā, paccayasamudayā, paccayajātikā, paccayapabhavā, paccayasambhārā, paccayasamuṭṭhānā.
paccayasamuṭṭhānā.translation_2: Expectation and non-expectation have conditions as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

chabbī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Chabbī is a taddhita derivative indicating possession of six parts or aspects, commonly used in compounds like chabbīdhamma (six mental states).

sattasamathanānatthādi.meaning_2: the variety in meaning, etc., between the seven principles for settling legal issues
sattasamathanānatthādi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound refers to the diversity or variations in interpretation (nānattha) and similar aspects (ādi) arising from the seven (satta) methods of settlement (samatha) used in Vinaya legal proceedings, as outlined in the Mahāvagga.
sattasamathanānatthādi.translation_1: 10. The variety in meaning, etc., between the seven principles for settling legal issues

nidānahetupaccayā.meaning_2: by sources, causes, conditions; due to origins, reasons, supporting factors
nidānahetupaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This form appears to be an instrumental plural or adverbial construction of the compound nidānahetupaccaya, functioning adverbially in the given context to denote causality. The English translation 'Sources, causes, conditions' suggests a list-like interpretation, likely in an ablative or instrumental sense indicating origin or dependency.

hetupaccayamūlāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the nominative plural form of the compound hetupaccayamūla, used in the context to denote the foundational elements of causation in Buddhist philosophy, specifically the roots (mūla) that are causes (hetu) and conditions (paccaya).

bhedādhikaraṇe.meaning_2: subdivision on legal issues; section dealing with disputes or schisms
bhedādhikaraṇe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In this Vinaya context, the compound refers to a specific subsection addressing schisms or divisive legal matters within monastic disciplinary proceedings, as indicated by the sentence meaning.
bhedādhikaraṇe.translation_1: “This is in the subdivision on legal issues.”

aparagāthāsaṅgaṇikaṃ.meaning_2: another verse-reciter; one who associates with other verses
aparagāthāsaṅgaṇikaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a descriptive compound (bahuvrīhi or karmadhāraya) in the neuter accusative singular, likely referring to a person or thing associated with reciting or composing verses other than the primary ones, in a Buddhist textual context where gāthā denotes verses or stanzas.

codanādipucchāvissajjanā.meaning_2: questions and answers on accusing, etc.
codanādipucchāvissajjanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a title for a section in the Vinaya, denoting 'questions and answers beginning with accusing (reprimanding, charging with an offense)' in the context of monastic discipline.
codanādipucchāvissajjanā.translation_1: Questions and answers on accusing, etc.

matikammaṃ.meaning_2: taking of advice; legal procedure involving consultation
matikammaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, matikammaṃ refers to a formal legal procedure requiring individual consultation or advice among the monks, as indicated by the sentences where it is described as 'individual' and questioned for its purpose.
matikammaṃ.translation_1: Why is there the taking of advice?

sāraṇatthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'codanā sāraṇatthāya' indicates that the purpose of accusing (codanā) is reminding (sāraṇa), where sāraṇa likely derives from the idea of directing or recalling someone to proper conduct, fitting the sequence of disciplinary processes in the Vinaya.
sāraṇatthāya.translation_1: The purpose of accusing is reminding,
sāraṇatthāya.example_2: suttaṃ saṃsandanatthāya, opammaṃ nidassanatthāya, attho viññāpanatthāya, paṭipucchā ṭhapanatthāya, okāsakammaṃ codanatthāya, codanā sāraṇatthāya, sāraṇā savacanīyatthāya, savacanīyaṃ palibodhatthāya, palibodho vinicchayatthāya, vinicchayo santīraṇatthāya, santīraṇaṃ ṭhānāṭhānagamanatthāya, ṭhānāṭhānagamanaṃ dummaṅkūnaṃ puggalānaṃ niggahatthāya, pesalānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ sampaggahatthāya, saṅgho sampariggahasampaṭicchanatthāya, saṅghena anumatā puggalā paccekaṭṭhāyino avisaṃvādakaṭṭhāyino.
sāraṇatthāya.translation_2: The Monastic Code is for the sake of concluding, a simile for the sake of illustration, the goal is to be made known, and questioning is for sake of establishing. Asking for permission is for the sake of accusing, accusing for reminding, reminding for directing, directing for obstructing, obstructing for investigating, investigating for weighing up, weighing up for deciding what is and is not the case, and deciding what is and is not the case is for the sake of restraining bad people and to support the good monks. The Sangha has the purpose of examining and accepting the decision. The Sangha should appoint people who are trustworthy to positions of authority.

niggahatthāya.meaning_2: for the purpose of restraint; for the sake of keeping in check; for the benefit of control
niggahatthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the provided sentences, 'niggahatthāya' denotes the ultimate purpose or goal of disciplinary processes in the Vinaya, specifically to achieve restraint over misconduct, as seen in 'niggahatthāya sāraṇā' (reminding for restraint) and the chain ending in restraining bad people while supporting good monks.
niggahatthāya.translation_1: The purpose of reminding is restraint;
niggahatthāya.translation_2: The purpose of sending back to the beginning is restraint.

pariggahatthāya.meaning_2: for the purpose of possession; for the sake of acquisition
pariggahatthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'saṅgho pariggahatthāya', the term refers to the Sangha's purpose involving possession or scrutiny of belongings, likely in the sense of examining or taking charge of property, aligning with Vinaya contexts of monastic oversight.
pariggahatthāya.translation_1: The purpose of the Sangha is scrutiny,

caṇḍikato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'mā kho caṇḍikato bhaṇi', 'caṇḍikato' is the ablative singular of 'caṇḍika', an adverbial form derived from the adjective 'caṇḍa' (fierce), indicating the manner of speaking: 'don't speak in a fierce way'.

suvuttaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, suvuttaṃ sikkhāpadānulomikaṃ describes speech that is well-spoken and aligned with the monastic training rules (sikkhāpadā), emphasizing propriety and adherence to Vinaya principles.
suvuttaṃ.translation_1: Well-spoken in line with the training rules—
suvuttaṃ.translation_2: Well-spoken in line with the training rules—

sikkhāpadānulomikaṃ.meaning_2: in line with the training rules; conforming to the precepts
sikkhāpadānulomikaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sikkhāpadānulomikaṃ is the neuter accusative singular, modifying suvuttaṃ ('well-spoken'), indicating speech that aligns with or follows the monastic training precepts (sikkhāpada) as per the Vinaya context.
sikkhāpadānulomikaṃ.translation_1: Well-spoken in line with the training rules—
sikkhāpadānulomikaṃ.translation_2: Well-spoken in line with the training rules—

kālenatthūpasaṃhitaṃ.meaning_2: at the right time, what is connected with the goal; timely and goal-oriented; appropriately connected with benefit or meaning
kālenatthūpasaṃhitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form appears as a fused instrumental adverbial phrase with accusative adjective, likely functioning adverbially in context to describe something done 'at the right time and connected with the goal.' The English translation supports this as a cohesive unit emphasizing timeliness and purpose.
kālenatthūpasaṃhitaṃ.translation_1: At the right time, what is connected with the goal.

padhāresi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'sahasa vohāraṃ mā padhāresi', the form is an imperative advising against hasty consideration or judgment of words or statements (vohāraṃ).

paṭiññānusandhitena.meaning_2: in accordance with the admission; in line with the acknowledgement
paṭiññānusandhitena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental singular form of a compound adjective used as a noun in the Vinaya context, meaning 'by what is joined to the admission' or 'in conformity with the admission'. It refers to handling matters according to the accused's acknowledgement of the offense, as per the English translation.
paṭiññānusandhitena.translation_1: Both should be dealt with in line with their admission.

vattānusandhitena.meaning_2: connection with conduct; accordance with behavior; conformity to custom
vattānusandhitena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'vattānusandhitena kāraye', this instrumental form indicates the manner in which actions should be carried out, aligning with the English translation 'in line with their conduct'. It combines 'vatta' (conduct, custom) and 'anusandhi' (connection, sequence), implying handling matters in conformity to one's behavior or established practices.
vattānusandhitena.translation_1: They should be dealt with in line with their conduct.

vuttānusandhitena.meaning_2: with the connection of what was said; with the sequential arrangement as stated
vuttānusandhitena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental singular form of the compound 'vuttānusandhi', where 'vutta' (said, spoken) combines with 'anusandhi' (connection, sequence) to indicate something linked to or following from what has been stated, likely in a grammatical or textual context given the related entries on prosody and compounds.

alajjīpuggalo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound alajjīpuggalo describes a person lacking shame, as used in the sentence where such individuals are explicitly termed shameless. The first component alajjī negates lajjī (having conscience), derived from √lajj.

lajjīpuggalo.meaning_2: conscientious person; person who has conscience; person who is ashamed
lajjīpuggalo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'lajjīpuggalo' refers to a person characterized by conscientiousness or sensitivity to shame, as defined by the qualities described in the discourse.
lajjīpuggalo.translation_1: What are they like, the people called conscientious?

mettācitto.meaning_2: with a mind of goodwill; with a benevolent mind; with a kind mind
mettācitto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'mettācitto' contrasts with 'dosantaro' (with a mind of ill will), emphasizing a state of mind characterized by benevolence and goodwill when accusing or speaking, as opposed to malice. It highlights the importance of positive intention in communication.
mettācitto.translation_1: They accuse with a mind of ill will, not a mind of good will—
mettācitto.translation_2: They accuse with a mind of good will, not a mind of ill will—

bālacodako.meaning_2: person who foolishly accuses or rebukes others
bālacodako.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'bālacodako' refers to individuals who ignorantly or foolishly accuse, rebuke, or complain, often in a legal or moral sense, combining the notions of foolishness (bāla) and accusation (codaka).
bālacodako.translation_1: What are they like, the people called ignorant accusers?
bālacodako.translation_2: Such people are called ignorant accusers.

anusandhivacanapathassa.meaning_2: expertise in grammatical connections and modes of expression; knowledge of euphonic combinations and speech patterns
anusandhivacanapathassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound genitive form appears in contexts contrasting knowledge (kovido) and ignorance (akovido) regarding grammatical and expressive skills, as seen in the provided sentences. It likely refers to proficiency in sandhi rules and verbal articulation in Pāḷi composition.

paṇḍitacodako.meaning_2: learned accuser; wise plaintiff; knowledgeable rebuker
paṇḍitacodako.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound paṇḍitacodako describes individuals who are both learned (paṇḍita) and accusers or rebukers (codaka), as defined in the contextual sentences where such people are characterized and named.
paṇḍitacodako.translation_1: What are they like, the people called learned accusers?
paṇḍitacodako.translation_2: Such people are called learned accusers.

ācāradiṭṭhiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in context to indicate 'for' or 'on account of' failure in both conduct (ācāra) and view (diṭṭhi), likely referring to misconduct and wrong views in a disciplinary or ethical sense.
ācāradiṭṭhiyā.translation_1: And for failure in conduct and view;

codanākaṇḍaṃ.meaning_2: process of investigation; section on accusations or charges
codanākaṇḍaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'codanākaṇḍaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ' ('The process of investigation is finished'), codanākaṇḍaṃ refers to the section or procedure involving accusations or investigations, likely in a Vinaya or grammatical context, with niṭṭhitaṃ indicating completion. The compound combines codanā (accusing, charging) and kaṇḍa (section, portion).
codanākaṇḍaṃ.translation_1: The process of investigation  is finished.

anuvijjakaanuyogo.meaning_2: investigation through practice; pursuit of knowledge via application
anuvijjakaanuyogo.construction: anu + vijja + ka + anu + yoge + a
anuvijjakaanuyogo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'anuvijjaka' (investigator) and 'anuyoga' (practice or scrutiny), likely denoting the methodical investigation or application involved in examining dhamma or related concepts in a Pāli text context.

asuddhaparisaṅkito.grammar: pp of parisaṅkati, comp with asuddha
asuddhaparisaṅkito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term functions as a descriptive compound in the nominative singular masculine, referring to a person who harbors suspicion or doubt regarding impurity, as indicated by the repetitive contextual translations.

tenuposatho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines the instrumental pronoun 'tena' (with him) and 'uposatho' (observance-day ceremony), indicating the ceremony performed in his company. In the sentence 'kātabbo tenuposatho', it functions as the object of the gerundive 'kātabbo', meaning 'the observance-day ceremony with him should be done'.
tenuposatho.translation_1: And they should then do the observance-day ceremony with him.
tenuposatho.translation_2: And they should then do the observance-day ceremony with him.

codakādipaṭipatti.meaning_2: proceeding of an accuser, etc.; legal or disciplinary procedure initiated by a complainant and similar parties
codakādipaṭipatti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'codakādipaṭipatti' refers to the procedural aspects in the Vinaya context, specifically the conduct or method of action involving an accuser (codaka) and others (ādi), such as in legal proceedings or monastic discipline, as indicated by the English translation 'The proceeding of an accuser, etc.'
codakādipaṭipatti.translation_1: 2. The proceeding of an accuser, etc.

otiṇṇānotiṇṇaṃ.meaning_1: what has been brought before it and what has not
otiṇṇānotiṇṇaṃ.meaning_2: that which has been presented or come before; that which has not been presented or come before
otiṇṇānotiṇṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, otiṇṇānotiṇṇaṃ refers to matters or cases that have been brought before the Sangha for consideration versus those that have not yet been presented. The first sense of otiṇṇa (descended into) fits the idea of something having come before the assembly, while anotiṇṇa denotes the absence of such presentation.
otiṇṇānotiṇṇaṃ.translation_1: The Sangha should know what has been brought before it and what has not.

sāmaggatthāya.meaning_2: for the sake of unity; for the purpose of reconciliation; for the benefit of reunification
sāmaggatthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given sentence, sāmaggatthāya functions as a dative compound indicating the purpose of the uposatha observance, emphasizing unity or harmony within the monastic community, as per Vinaya context.
sāmaggatthāya.translation_1: The purpose of the observance-day ceremony is unity.

visuddhatthāya.meaning_2: for the sake of purity; for the purpose of purification
visuddhatthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the dative singular form of the tatpuruṣa compound visuddhattha, meaning 'purpose of purity'. In the given sentences, it modifies nouns like pavāraṇā and abbhānaṃ, indicating the goal or intent of these ceremonies and processes is to achieve purity or purification, aligning with the Vinaya's emphasis on moral and ritual cleansing.
visuddhatthāya.translation_1: The purpose of the invitation ceremony is purity.
visuddhatthāya.translation_2: The purpose of rehabilitation is purity.

mānattatthāya.meaning_2: for the purpose of penance; for the sake of the probationary respect
mānattatthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'mānattatthāya' refers to the purpose of mānatta, the probationary period of penance imposed for saṅghādisesa offenses, during which the offender demonstrates respect to the Saṅgha to facilitate rehabilitation; the English translation simplifies 'mānatta' as 'trial period,' but it specifically means a state of paying respect as atonement.
mānattatthāya.translation_1: The purpose of probation is the trial period.

abbhānatthāya.meaning_2: for the purpose of reinstatement; for the sake of readmission
abbhānatthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'mānattaṃ abbhānatthāya' means 'the trial period for the purpose of reinstatement,' where mānattaṃ is the probationary period in the Vinaya leading to abbhāna, the formal readmission after a serious offense.
abbhānatthāya.translation_1: The purpose of the trial period is rehabilitation.

codakassaattajhāpanaṃ.meaning_2: cremation of the plaintiff's self; burning of the accuser's body
codakassaattajhāpanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a tatpuruṣa compound in the genitive singular neuter, referring to the act of cremating the self or body of the plaintiff/accuser (codaka), possibly in a legal or ritual context from the Vinaya.

dhammādhammaṃ.meaning_2: the Teaching and what is contrary to it
dhammādhammaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound dhammādhamma, where dhamma means 'teaching; doctrine' and adhamma means 'false teaching; something opposed to the teaching'. In the context of the sentence, it refers to the Buddhist doctrine and its opposites, highlighting a lack of discernment between righteous and unrighteous paths.
dhammādhammaṃ.translation_1: Not knowing the Teaching and what is contrary to it,

dhammādhammassa.meaning_2: right and wrong; dhamma and adhamma; good and evil
dhammādhammassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive singular form used in the context of being 'ignorant about both' right and wrong, indicating lack of discernment between moral and immoral conduct.

vinayāvinayaṃ.meaning_2: monastic law and what is contrary to it
vinayāvinayaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a dvanda compound juxtaposing vinaya (monastic discipline) and its opposite avinaya, used in the accusative singular to indicate the objects of not knowing, as per the sentence context.
vinayāvinayaṃ.translation_1: Not knowing the Monastic Law and what is contrary to it,

vinayāvinayassa.meaning_2: of the discipline and the non-discipline; of vinaya and avinaya
vinayāvinayassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in genitive singular, used in the context to mean 'of both the discipline and the lack of discipline', indicating ignorance about both aspects as per the sentence 'vinayāvinayassa akovido' meaning 'ignorant about both'.

bhāsitābhāsitaṃ.meaning_2: what was spoken and what was not; what was said and what was not
bhāsitābhāsitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a dvanda compound functioning as a neuter noun in the accusative singular, referring to the pair of spoken and unspoken things. In the sentence, it is the object of 'na jānāti' (does not know), indicating confusion or lack of awareness about what was uttered versus what was not.
bhāsitābhāsitaṃ.translation_1: Not knowing what was spoken and what was not,

bhāsitābhāsitassa.meaning_2: of that which has been said and not said; of speech and silence; of the spoken and unspoken
bhāsitābhāsitassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound bhāsitābhāsitassa is the genitive singular form, indicating 'of one ignorant about both the spoken and unspoken' in the context of the sentence, where akovido means 'ignorant' or 'unskilled'. This likely refers to a person lacking knowledge of both doctrine (what has been taught) and what remains untaught, or broadly, speech and its absence.

āciṇṇānāciṇṇaṃ.meaning_2: what was practiced and what was not; practiced and unpracticed
āciṇṇānāciṇṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence, this compound neuter accusative singular noun serves as the object of 'jānāti', referring to the distinction between customary or practiced actions and those that are not, in the context of ignorance about moral or habitual conduct.
āciṇṇānāciṇṇaṃ.translation_1: Not knowing what was practiced and what was not,

āciṇṇānāciṇṇassa.meaning_2: accustomed and unaccustomed; practiced and unpracticed; customary and non-customary
āciṇṇānāciṇṇassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound used as a genitive singular adjective modifying 'akovido' (the ignorant one). In context, it refers to someone lacking knowledge or skill regarding both established customs/practices and those not established, emphasizing ignorance in traditional and non-traditional matters.

āpattānāpattiyā.meaning_2: with regard to offence and non-offence; concerning transgression and non-transgression
āpattānāpattiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the tatpuruṣa compound āpattānāpatti 'offence and non-offence', used in the context of ignorance (akovido) regarding both in Vinaya matters, as in the sentence 'ignorant about both'.

lahukagarukassa.meaning_2: unskilled in light and heavy matters; ignorant about trivial and important things
lahukagarukassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound 'lahukagarukassa' is the genitive singular form, modifying 'akovido' (ignorant). In context, it describes someone lacking knowledge or skill in distinguishing between light (trifling, unimportant) and heavy (serious, weighty) matters, hence ignorant about both.

sāvasesānavasesassa.meaning_2: with remainder and without remainder; complete and incomplete
sāvasesānavasesassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, the compound describes someone ignorant about both types of offenses: the sāvasesa (remediable, with remainder) and anavasesa (irremediable, without remainder), indicating a lack of understanding of Vinaya classifications.

mūlenuposatho.meaning_2: beginning at the root, observance day
mūlenuposatho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound noun refers to the initial or foundational observance day, likely indicating the starting point of the uposatha observance in a sequence or ritual context, as suggested by the sentence 'Beginning, at the root, observance day'.
mūlenuposatho.translation_1: Beginning, at the root, observance day,

codanakaṇḍamhi.meaning_2: process of investigation; section of accusation
codanakaṇḍamhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound codanakaṇḍa combines 'codanā' (accusation, charging) with 'kaṇḍa' (section, portion), referring to the investigative process in legal or disciplinary contexts, as in the Vinaya. The locative 'mhi' indicates 'in the process of investigation'.

patiṭṭhāpayanti.meaning_2: firmly establish; cause to stand back
patiṭṭhāpayanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'sāsanaṃ patiṭṭhāpayanti,' the verb describes the action of establishing or firmly setting up the Buddhist teaching (sāsana), emphasizing stability and foundation.

cūḷasaṅgāmo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound likely in nominative singular, denoting a lesser or minor instance of battle or war based on the components.

anuvijjakassapaṭipatti.meaning_2: procedure for an investigator; method of the examiner's conduct
anuvijjakassapaṭipatti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'anuvijjakassa' (genitive of 'anuvijjaka', investigator) modifies 'paṭipatti' (practice, procedure). The English translation 'The procedure for an investigator' reflects the genitive sense, indicating the method or conduct pertaining to an investigator, likely in a Vinaya or monastic context.

nisajjakusalena.meaning_2: skilled in where to sit down; competent in appropriate seating
nisajjakusalena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in the context of monastic etiquette, emphasizing skill in choosing and taking one's seat without disturbing others, as per the Vinaya guidelines for harmonious community living.
nisajjakusalena.example_1: āsanakusalena bhavitabbaṃ nisajjakusalena; there bhikkhū anupakhajjantena, nave bhikkhū āsanena appaṭibāhantena, yathāpatirūpe āsane nisīditabbaṃ;
nisajjakusalena.translation_1: be skilled in appropriate seating and where to sit down, taking a seat without encroaching on the senior monks and without blocking the junior monks;
nisajjakusalena.example_2: āsanakusalena bhavitabbaṃ nisajjakusalena, yugamattaṃ pekkhantena atthaṃ anuvidhiyantena sake āsane nisīditabbaṃ, na ca āsanā vuṭṭhātabbaṃ, na vītihātabbaṃ, na kummaggo sevitabbo, na bāhāvikkhepakaṃ bhaṇitabbaṃ, aturitena bhavitabbaṃ asāhasikena, acaṇḍikatena bhavitabbaṃ vacanakkhamena, mettācittena bhavitabbaṃ hitānukampinā, kāruṇikena bhavitabbaṃ hitaparisakkinā, asamphappalāpinā bhavitabbaṃ pariyantabhāṇinā, averavasikena bhavitabbaṃ anasuruttena, attā pariggahetabbo, paro pariggahetabbo, codako pariggahetabbo, cuditako pariggahetabbo, adhammacodako pariggahetabbo, adhammacuditako pariggahetabbo, dhammacodako pariggahetabbo, dhammacuditako pariggahetabbo, vuttaṃ ahāpentena avuttaṃ apakāsentena otiṇṇāni padabyañjanāni sādhukaṃ pariggahetvā paro paṭipucchitvā yathā paṭiññāya kāretabbo, mando hāsetabbo, bhīrū assāsetabbo, caṇḍo nisedhetabbo, asuci vibhāvetabbo, ujumaddavena na chandāgatiṃ gantabbaṃ, na dosāgatiṃ gantabbaṃ, na mohāgatiṃ gantabbaṃ, na bhayāgatiṃ gantabbaṃ, majjhattena bhavitabbaṃ dhammesu ca puggalesu ca.
nisajjakusalena.translation_2: He should be skilled in appropriate seating and where to sit down. Looking a plow’s length ahead, acting in line with his aim, he should sit down on his own seat. He should not get up from his seat, bungle the investigation, take a wrong path, or gesticulate. He should proceed without haste or force, not be fierce, and be patient with others’ speech. He should have mind of loving kindness with compassion and empathy, and strive for what is beneficial. He should not speak idly but to the point, without being angry or argumentative. He should assess himself, the others, the accuser, the accused, one who accuses illegitimately, one who is accused illegitimately, one who accuses legitimately, and one who is accused legitimately. Not omitting what has been said, nor announcing what has not been said, he should carefully scrutinize the sentences and words under consideration, question the others, and deal with them according to what they have admitted. He should gladden those who are confused, comfort those who are frightened, restrain those who are fierce, and expose those who are impure. Being upright and gentle, he should not be biased by favoritism, anger, confusion, or fear. He should be impartial in regard to the Teaching and the people involved.

appaṭibāhantena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, appaṭibāhantena describes the manner of taking a seat with 'āsanena' (instrumental), meaning without obstructing or blocking the junior monks (nave bhikkhū) from their seating positions, ensuring considerate placement of the seat.
appaṭibāhantena.example_1: āsanakusalena bhavitabbaṃ nisajjakusalena; there bhikkhū anupakhajjantena, nave bhikkhū āsanena appaṭibāhantena, yathāpatirūpe āsane nisīditabbaṃ;
appaṭibāhantena.translation_1: be skilled in appropriate seating and where to sit down, taking a seat without encroaching on the senior monks and without blocking the junior monks;
appaṭibāhantena.example_2: saṅgāmāvacarena, upāli, bhikkhunā saṅghaṃ upasaṅkamantena nīcacittena saṅgho upasaṅkamitabbo, rajoharaṇasamena cittena, āsanakusalena bhavitabbaṃ nissajjakusalena, there bhikkhū anupakhajjantena, nave bhikkhū āsanena appaṭibāhantena yathāpatirūpe āsane nisīditabbaṃ, anānākathikena bhavitabbaṃ atiracchānakathikena, sāmaṃ vā dhammo bhāsitabbo, paro vā ajjhesitabbo, ariyo vā tuṇhībhāvo nātimaññitabbo, sace, upāli, saṅgho samaggakaraṇīyāni kammāni karoti;
appaṭibāhantena.translation_2: (1) he should be humble; (2) he should be intent on removing defilements; (3) he should be skilled in appropriate seating and where to sit down, taking a seat without encroaching on the senior monks and without blocking the junior monks; (4) he shouldn’t ramble or engage in worldly talk, but should speak according to the Teaching or invite others to speak or value noble silence; (5) if the Sangha is doing legal procedures requiring unity, but the monk doesn’t approve, then he should reveal his view but think, ‘I shouldn’t be at variance with the Sangha,’ and unity can then be announced.”

yathāpatirūpe.meaning_2: in a suitable seat; in an appropriate place; in a fitting position
yathāpatirūpe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'yathāpatirūpe āsane' refers to sitting in a seat that is appropriate according to monastic etiquette, respecting seniority and not obstructing juniors, emphasizing decorum in the assembly.
yathāpatirūpe.example_1: āsanakusalena bhavitabbaṃ nisajjakusalena; there bhikkhū anupakhajjantena, nave bhikkhū āsanena appaṭibāhantena, yathāpatirūpe āsane nisīditabbaṃ;
yathāpatirūpe.translation_1: be skilled in appropriate seating and where to sit down, taking a seat without encroaching on the senior monks and without blocking the junior monks;
yathāpatirūpe.example_2: saṅgāmāvacarena, upāli, bhikkhunā saṅghaṃ upasaṅkamantena nīcacittena saṅgho upasaṅkamitabbo, rajoharaṇasamena cittena, āsanakusalena bhavitabbaṃ nissajjakusalena, there bhikkhū anupakhajjantena, nave bhikkhū āsanena appaṭibāhantena yathāpatirūpe āsane nisīditabbaṃ, anānākathikena bhavitabbaṃ atiracchānakathikena, sāmaṃ vā dhammo bhāsitabbo, paro vā ajjhesitabbo, ariyo vā tuṇhībhāvo nātimaññitabbo, sace, upāli, saṅgho samaggakaraṇīyāni kammāni karoti;
yathāpatirūpe.translation_2: (1) he should be humble; (2) he should be intent on removing defilements; (3) he should be skilled in appropriate seating and where to sit down, taking a seat without encroaching on the senior monks and without blocking the junior monks; (4) he shouldn’t ramble or engage in worldly talk, but should speak according to the Teaching or invite others to speak or value noble silence; (5) if the Sangha is doing legal procedures requiring unity, but the monk doesn’t approve, then he should reveal his view but think, ‘I shouldn’t be at variance with the Sangha,’ and unity can then be announced.”

ajjhesitabbo.meaning_2: should be invited; should be asked to speak
ajjhesitabbo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'paro vā ajjhesitabbo' means 'or another (person) should be invited (to speak)', referring to encouraging others to contribute to the Dhamma discussion in the Saṅgha assembly.
ajjhesitabbo.example_1: anānākathikena bhavitabbaṃ atiracchānakathikena; sāmaṃ vā dhammo bhāsitabbo paro vā ajjhesitabbo ariyo vā tuṇhībhāvo nātimaññitabbo.
ajjhesitabbo.translation_1: not ramble or engage in worldly talk, but speak according to the Teaching or invite others to speak or value noble silence.
ajjhesitabbo.example_2: saṅgāmāvacarena, upāli, bhikkhunā saṅghaṃ upasaṅkamantena nīcacittena saṅgho upasaṅkamitabbo, rajoharaṇasamena cittena, āsanakusalena bhavitabbaṃ nissajjakusalena, there bhikkhū anupakhajjantena, nave bhikkhū āsanena appaṭibāhantena yathāpatirūpe āsane nisīditabbaṃ, anānākathikena bhavitabbaṃ atiracchānakathikena, sāmaṃ vā dhammo bhāsitabbo, paro vā ajjhesitabbo, ariyo vā tuṇhībhāvo nātimaññitabbo, sace, upāli, saṅgho samaggakaraṇīyāni kammāni karoti;
ajjhesitabbo.translation_2: (1) he should be humble; (2) he should be intent on removing defilements; (3) he should be skilled in appropriate seating and where to sit down, taking a seat without encroaching on the senior monks and without blocking the junior monks; (4) he shouldn’t ramble or engage in worldly talk, but should speak according to the Teaching or invite others to speak or value noble silence; (5) if the Sangha is doing legal procedures requiring unity, but the monk doesn’t approve, then he should reveal his view but think, ‘I shouldn’t be at variance with the Sangha,’ and unity can then be announced.”

anuvijjitukāmena.meaning_2: by one who desires to investigate; by an investigator who wishes to investigate
anuvijjitukāmena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental singular form of a bahuvrīhi compound describing the investigator in the context of Vinaya procedure. It qualifies the agent 'puggalena anuvijjakena', indicating the person approved by the Saṅgha who has the desire to conduct the investigation, emphasizing intent in formal monastic inquiry.
anuvijjitukāmena.example_1: saṅghena anumatena puggalena anuvijjakena anuvijjitukāmena na upajjhāyo pucchitabbo, na ācariyo pucchitabbo, na saddhivihāriko pucchitabbo, na antevāsiko pucchitabbo, na samānupajjhāyako pucchitabbo, na samānācariyako pucchitabbo, na jāti pucchitabbā, na nāmaṃ pucchitabbaṃ, na gottaṃ pucchitabbaṃ, na āgamo pucchitabbo, na kulapadeso pucchitabbo, na jātibhūmi pucchitabbā.
anuvijjitukāmena.translation_1: An investigator—who has been approved by the Sangha and who wishes to investigate—should not ask about preceptor, teacher, student, pupil, co-student, co-pupil, caste, name, family, reciter tradition, home address, or nationality.
anuvijjitukāmena.example_2: saṅghena anumatena puggalena anuvijjakena anuvijjitukāmena saṅghagarukena bhavitabbaṃ no puggalagarukena, saddhammagarukena bhavitabbaṃ no āmisagarukena, atthavasikena bhavitabbaṃ no parisakappikena, kālena anuvijjitabbaṃ no akālena, bhūtena anuvijjitabbaṃ no abhūtena, saṇhena anuvijjitabbaṃ no pharusena, atthasaṃhitena anuvijjitabbaṃ no anatthasaṃhitena, mettācittena anuvijjitabbaṃ no dosantarena, na upakaṇṇakajappinā bhavitabbaṃ, na jimhaṃ pekkhitabbaṃ, na akkhi nikhaṇitabbaṃ, na bhamukaṃ ukkhipitabbaṃ, na sīsaṃ ukkhipitabbaṃ, na hatthavikāro kātabbo, na hatthamuddā dassetabbā.
anuvijjitukāmena.translation_2: An investigator—who has been approved by the Sangha and who wishes to investigate—should respect the Sangha, not individuals; should value the true Dhamma, not worldly things; should value the goal, not conforming to the gathering; should investigate at an appropriate time, not at an inappropriate one; should investigate truthfully, not falsely; should investigate gently, not harshly; should investigate beneficially, not unbeneficially; should investigate with a mind of good will, not with ill will; should not whisper in the ear; should not look for flaws; should not wink; should not raise an eyebrow; should not raise the head; should not signal with the hand; should not gesture with the hand.

kulapadeso.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya rule, 'kulapadeso' refers to the place or address associated with one's family, which an investigator must not inquire about to protect privacy and prevent discrimination during monastic investigations.
kulapadeso.example_1: saṅghena anumatena puggalena anuvijjakena anuvijjitukāmena na upajjhāyo pucchitabbo, na ācariyo pucchitabbo, na saddhivihāriko pucchitabbo, na antevāsiko pucchitabbo, na samānupajjhāyako pucchitabbo, na samānācariyako pucchitabbo, na jāti pucchitabbā, na nāmaṃ pucchitabbaṃ, na gottaṃ pucchitabbaṃ, na āgamo pucchitabbo, na kulapadeso pucchitabbo, na jātibhūmi pucchitabbā.
kulapadeso.translation_1: An investigator—who has been approved by the Sangha and who wishes to investigate—should not ask about preceptor, teacher, student, pupil, co-student, co-pupil, caste, name, family, reciter tradition, home address, or nationality.

saṅghagarukena.meaning_2: respecting the Sangha; giving importance to the community; valuing the monastic order
saṅghagarukena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in the context to advise the investigator to prioritize respect for the Sangha over individuals, emphasizing communal over personal allegiance in monastic proceedings.
saṅghagarukena.example_1: saṅghena anumatena puggalena anuvijjakena anuvijjitukāmena saṅghagarukena bhavitabbaṃ no puggalagarukena, saddhammagarukena bhavitabbaṃ no āmisagarukena, atthavasikena bhavitabbaṃ no parisakappikena, kālena anuvijjitabbaṃ no akālena, bhūtena anuvijjitabbaṃ no abhūtena, saṇhena anuvijjitabbaṃ no pharusena, atthasaṃhitena anuvijjitabbaṃ no anatthasaṃhitena, mettācittena anuvijjitabbaṃ no dosantarena, na upakaṇṇakajappinā bhavitabbaṃ, na jimhaṃ pekkhitabbaṃ, na akkhi nikhaṇitabbaṃ, na bhamukaṃ ukkhipitabbaṃ, na sīsaṃ ukkhipitabbaṃ, na hatthavikāro kātabbo, na hatthamuddā dassetabbā.
saṅghagarukena.translation_1: An investigator—who has been approved by the Sangha and who wishes to investigate—should respect the Sangha, not individuals; should value the true Dhamma, not worldly things; should value the goal, not conforming to the gathering; should investigate at an appropriate time, not at an inappropriate one; should investigate truthfully, not falsely; should investigate gently, not harshly; should investigate beneficially, not unbeneficially; should investigate with a mind of good will, not with ill will; should not whisper in the ear; should not look for flaws; should not wink; should not raise an eyebrow; should not raise the head; should not signal with the hand; should not gesture with the hand.

puggalagarukena.meaning_2: respecting an individual; esteeming a person
puggalagarukena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in the context to contrast with saṅghagarukena, indicating that the investigator should not give importance to individuals but to the Sangha.
puggalagarukena.example_1: saṅghena anumatena puggalena anuvijjakena anuvijjitukāmena saṅghagarukena bhavitabbaṃ no puggalagarukena, saddhammagarukena bhavitabbaṃ no āmisagarukena, atthavasikena bhavitabbaṃ no parisakappikena, kālena anuvijjitabbaṃ no akālena, bhūtena anuvijjitabbaṃ no abhūtena, saṇhena anuvijjitabbaṃ no pharusena, atthasaṃhitena anuvijjitabbaṃ no anatthasaṃhitena, mettācittena anuvijjitabbaṃ no dosantarena, na upakaṇṇakajappinā bhavitabbaṃ, na jimhaṃ pekkhitabbaṃ, na akkhi nikhaṇitabbaṃ, na bhamukaṃ ukkhipitabbaṃ, na sīsaṃ ukkhipitabbaṃ, na hatthavikāro kātabbo, na hatthamuddā dassetabbā.
puggalagarukena.translation_1: An investigator—who has been approved by the Sangha and who wishes to investigate—should respect the Sangha, not individuals; should value the true Dhamma, not worldly things; should value the goal, not conforming to the gathering; should investigate at an appropriate time, not at an inappropriate one; should investigate truthfully, not falsely; should investigate gently, not harshly; should investigate beneficially, not unbeneficially; should investigate with a mind of good will, not with ill will; should not whisper in the ear; should not look for flaws; should not wink; should not raise an eyebrow; should not raise the head; should not signal with the hand; should not gesture with the hand.

saddhammagarukena.meaning_2: valuing the true Dhamma; giving weight to the good teaching; respecting the true doctrine
saddhammagarukena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, it contrasts with āmisagarukena, emphasizing prioritization of spiritual truth over material gains during investigation.
saddhammagarukena.example_1: saṅghena anumatena puggalena anuvijjakena anuvijjitukāmena saṅghagarukena bhavitabbaṃ no puggalagarukena, saddhammagarukena bhavitabbaṃ no āmisagarukena, atthavasikena bhavitabbaṃ no parisakappikena, kālena anuvijjitabbaṃ no akālena, bhūtena anuvijjitabbaṃ no abhūtena, saṇhena anuvijjitabbaṃ no pharusena, atthasaṃhitena anuvijjitabbaṃ no anatthasaṃhitena, mettācittena anuvijjitabbaṃ no dosantarena, na upakaṇṇakajappinā bhavitabbaṃ, na jimhaṃ pekkhitabbaṃ, na akkhi nikhaṇitabbaṃ, na bhamukaṃ ukkhipitabbaṃ, na sīsaṃ ukkhipitabbaṃ, na hatthavikāro kātabbo, na hatthamuddā dassetabbā.
saddhammagarukena.translation_1: An investigator—who has been approved by the Sangha and who wishes to investigate—should respect the Sangha, not individuals; should value the true Dhamma, not worldly things; should value the goal, not conforming to the gathering; should investigate at an appropriate time, not at an inappropriate one; should investigate truthfully, not falsely; should investigate gently, not harshly; should investigate beneficially, not unbeneficially; should investigate with a mind of good will, not with ill will; should not whisper in the ear; should not look for flaws; should not wink; should not raise an eyebrow; should not raise the head; should not signal with the hand; should not gesture with the hand.

āmisagarukena.meaning_2: valuing worldly gain; giving weight to material benefit; attached to worldly things
āmisagarukena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, āmisagarukena contrasts with saddhammagarukena, advising against valuing material or worldly benefits over the true Dhamma during investigation.
āmisagarukena.example_1: saṅghena anumatena puggalena anuvijjakena anuvijjitukāmena saṅghagarukena bhavitabbaṃ no puggalagarukena, saddhammagarukena bhavitabbaṃ no āmisagarukena, atthavasikena bhavitabbaṃ no parisakappikena, kālena anuvijjitabbaṃ no akālena, bhūtena anuvijjitabbaṃ no abhūtena, saṇhena anuvijjitabbaṃ no pharusena, atthasaṃhitena anuvijjitabbaṃ no anatthasaṃhitena, mettācittena anuvijjitabbaṃ no dosantarena, na upakaṇṇakajappinā bhavitabbaṃ, na jimhaṃ pekkhitabbaṃ, na akkhi nikhaṇitabbaṃ, na bhamukaṃ ukkhipitabbaṃ, na sīsaṃ ukkhipitabbaṃ, na hatthavikāro kātabbo, na hatthamuddā dassetabbā.
āmisagarukena.translation_1: An investigator—who has been approved by the Sangha and who wishes to investigate—should respect the Sangha, not individuals; should value the true Dhamma, not worldly things; should value the goal, not conforming to the gathering; should investigate at an appropriate time, not at an inappropriate one; should investigate truthfully, not falsely; should investigate gently, not harshly; should investigate beneficially, not unbeneficially; should investigate with a mind of good will, not with ill will; should not whisper in the ear; should not look for flaws; should not wink; should not raise an eyebrow; should not raise the head; should not signal with the hand; should not gesture with the hand.

parisakappikena.meaning_2: conforming to the assembly; catering to the gathering; speculating according to the crowd
parisakappikena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, parisakappikena contrasts with atthavasikena, indicating that the investigator should focus on the goal (attha) rather than being swayed by or conforming to the expectations of the assembly (parisā). The term likely derives from parisā (assembly) and kappika (speculating or theorizing), suggesting a mindset adjusted to the group's views.
parisakappikena.example_1: saṅghena anumatena puggalena anuvijjakena anuvijjitukāmena saṅghagarukena bhavitabbaṃ no puggalagarukena, saddhammagarukena bhavitabbaṃ no āmisagarukena, atthavasikena bhavitabbaṃ no parisakappikena, kālena anuvijjitabbaṃ no akālena, bhūtena anuvijjitabbaṃ no abhūtena, saṇhena anuvijjitabbaṃ no pharusena, atthasaṃhitena anuvijjitabbaṃ no anatthasaṃhitena, mettācittena anuvijjitabbaṃ no dosantarena, na upakaṇṇakajappinā bhavitabbaṃ, na jimhaṃ pekkhitabbaṃ, na akkhi nikhaṇitabbaṃ, na bhamukaṃ ukkhipitabbaṃ, na sīsaṃ ukkhipitabbaṃ, na hatthavikāro kātabbo, na hatthamuddā dassetabbā.
parisakappikena.translation_1: An investigator—who has been approved by the Sangha and who wishes to investigate—should respect the Sangha, not individuals; should value the true Dhamma, not worldly things; should value the goal, not conforming to the gathering; should investigate at an appropriate time, not at an inappropriate one; should investigate truthfully, not falsely; should investigate gently, not harshly; should investigate beneficially, not unbeneficially; should investigate with a mind of good will, not with ill will; should not whisper in the ear; should not look for flaws; should not wink; should not raise an eyebrow; should not raise the head; should not signal with the hand; should not gesture with the hand.

anuvijjitabbaṃ.meaning_2: to be investigated; that which should be investigated
anuvijjitabbaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'anuvijjitabbaṃ' is used in adverbial phrases like 'kālena anuvijjitabbaṃ' meaning 'it should be investigated at the appropriate time,' prescribing the proper manner for an investigator (anuvijjaka) in Vinaya proceedings to ensure fairness and adherence to Dhamma principles.
anuvijjitabbaṃ.example_1: saṅghena anumatena puggalena anuvijjakena anuvijjitukāmena saṅghagarukena bhavitabbaṃ no puggalagarukena, saddhammagarukena bhavitabbaṃ no āmisagarukena, atthavasikena bhavitabbaṃ no parisakappikena, kālena anuvijjitabbaṃ no akālena, bhūtena anuvijjitabbaṃ no abhūtena, saṇhena anuvijjitabbaṃ no pharusena, atthasaṃhitena anuvijjitabbaṃ no anatthasaṃhitena, mettācittena anuvijjitabbaṃ no dosantarena, na upakaṇṇakajappinā bhavitabbaṃ, na jimhaṃ pekkhitabbaṃ, na akkhi nikhaṇitabbaṃ, na bhamukaṃ ukkhipitabbaṃ, na sīsaṃ ukkhipitabbaṃ, na hatthavikāro kātabbo, na hatthamuddā dassetabbā.

anuvijjitabbaṃ.example_2: saṅghena anumatena puggalena anuvijjakena anuvijjitukāmena saṅghagarukena bhavitabbaṃ no puggalagarukena, saddhammagarukena bhavitabbaṃ no āmisagarukena, atthavasikena bhavitabbaṃ no parisakappikena, kālena anuvijjitabbaṃ no akālena, bhūtena anuvijjitabbaṃ no abhūtena, saṇhena anuvijjitabbaṃ no pharusena, atthasaṃhitena anuvijjitabbaṃ no anatthasaṃhitena, mettācittena anuvijjitabbaṃ no dosantarena, na upakaṇṇakajappinā bhavitabbaṃ, na jimhaṃ pekkhitabbaṃ, na akkhi nikhaṇitabbaṃ, na bhamukaṃ ukkhipitabbaṃ, na sīsaṃ ukkhipitabbaṃ, na hatthavikāro kātabbo, na hatthamuddā dassetabbā.
anuvijjitabbaṃ.translation_2: An investigator—who has been approved by the Sangha and who wishes to investigate—should respect the Sangha, not individuals; should value the true Dhamma, not worldly things; should value the goal, not conforming to the gathering; should investigate at an appropriate time, not at an inappropriate one; should investigate truthfully, not falsely; should investigate gently, not harshly; should investigate beneficially, not unbeneficially; should investigate with a mind of good will, not with ill will; should not whisper in the ear; should not look for flaws; should not wink; should not raise an eyebrow; should not raise the head; should not signal with the hand; should not gesture with the hand.

nikhaṇitabbaṃ.meaning_2: should be lowered; should be cast down
nikhaṇitabbaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'na akkhi nikhaṇitabbaṃ' means 'the eye should not be lowered or winked,' indicating a prohibition against making such a gesture during investigation to maintain proper decorum.
nikhaṇitabbaṃ.example_1: saṅghena anumatena puggalena anuvijjakena anuvijjitukāmena saṅghagarukena bhavitabbaṃ no puggalagarukena, saddhammagarukena bhavitabbaṃ no āmisagarukena, atthavasikena bhavitabbaṃ no parisakappikena, kālena anuvijjitabbaṃ no akālena, bhūtena anuvijjitabbaṃ no abhūtena, saṇhena anuvijjitabbaṃ no pharusena, atthasaṃhitena anuvijjitabbaṃ no anatthasaṃhitena, mettācittena anuvijjitabbaṃ no dosantarena, na upakaṇṇakajappinā bhavitabbaṃ, na jimhaṃ pekkhitabbaṃ, na akkhi nikhaṇitabbaṃ, na bhamukaṃ ukkhipitabbaṃ, na sīsaṃ ukkhipitabbaṃ, na hatthavikāro kātabbo, na hatthamuddā dassetabbā.
nikhaṇitabbaṃ.translation_1: An investigator—who has been approved by the Sangha and who wishes to investigate—should respect the Sangha, not individuals; should value the true Dhamma, not worldly things; should value the goal, not conforming to the gathering; should investigate at an appropriate time, not at an inappropriate one; should investigate truthfully, not falsely; should investigate gently, not harshly; should investigate beneficially, not unbeneficially; should investigate with a mind of good will, not with ill will; should not whisper in the ear; should not look for flaws; should not wink; should not raise an eyebrow; should not raise the head; should not signal with the hand; should not gesture with the hand.

hatthamuddā.meaning_2: hand gesture; signaling with the hand
hatthamuddā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'hatthamuddā dassetabbā' is negated to prohibit showing hand gestures during investigation, emphasizing proper conduct without signaling.
hatthamuddā.example_1: saṅghena anumatena puggalena anuvijjakena anuvijjitukāmena saṅghagarukena bhavitabbaṃ no puggalagarukena, saddhammagarukena bhavitabbaṃ no āmisagarukena, atthavasikena bhavitabbaṃ no parisakappikena, kālena anuvijjitabbaṃ no akālena, bhūtena anuvijjitabbaṃ no abhūtena, saṇhena anuvijjitabbaṃ no pharusena, atthasaṃhitena anuvijjitabbaṃ no anatthasaṃhitena, mettācittena anuvijjitabbaṃ no dosantarena, na upakaṇṇakajappinā bhavitabbaṃ, na jimhaṃ pekkhitabbaṃ, na akkhi nikhaṇitabbaṃ, na bhamukaṃ ukkhipitabbaṃ, na sīsaṃ ukkhipitabbaṃ, na hatthavikāro kātabbo, na hatthamuddā dassetabbā.
hatthamuddā.translation_1: An investigator—who has been approved by the Sangha and who wishes to investigate—should respect the Sangha, not individuals; should value the true Dhamma, not worldly things; should value the goal, not conforming to the gathering; should investigate at an appropriate time, not at an inappropriate one; should investigate truthfully, not falsely; should investigate gently, not harshly; should investigate beneficially, not unbeneficially; should investigate with a mind of good will, not with ill will; should not whisper in the ear; should not look for flaws; should not wink; should not raise an eyebrow; should not raise the head; should not signal with the hand; should not gesture with the hand.

anuvidhiyantena.meaning_2: acting in accordance with; conforming to; following
anuvidhiyantena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'anuvidhiyantena' describes the monk's conduct during investigation, emphasizing adherence to the intended purpose or goal (atthaṃ), ensuring actions align with the objective of the proceedings.
anuvidhiyantena.example_1: āsanakusalena bhavitabbaṃ nisajjakusalena, yugamattaṃ pekkhantena atthaṃ anuvidhiyantena sake āsane nisīditabbaṃ, na ca āsanā vuṭṭhātabbaṃ, na vītihātabbaṃ, na kummaggo sevitabbo, na bāhāvikkhepakaṃ bhaṇitabbaṃ, aturitena bhavitabbaṃ asāhasikena, acaṇḍikatena bhavitabbaṃ vacanakkhamena, mettācittena bhavitabbaṃ hitānukampinā, kāruṇikena bhavitabbaṃ hitaparisakkinā, asamphappalāpinā bhavitabbaṃ pariyantabhāṇinā, averavasikena bhavitabbaṃ anasuruttena, attā pariggahetabbo, paro pariggahetabbo, codako pariggahetabbo, cuditako pariggahetabbo, adhammacodako pariggahetabbo, adhammacuditako pariggahetabbo, dhammacodako pariggahetabbo, dhammacuditako pariggahetabbo, vuttaṃ ahāpentena avuttaṃ apakāsentena otiṇṇāni padabyañjanāni sādhukaṃ pariggahetvā paro paṭipucchitvā yathā paṭiññāya kāretabbo, mando hāsetabbo, bhīrū assāsetabbo, caṇḍo nisedhetabbo, asuci vibhāvetabbo, ujumaddavena na chandāgatiṃ gantabbaṃ, na dosāgatiṃ gantabbaṃ, na mohāgatiṃ gantabbaṃ, na bhayāgatiṃ gantabbaṃ, majjhattena bhavitabbaṃ dhammesu ca puggalesu ca.
anuvidhiyantena.translation_1: He should be skilled in appropriate seating and where to sit down. Looking a plow’s length ahead, acting in line with his aim, he should sit down on his own seat. He should not get up from his seat, bungle the investigation, take a wrong path, or gesticulate. He should proceed without haste or force, not be fierce, and be patient with others’ speech. He should have mind of loving kindness with compassion and empathy, and strive for what is beneficial. He should not speak idly but to the point, without being angry or argumentative. He should assess himself, the others, the accuser, the accused, one who accuses illegitimately, one who is accused illegitimately, one who accuses legitimately, and one who is accused legitimately. Not omitting what has been said, nor announcing what has not been said, he should carefully scrutinize the sentences and words under consideration, question the others, and deal with them according to what they have admitted. He should gladden those who are confused, comfort those who are frightened, restrain those who are fierce, and expose those who are impure. Being upright and gentle, he should not be biased by favoritism, anger, confusion, or fear. He should be impartial in regard to the Teaching and the people involved.

vītihātabbaṃ.meaning_2: to be avoided; to be bungled; to be transgressed
vītihātabbaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'na vītihātabbaṃ' indicates that the investigation or procedure should not be bungled or deviated from, aligning with the English translation 'bungle the investigation'. The prefix vīti- suggests excessive or faulty action leading to something that must be avoided.

asāhasikena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'asāhasikena bhavitabbaṃ' instructs the monk to proceed without rashness or force during the legal proceedings, emphasizing a measured and calm approach to avoid errors in judgment.

acaṇḍikatena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'acaṇḍikatena' is an instrumental singular form modifying the implied subject (a judge or mediator), emphasizing the need to proceed without fierceness or violence, in contrast to 'caṇḍo nisedhetabbo' where the fierce one must be restrained.

hitaparisakkinā.meaning_2: with compassion and empathy; with sympathy for the welfare of the assembly
hitaparisakkinā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, hitaparisakkinā describes the mindset of the Vinaya judge or arbiter, emphasizing compassionate concern for the benefit of those gathered in the assembly during adjudication. The suffix -kīna (instrumental of -kin) denotes a quality or state related to seeking welfare for the group.
hitaparisakkinā.example_1: āsanakusalena bhavitabbaṃ nisajjakusalena, yugamattaṃ pekkhantena atthaṃ anuvidhiyantena sake āsane nisīditabbaṃ, na ca āsanā vuṭṭhātabbaṃ, na vītihātabbaṃ, na kummaggo sevitabbo, na bāhāvikkhepakaṃ bhaṇitabbaṃ, aturitena bhavitabbaṃ asāhasikena, acaṇḍikatena bhavitabbaṃ vacanakkhamena, mettācittena bhavitabbaṃ hitānukampinā, kāruṇikena bhavitabbaṃ hitaparisakkinā, asamphappalāpinā bhavitabbaṃ pariyantabhāṇinā, averavasikena bhavitabbaṃ anasuruttena, attā pariggahetabbo, paro pariggahetabbo, codako pariggahetabbo, cuditako pariggahetabbo, adhammacodako pariggahetabbo, adhammacuditako pariggahetabbo, dhammacodako pariggahetabbo, dhammacuditako pariggahetabbo, vuttaṃ ahāpentena avuttaṃ apakāsentena otiṇṇāni padabyañjanāni sādhukaṃ pariggahetvā paro paṭipucchitvā yathā paṭiññāya kāretabbo, mando hāsetabbo, bhīrū assāsetabbo, caṇḍo nisedhetabbo, asuci vibhāvetabbo, ujumaddavena na chandāgatiṃ gantabbaṃ, na dosāgatiṃ gantabbaṃ, na mohāgatiṃ gantabbaṃ, na bhayāgatiṃ gantabbaṃ, majjhattena bhavitabbaṃ dhammesu ca puggalesu ca.
hitaparisakkinā.translation_1: He should be skilled in appropriate seating and where to sit down. Looking a plow’s length ahead, acting in line with his aim, he should sit down on his own seat. He should not get up from his seat, bungle the investigation, take a wrong path, or gesticulate. He should proceed without haste or force, not be fierce, and be patient with others’ speech. He should have mind of loving kindness with compassion and empathy, and strive for what is beneficial. He should not speak idly but to the point, without being angry or argumentative. He should assess himself, the others, the accuser, the accused, one who accuses illegitimately, one who is accused illegitimately, one who accuses legitimately, and one who is accused legitimately. Not omitting what has been said, nor announcing what has not been said, he should carefully scrutinize the sentences and words under consideration, question the others, and deal with them according to what they have admitted. He should gladden those who are confused, comfort those who are frightened, restrain those who are fierce, and expose those who are impure. Being upright and gentle, he should not be biased by favoritism, anger, confusion, or fear. He should be impartial in regard to the Teaching and the people involved.

pariggahetabbo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya text, pariggahetabbo refers to the duty of the adjudicator to carefully assess or take into account various parties involved in a dispute, such as oneself (attā), the other party (paro), the accuser (codaka), and others, to ensure impartial and proper handling of the matter. This usage emphasizes discernment and thorough evaluation rather than material possession.

ahāpentena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'vuttaṃ ahāpentena' means 'not omitting what has been said', where 'ahāpentena' is the instrumental singular present participle of ahāpeti, functioning adverbially to indicate the manner of scrutinizing statements during legal proceedings in the Vinaya.
ahāpentena.example_1: āsanakusalena bhavitabbaṃ nisajjakusalena, yugamattaṃ pekkhantena atthaṃ anuvidhiyantena sake āsane nisīditabbaṃ, na ca āsanā vuṭṭhātabbaṃ, na vītihātabbaṃ, na kummaggo sevitabbo, na bāhāvikkhepakaṃ bhaṇitabbaṃ, aturitena bhavitabbaṃ asāhasikena, acaṇḍikatena bhavitabbaṃ vacanakkhamena, mettācittena bhavitabbaṃ hitānukampinā, kāruṇikena bhavitabbaṃ hitaparisakkinā, asamphappalāpinā bhavitabbaṃ pariyantabhāṇinā, averavasikena bhavitabbaṃ anasuruttena, attā pariggahetabbo, paro pariggahetabbo, codako pariggahetabbo, cuditako pariggahetabbo, adhammacodako pariggahetabbo, adhammacuditako pariggahetabbo, dhammacodako pariggahetabbo, dhammacuditako pariggahetabbo, vuttaṃ ahāpentena avuttaṃ apakāsentena otiṇṇāni padabyañjanāni sādhukaṃ pariggahetvā paro paṭipucchitvā yathā paṭiññāya kāretabbo, mando hāsetabbo, bhīrū assāsetabbo, caṇḍo nisedhetabbo, asuci vibhāvetabbo, ujumaddavena na chandāgatiṃ gantabbaṃ, na dosāgatiṃ gantabbaṃ, na mohāgatiṃ gantabbaṃ, na bhayāgatiṃ gantabbaṃ, majjhattena bhavitabbaṃ dhammesu ca puggalesu ca.

apakāsentena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya text on judicial procedure, 'avuttaṃ apakāsentena' instructs the judge not to declare or reveal what has not been stated, ensuring fidelity to the actual testimony and preventing fabrication or unwarranted disclosure.
apakāsentena.example_1: āsanakusalena bhavitabbaṃ nisajjakusalena, yugamattaṃ pekkhantena atthaṃ anuvidhiyantena sake āsane nisīditabbaṃ, na ca āsanā vuṭṭhātabbaṃ, na vītihātabbaṃ, na kummaggo sevitabbo, na bāhāvikkhepakaṃ bhaṇitabbaṃ, aturitena bhavitabbaṃ asāhasikena, acaṇḍikatena bhavitabbaṃ vacanakkhamena, mettācittena bhavitabbaṃ hitānukampinā, kāruṇikena bhavitabbaṃ hitaparisakkinā, asamphappalāpinā bhavitabbaṃ pariyantabhāṇinā, averavasikena bhavitabbaṃ anasuruttena, attā pariggahetabbo, paro pariggahetabbo, codako pariggahetabbo, cuditako pariggahetabbo, adhammacodako pariggahetabbo, adhammacuditako pariggahetabbo, dhammacodako pariggahetabbo, dhammacuditako pariggahetabbo, vuttaṃ ahāpentena avuttaṃ apakāsentena otiṇṇāni padabyañjanāni sādhukaṃ pariggahetvā paro paṭipucchitvā yathā paṭiññāya kāretabbo, mando hāsetabbo, bhīrū assāsetabbo, caṇḍo nisedhetabbo, asuci vibhāvetabbo, ujumaddavena na chandāgatiṃ gantabbaṃ, na dosāgatiṃ gantabbaṃ, na mohāgatiṃ gantabbaṃ, na bhayāgatiṃ gantabbaṃ, majjhattena bhavitabbaṃ dhammesu ca puggalesu ca.
apakāsentena.translation_1: He should be skilled in appropriate seating and where to sit down. Looking a plow’s length ahead, acting in line with his aim, he should sit down on his own seat. He should not get up from his seat, bungle the investigation, take a wrong path, or gesticulate. He should proceed without haste or force, not be fierce, and be patient with others’ speech. He should have mind of loving kindness with compassion and empathy, and strive for what is beneficial. He should not speak idly but to the point, without being angry or argumentative. He should assess himself, the others, the accuser, the accused, one who accuses illegitimately, one who is accused illegitimately, one who accuses legitimately, and one who is accused legitimately. Not omitting what has been said, nor announcing what has not been said, he should carefully scrutinize the sentences and words under consideration, question the others, and deal with them according to what they have admitted. He should gladden those who are confused, comfort those who are frightened, restrain those who are fierce, and expose those who are impure. Being upright and gentle, he should not be biased by favoritism, anger, confusion, or fear. He should be impartial in regard to the Teaching and the people involved.

hāsetabbo.meaning_2: should be gladdened; should be made to laugh
hāsetabbo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya text, 'mando hāsetabbo' instructs that a confused or dull person should be gladdened or cheered, using the potential participle to indicate an obligation or recommended action in monastic disciplinary proceedings.

vepo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely a nominal form derived from the root √vip (to tremble, shake), used to denote an instance of shaking or quaking, such as in natural phenomena. No contextual sentence provided, so meaning based on standard Pāli usage in texts like the suttas where vepo refers to earthquakes accompanying significant events.

pahāsetabbo.meaning_2: should be made to laugh; should be gladdened
pahāsetabbo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a future passive participle (gerundive) indicating obligation or desirability, derived from the causative of √has 'to laugh'. It combines the intensive prefix pa- with the causative stem hāse, plus the tabba suffix for potential passive. No contextual sentence provided, so meaning is based on standard usage in Pāli literature, often in ethical or descriptive contexts.

ujumaddavena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in the context of qualities a judge or investigator should embody: being upright (honest, just) and gentle (mild, compassionate) to avoid biases from favoritism, anger, delusion, or fear.

Not omitting what has been said, nor announcing what has not been said, he should carefully scrutinize the sentences and words under consideration, question the others, and deal with them according to what they have admitted. saṃsandanatthāya.meaning_2: for the sake of concluding; for the purpose of converging or bringing together
saṃsandanatthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'suttaṃ saṃsandanatthāya' refers to the suttas or monastic code serving the purpose of concluding or finalizing matters, likely by converging arguments, evidence, or interpretations in legal or doctrinal discussions within the Vinaya framework.
saṃsandanatthāya.example_1: suttaṃ saṃsandanatthāya, opammaṃ nidassanatthāya, attho viññāpanatthāya, paṭipucchā ṭhapanatthāya, okāsakammaṃ codanatthāya, codanā sāraṇatthāya, sāraṇā savacanīyatthāya, savacanīyaṃ palibodhatthāya, palibodho vinicchayatthāya, vinicchayo santīraṇatthāya, santīraṇaṃ ṭhānāṭhānagamanatthāya, ṭhānāṭhānagamanaṃ dummaṅkūnaṃ puggalānaṃ niggahatthāya, pesalānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ sampaggahatthāya, saṅgho sampariggahasampaṭicchanatthāya, saṅghena anumatā puggalā paccekaṭṭhāyino avisaṃvādakaṭṭhāyino.
saṃsandanatthāya.translation_1: The Monastic Code is for the sake of concluding, a simile for the sake of illustration, the goal is to be made known, and questioning is for sake of establishing. Asking for permission is for the sake of accusing, accusing for reminding, reminding for directing, directing for obstructing, obstructing for investigating, investigating for weighing up, weighing up for deciding what is and is not the case, and deciding what is and is not the case is for the sake of restraining bad people and to support the good monks. The Sangha has the purpose of examining and accepting the decision. The Sangha should appoint people who are trustworthy to positions of authority.
saṃsandanatthāya.translation_2: The Monastic Code is for the sake of concluding,

codanatthāya.grammar: masc, comp, dat sg, from codanā + attha
codanatthāya.meaning_2: for the sake of accusing; for the purpose of charging or reprimanding
codanatthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'okāsakammaṃ codanatthāya' indicates that asking for permission serves the purpose of enabling accusation or charging in monastic disciplinary procedures, aligning with the Vinaya's aim to address offenses.

savacanīyatthāya.meaning_2: for the sake of directing; for the purpose of giving instructions
savacanīyatthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'sāraṇā savacanīyatthāya' translates as 'reminding for directing,' where 'directing' refers to instructing or guiding someone, likely in the disciplinary process of the Vinaya.
savacanīyatthāya.example_1: suttaṃ saṃsandanatthāya, opammaṃ nidassanatthāya, attho viññāpanatthāya, paṭipucchā ṭhapanatthāya, okāsakammaṃ codanatthāya, codanā sāraṇatthāya, sāraṇā savacanīyatthāya, savacanīyaṃ palibodhatthāya, palibodho vinicchayatthāya, vinicchayo santīraṇatthāya, santīraṇaṃ ṭhānāṭhānagamanatthāya, ṭhānāṭhānagamanaṃ dummaṅkūnaṃ puggalānaṃ niggahatthāya, pesalānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ sampaggahatthāya, saṅgho sampariggahasampaṭicchanatthāya, saṅghena anumatā puggalā paccekaṭṭhāyino avisaṃvādakaṭṭhāyino.

palibodhatthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'savacanīyaṃ palibodhatthāya' translates as 'directing for obstructing', where palibodha serves as the dative form indicating purpose, functioning as a procedural step in monastic discipline to block or hinder improper actions before proceeding to investigation.

santīraṇatthāya.translation_1: The Monastic Code is for the sake of concluding, a simile for the sake of illustration, the goal is to be made known, and questioning is for sake of establishing. Asking for permission is for the sake of accusing, accusing for reminding, reminding for directing, directing for obstructing, obstructing for investigating, investigating for weighing up, weighing up for deciding what is and is not the case, and deciding what is and is not the case is for the sake of restraining bad people and to support the good monks. ṭhānāṭhānagamanatthāya.meaning_2: for the sake of deciding what is and is not the case
ṭhānāṭhānagamanatthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya procedural chain, this adverbial compound describes the purpose of 'santīraṇaṃ' (weighing up), which is to arrive at a decision on what is appropriate (ṭhāna) or inappropriate (aṭhāna) in the matter under investigation, guiding the subsequent steps in monastic adjudication.
ṭhānāṭhānagamanatthāya.example_1: suttaṃ saṃsandanatthāya, opammaṃ nidassanatthāya, attho viññāpanatthāya, paṭipucchā ṭhapanatthāya, okāsakammaṃ codanatthāya, codanā sāraṇatthāya, sāraṇā savacanīyatthāya, savacanīyaṃ palibodhatthāya, palibodho vinicchayatthāya, vinicchayo santīraṇatthāya, santīraṇaṃ ṭhānāṭhānagamanatthāya, ṭhānāṭhānagamanaṃ dummaṅkūnaṃ puggalānaṃ niggahatthāya, pesalānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ sampaggahatthāya, saṅgho sampariggahasampaṭicchanatthāya, saṅghena anumatā puggalā paccekaṭṭhāyino avisaṃvādakaṭṭhāyino.
