pācittiyāpattipucchā.translation_1: there are questions on the offenses entailing expulsion, on the offenses entailing suspension, on the serious offenses, on the offenses entailing confession, on the offenses entailing acknowledgement, on the offenses of wrong conduct, and on the offenses of wrong speech.

pāṭidesanīyāpattipucchā.meaning_2: question on the offense entailing acknowledgement
pāṭidesanīyāpattipucchā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound noun refers to the formal inquiry or questioning regarding pāṭidesanīyā offenses, which are a category of monastic rules in the Vinaya requiring specific acknowledgement or confession by the offender, as listed alongside other offense categories in the sentence.
pāṭidesanīyāpattipucchā.example_1: pārājikāpattipucchā, saṅghādisesāpattipucchā, thullaccayāpattipucchā, pācittiyāpattipucchā, pāṭidesanīyāpattipucchā, dukkaṭāpattipucchā, dubbhāsitāpattipucchā.
pāṭidesanīyāpattipucchā.translation_1: there are questions on the offenses entailing expulsion, on the offenses entailing suspension, on the serious offenses, on the offenses entailing confession, on the offenses entailing acknowledgement, on the offenses of wrong conduct, and on the offenses of wrong speech.

dukkaṭāpattipucchā.meaning_2: question on the offense of wrong conduct
dukkaṭāpattipucchā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound noun refers to the specific type of interrogation or questioning used in Vinaya procedures concerning dukkaṭa offenses, which are minor rule violations entailing forfeiture or formal meeting of the Saṅgha.
dukkaṭāpattipucchā.example_1: pārājikāpattipucchā, saṅghādisesāpattipucchā, thullaccayāpattipucchā, pācittiyāpattipucchā, pāṭidesanīyāpattipucchā, dukkaṭāpattipucchā, dubbhāsitāpattipucchā.
dukkaṭāpattipucchā.translation_1: there are questions on the offenses entailing expulsion, on the offenses entailing suspension, on the serious offenses, on the offenses entailing confession, on the offenses entailing acknowledgement, on the offenses of wrong conduct, and on the offenses of wrong speech.

dubbhāsitāpattipucchā.meaning_2: question on the offenses of wrong speech
dubbhāsitāpattipucchā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound noun refers to the specific type of inquiry or question concerning offenses involving wrong or false speech in the Vinaya context, as listed alongside other categories of offense inquiries.
dubbhāsitāpattipucchā.example_1: pārājikāpattipucchā, saṅghādisesāpattipucchā, thullaccayāpattipucchā, pācittiyāpattipucchā, pāṭidesanīyāpattipucchā, dukkaṭāpattipucchā, dubbhāsitāpattipucchā.
dubbhāsitāpattipucchā.translation_1: there are questions on the offenses entailing expulsion, on the offenses entailing suspension, on the serious offenses, on the offenses entailing confession, on the offenses entailing acknowledgement, on the offenses of wrong conduct, and on the offenses of wrong speech.

ajjhācārapucchāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ends in -ti, functioning as an indeclinable citation label (iti-style) for the topic 'questions on misconduct' in Vinaya context, where ajjhācāra refers to monastic transgressions.

dvayaṃdvayasamāpattipucchā.meaning_2: question on the meeting of couples; enquiry regarding encounters wherever there are pairs
dvayaṃdvayasamāpattipucchā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'dvayaṃdvaya' (referring to couples or pairs) with 'samāpatti' (meeting or encounter) and 'pucchā' (question), forming a feminine noun denoting inquiries about situations involving pairs, as reflected in the contextual translation 'there are questions on that which is done wherever there are couples'.
dvayaṃdvayasamāpattipucchā.translation_1: there are questions on that which is done wherever there are couples.

liṅgapucchā.meaning_2: question concerning attributes; question about features
liṅgapucchā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given context, liṅgapucchā refers to questions focused on the characteristics or attributes of something, as part of a classification of inquiry types including those on postures (iriyāpatha), attributes (ākāra), and modes (vippakāra).
liṅgapucchā.translation_1: there are questions on characteristics, postures, attributes, and modes.

iriyāpathapucchā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, iriyāpathapucchā refers to questions concerning the four postures (walking, standing, sitting, lying down), translated as 'questions on postures'.
iriyāpathapucchā.translation_1: there are questions on characteristics, postures, attributes, and modes.

ākārapucchā.meaning_2: question on attributes; question on modes
ākārapucchā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, ākārapucchā refers to questions focusing on attributes or modes of things, as part of a classification of interrogative types in Pāḷi grammatical or analytical tradition.
ākārapucchā.translation_1: there are questions on characteristics, postures, attributes, and modes.

vippakārapucchā.grammar: fem, comp from vippakāra and pucchā
vippakārapucchā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, vippakārapucchā refers to questions concerning modes or manners, likely drawing on the sense of vippakāra as change, alteration, or transformation rather than disrespectful behavior.
vippakārapucchā.translation_1: there are questions on characteristics, postures, attributes, and modes.

liṅgapucchāti.meaning_2: questions on characteristics: tall, short, dark-skinned, or light-skinned
liṅgapucchāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term is a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'question about characteristics' and is used in Vinaya contexts to refer to inquiries about physical attributes such as height and complexion, as exemplified in the sentence.
liṅgapucchāti.example_1: liṅgapucchāti—dīghaṃ vā rassaṃ vā kaṇhaṃ vā odātaṃ vā.
liṅgapucchāti.translation_1: ‘Questions on characteristics’: tall, short, dark-skinned, or light-skinned.

iriyāpathapucchāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term iriyāpathapucchāti functions as an indeclinable explanatory phrase in the text, glossing 'questions on postures' by listing the four canonical postures: walking, standing, sitting, or lying down. The ending -ti is a common quotative particle in Pāḷi, marking the phrase as a definition or explanation.
iriyāpathapucchāti.example_1: iriyāpathapucchāti gacchantaṃ vā ṭhitaṃ vā nisinnaṃ vā nipannaṃ vā.
iriyāpathapucchāti.translation_1: ‘Questions on postures’: walking, standing, sitting, or lying down.

ākārapucchāti.meaning_2: questions on attributes; questions regarding characteristics or forms
ākārapucchāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an indeclinable adverbial phrase formed from 'ākāra' (attribute, characteristic) + 'pucchā' (question) + 'iti' (thus), explaining a technical term in the Vinaya context for inquiries into the attributes of householders, lay followers of other religions, or monastics. The sentence illustrates its usage as a gloss for types of questions.
ākārapucchāti.example_1: ākārapucchāti gihiliṅge vā titthiyaliṅge vā pabbajitaliṅge vā.
ākārapucchāti.translation_1: ‘Questions on attributes’: the characteristics of a householder, of a monastic of another religion, or of one gone forth.

titthiyaliṅge.meaning_2: characteristic of a person of another sect; attribute of a follower of another religion
titthiyaliṅge.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, titthiyaliṅge refers to the distinctive attributes or features associated with individuals from other religious sects, as opposed to householders or Buddhist monastics, in the framework of attribute-based questioning.
titthiyaliṅge.example_1: ākārapucchāti gihiliṅge vā titthiyaliṅge vā pabbajitaliṅge vā.
titthiyaliṅge.translation_1: ‘Questions on attributes’: the characteristics of a householder, of a monastic of another religion, or of one gone forth.

pabbajitaliṅge.meaning_2: characteristic of a renunciant; attribute of one gone forth
pabbajitaliṅge.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, pabbajitaliṅge refers to the defining attributes or characteristics of a pabbajita (renunciant or monk), paralleling gihiliṅge (householder's characteristics) and titthiyaliṅge (characteristics of a follower of another religion). The locative case indicates the domain of questioning on attributes.
pabbajitaliṅge.example_1: ākārapucchāti gihiliṅge vā titthiyaliṅge vā pabbajitaliṅge vā.
pabbajitaliṅge.translation_1: ‘Questions on attributes’: the characteristics of a householder, of a monastic of another religion, or of one gone forth.

vippakārapucchāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term is a quotative construction (iti) glossing 'vippakārapuccha' as referring to questions about behavioral modes or postures, specifically the four: walking, standing, sitting, or lying down, in the context of Vinaya procedural inquiries.
vippakārapucchāti.example_1: vippakārapucchāti gacchantaṃ vā ṭhitaṃ vā nisinnaṃ vā nipannaṃ vā.
vippakārapucchāti.translation_1: ‘Questions on modes’: walking, standing, sitting, or lying down.

kālapucchā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, kālapucchā refers to questions concerning time, as part of a list including questions on occasion (samayapucchā), day (divasapucchā), and season (utupucchā).
kālapucchā.translation_1: there are questions on time, on occasion, on day, and on season.

samayapucchā.meaning_2: question on occasion; question about time or suitable moment
samayapucchā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the contextual sentence, samayapucchā refers to questions concerning the occasion or appropriate time, paralleling kālapucchā for time in general.
samayapucchā.translation_1: there are questions on time, on occasion, on day, and on season.

divasapucchā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, divasapucchā refers to questions concerning the day, as part of a classification of inquiries on time, occasion, day, and season.
divasapucchā.translation_1: there are questions on time, on occasion, on day, and on season.

utupucchā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, utupucchā refers to questions concerning the season or time of year, as one of the types of inquiries listed alongside time, occasion, and day.
utupucchā.translation_1: there are questions on time, on occasion, on day, and on season.

kālapucchāti.meaning_2: questions on time; in the morning, at midday, or in the evening
kālapucchāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an indeclinable adverbial expression formed as a tatpuruṣa compound 'kālapuccha' (time-question) with the feminine suffix *-ā* indicating the topic, followed by 'iti' to quotatively define the term. In context, it glosses inquiries or questions pertaining to different times of the day, as specified in the explanatory sentence.
kālapucchāti.example_1: kālapucchāti pubbaṇhakāle vā majjhanhikakāle vā sāyanhakāle vā.
kālapucchāti.translation_1: ‘Questions on time’: in the morning, at midday, or in the evening.

pubbaṇhakāle.meaning_2: in the early morning; in the morning time
pubbaṇhakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence, 'pubbaṇhakāle' is the locative singular form of the compound 'pubbaṇhakāla', used adverbially to denote 'in the morning' as one of the times for questions, parallel to majjhanhikakāle and sāyanhakāle.
pubbaṇhakāle.example_1: kālapucchāti pubbaṇhakāle vā majjhanhikakāle vā sāyanhakāle vā.
pubbaṇhakāle.translation_1: ‘Questions on time’: in the morning, at midday, or in the evening.

majjhanhikakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is locative singular of the compound majjhanhikakāla, used in the context to denote the midday period as one of the three daily times for questioning, alongside morning and evening.
majjhanhikakāle.example_1: kālapucchāti pubbaṇhakāle vā majjhanhikakāle vā sāyanhakāle vā.
majjhanhikakāle.translation_1: ‘Questions on time’: in the morning, at midday, or in the evening.

samayapucchāti.meaning_2: asks about the occasion; questions regarding the time
samayapucchāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term 'samayapucchāti' is a present indicative 3rd singular form glossing 'questions on occasion' in the context of timing—morning, midday, or evening—likely referring to inquiries about appropriate times for religious or doctrinal practices.
samayapucchāti.example_1: samayapucchāti pubbaṇhasamaye vā majjhanhikasamaye vā sāyanhasamaye vā.
samayapucchāti.translation_1: ‘Questions on occasion’: in the morning, at midday, or in the evening.

divasapucchāti.meaning_2: questions on day; asking during the day
divasapucchāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form divasapucchāti is a sandhi compound serving as an indeclinable gloss, explaining the term as 'questions on day'. It combines divasa (day, in stem form divas-) with pucchā (question) and the imperative ending -ti from pucchati (to ask). In context, it specifies times for questioning: before or after meal, at night or by day, during waning or waxing moon, indicating permissible or notable periods for monastic inquiries.
divasapucchāti.example_1: divasapucchāti purebhattaṃ vā pacchābhattaṃ vā rattiṃ vā divā vā kāḷe vā juṇhe vā.
divasapucchāti.translation_1: ‘Questions on day’: before the meal, after the meal, at night, by day, during the waning moon, or during the waxing moon.

utupucchāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form utupucchāti is a compound verb where 'utu' (season) specifies the topic of questioning. In the sentence, it introduces seasonal contexts: winter (hemant), summer (gimh), and rainy season (vass), as in queries about practices or conditions in these times.
utupucchāti.example_1: utupucchāti hemante vā gimhe vā vasse vā.
utupucchāti.translation_1: ‘Questions on season’: in winter, in summer, or during the rainy season.

ṭhānapucchā.meaning_2: question about place; question about location
ṭhānapucchā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given context, ṭhānapucchā refers to a type of question concerning place or location, as part of a list of spatial inquiries including bhūmipucchā (about elevation), okāsapucchā (about location), and padesapucchā (about region).
ṭhānapucchā.translation_1: there are questions about place, about elevation, about location, and about region.

bhūmipucchā.meaning_2: question about elevation; question about land or region
bhūmipucchā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, bhūmipucchā is listed alongside other types of questions (ṭhānapucchā, okāsapucchā, padesapucchā) and translated as 'questions about elevation', suggesting a specific usage of bhūmi in the sense of height or level, though bhūmi more commonly means earth or land; this may refer to inquiries about geographical or spatial elevation in a technical or doctrinal context.
bhūmipucchā.translation_1: there are questions about place, about elevation, about location, and about region.

okāsapucchā.meaning_2: question about location; question about place
okāsapucchā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'okāsapucchā' is listed alongside other types of questions (ṭhānapucchā, bhūmipucchā, padesapucchā) and translated as 'questions about location', indicating its use in classificatory discussions of inquiry types, likely in grammatical or philosophical contexts where location refers to spatial or situational placement.
okāsapucchā.translation_1: there are questions about place, about elevation, about location, and about region.

padesapucchā.meaning_2: question about place; question about location; question about region; question about area
padesapucchā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given context, padesapucchā refers to a type of question concerning a specific region or delimited area, as part of a list of spatial inquiries in Pāḷi texts, likely related to Vinaya or doctrinal classifications.
padesapucchā.translation_1: there are questions about place, about elevation, about location, and about region.

ṭhānapucchāti.meaning_2: questions about place; questions about location
ṭhānapucchāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial phrase formed as a tatpuruṣa compound 'ṭhānapuccha' (place-question) followed by the quotative particle 'iti', glossing the topic of inquiries concerning physical location, as exemplified in the sentence by references to ground, earth, planet, or world.
ṭhānapucchāti.example_1: ṭhānapucchāti bhūmiyā vā pathaviyā vā dharaṇiyā vā jagatiyā vā.
ṭhānapucchāti.translation_1: ‘Questions about place’: in the ground, on the earth, on the planet, or in the world.

bhūmipucchāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial phrase formed as a tatpuruṣa compound 'bhūmi-puccha' (elevation-question) with the feminine suffix -ā and quotative particle iti, explaining a term likely from a list of question types in the text. The context lists various elevated surfaces (ground, earth, mountain, rock, stilt house) to illustrate the sense of 'elevation' in bhūmi.
bhūmipucchāti.example_1: bhūmipucchāti bhūmiyā vā pathaviyā vā pabbate vā pāsāṇe vā pāsāde vā.
bhūmipucchāti.translation_1: ‘Questions about elevation’: in the ground, on the the earth, on a mountain, on a rock, or in a stilt house.

okāsapucchāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form okāsapucchāti is a tatpurusha compound serving as an adverbial indeclinable, glossing the technical term for locative case inquiries, exemplified by directions: east (puratthime), west (pacchime), north (uttare), south (dakkhiṇe). It combines okāsa (space/location) with puccha (question), suffixed with iti to denote the explanatory phrase.
okāsapucchāti.example_1: okāsapucchāti puratthime vā okāse pacchime vā okāse uttare vā okāse dakkhiṇe vā okāse.
okāsapucchāti.translation_1: ‘Questions about location’: to the east, to the west, to the north, or to the south.

padesapucchāti.meaning_2: asks about a place; enquires about a location; questions about a region
padesapucchāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form padesapucchāti is a denominative present verb derived from the compound padesapuccha, meaning 'question about a region,' formed by combining padesa (region, place) with puccha (question). In the given context, it refers to questioning about specific directional regions: east, west, north, or south.
padesapucchāti.example_1: padesapucchāti puratthime vā padese pacchime vā padese uttare vā padese dakkhiṇe vā padeseti.
padesapucchāti.translation_1: ‘Questions about region’: to the east, to the west, to the north, or to the south.”

kammādhikaraṇañceva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound or phrase combining 'kamma' (legal procedure) and 'adhikaraṇa' (legal issue), connected by 'ca' (and) and emphasized by 'eva' (indeed). In the Vinaya context, it refers to both the formal actions and the matters under dispute in monastic disciplinary procedures.

pakkhomhi.meaning_2: I have; I am supported; I am backed; I am on the side of
pakkhomhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'pekkhā pasāde pakkhomhi', the form pakkhomhi is a contraction of pakkhe atthi (or pakkho amhi), meaning 'I am on the side of' or 'I have supporters' in the sense of being aligned with or backed by those who look on with inspiration (pasāda). The English translation 'I have supporters' captures the sense of having backing or allies.
pakkhomhi.translation_1: Looking on, inspiration, I have supporters,

sutatheratarena.meaning_2: by the one who is learned and more senior
sutatheratarena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the compound adjective sutatheratara, used to denote the agent of an action, as in 'by the learned and more senior one', aligning with the sentence's implication of agency or means.

mahāsaṅgāmañāpanāti.meaning_2: the explanation in the great section on conflict
mahāsaṅgāmañāpanāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative tatpuruṣa compound ending in -ti, functioning as an adverbial phrase specifying the source or context of the explanation, as in 'in the great conflict-explanation thus'.
mahāsaṅgāmañāpanāti.translation_1: The explanation in the great section on conflict.”

kathinabhedo.meaning_2: dissolution of the kathina privileges; end of the robe-making ceremony
kathinabhedo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'kathinabhedo' refers to the formal conclusion of the kathina ceremony period, after which the special allowances for robe-making and shared ownership cease, as indicated by the sentence 'The robe-making ceremony is finished.'

kathinaatthatādi.meaning_2: kathina ceremony, etc.; robe-making ceremony and the like
kathinaatthatādi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound 'kathina-attha-ādi' is a dvanda or descriptive compound used in Vinaya contexts to refer to participation in the kathina ceremony and related activities or privileges. Here, 'attha' likely denotes the purpose, benefit, or matter of the kathina, with 'ādi' indicating 'etc.' or similar observances, aligning with the English translation of participation in the robe-making ceremony and so forth.
kathinaatthatādi.translation_1: 1. Participated in the robe-making ceremony, etc.

anatthārakassa.meaning_2: one who has not performed the robe-making ceremony; one who does not spread out the robe
anatthārakassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'anatthāraka' specifically refers to a monk who has not participated in the kaṭhina robe ceremony by spreading out or contributing to the robe material, as opposed to 'atthāraka' who does so. The genitive form 'anatthārakassa' indicates possession, aligning with 'those who have not performed' in the English translation.
anatthārakassa.translation_1: those who have not performed the robe-making ceremony and those who have not expressed their appreciation.

gaṇḍusakaraṇamattena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of a compound noun meaning 'that which is measured as a mouthful for gargling', referring to the liquid used in the act of gargling (gaṇḍusa).

anādiyadānaṃ.meaning_2: gift not to be taken as one’s own; inappropriate gift
anādiyadānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, anādiyadānaṃ refers to a gift that should not be appropriated or claimed as personal property, often in monastic regulations regarding offerings. The English translation 'a gift not to be taken as one’s own' directly reflects its usage in the provided sentences.
anādiyadānaṃ.translation_1: Borrowed: a gift not to be taken as one’s own is so called.
anādiyadānaṃ.translation_2: a gift not to be taken as one’s own.

sannidhiyo.meaning_2: storing; store; kind of storing; for the purpose of making; for the purpose of accumulation
sannidhiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'sannidhiyo' is the nominative plural form referring to two kinds of storing: karaṇasannidhi (for making) and nicayasannidhi (for accumulation), as explained in the Vinaya text on monastic rules.
sannidhiyo.translation_1: Stored: there are two kinds of storing:
sannidhiyo.example_2: dve sannidhiyo jānitabbā—karaṇasannidhi vā nicayasannidhi vā.
sannidhiyo.translation_2: there are two kinds of storing: for the purpose of making and for the purpose of accumulation.

karaṇasannidhi.meaning_2: storing for the purpose of making; storing for the purpose of production or preparation
karaṇasannidhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, karaṇasannidhi refers to a type of storing or hoarding intended for the purpose of making or producing something, contrasting with nicayasannidhi which is for mere accumulation. The first member karaṇa, derived from √kar 'to do/make', specifies the instrumental or purposive aspect of the storing.
karaṇasannidhi.translation_1: storing for the purpose of making and storing for the purpose of accumulation.
karaṇasannidhi.example_2: dve sannidhiyo jānitabbā—karaṇasannidhi vā nicayasannidhi vā.
karaṇasannidhi.translation_2: there are two kinds of storing: for the purpose of making and for the purpose of accumulation.

nicayasannidhi.meaning_2: storing for the purpose of accumulation
nicayasannidhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound nicayasannidhi refers to a type of storing specifically for the purpose of accumulation, contrasting with karaṇasannidhi which is for the purpose of making. It combines 'nicaya' (accumulation, collection) with 'sannidhi' (store, hoard).
nicayasannidhi.translation_1: storing for the purpose of making and storing for the purpose of accumulation.
nicayasannidhi.example_2: dve sannidhiyo jānitabbā—karaṇasannidhi vā nicayasannidhi vā.
nicayasannidhi.translation_2: there are two kinds of storing: for the purpose of making and for the purpose of accumulation.

kathinaanantarapaccayādi.meaning_2: the proximity condition for the robe-making ceremony, etc.
kathinaanantarapaccayādi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a technical term in the context of Pāḷi grammar or Buddhist doctrine, specifically referring to the 'proximity condition' (anantarapaccaya) associated with the kathina ceremony and similar concepts, with ādi indicating 'etc.' or 'beginning with'. The English translation confirms its use in describing conditions following the robe-making event.
kathinaanantarapaccayādi.translation_1: 2. The proximity condition for the robe-making ceremony, etc.

anantarapaccayena.meaning_2: proximity condition; condition by immediate proximity; immediately preceding supporting condition
anantarapaccayena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the contextual sentences from the Pāḷi Vinaya or Abhidhamma, 'anantarapaccayena' functions as an instrumental form denoting 'by being a proximity condition,' specifying one of the 24 modes of conditionality in dependent origination. It describes a causal relationship where the condition immediately precedes without interruption, as in prior duties supporting effort directly.
anantarapaccayena.example_1: payogassa katame dhammā anantarapaccayena paccayo, samanantarapaccayena paccayo, nissayapaccayena paccayo, upanissayapaccayena paccayo, purejātapaccayena paccayo, pacchājātapaccayena paccayo, sahajātapaccayena paccayo?
anantarapaccayena.translation_1: Which things are a condition for effort by being a proximity condition, an immediacy condition, a support condition, a decisive support condition, a pre-arising condition, a post-arising condition, and a co-arising condition?
anantarapaccayena.translation_2: Which things are a condition for the prior duties by being a proximity condition …

samanantarapaccayena.meaning_2: immediacy condition; condition of immediate proximity
samanantarapaccayena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'samanantarapaccayena' functions as an instrumental form denoting the type of conditional relationship, specifically the 'immediacy condition' in the chain of dependent origination or vinaya processes, linking prior elements directly to subsequent ones without interruption.
samanantarapaccayena.example_1: payogassa katame dhammā anantarapaccayena paccayo, samanantarapaccayena paccayo, nissayapaccayena paccayo, upanissayapaccayena paccayo, purejātapaccayena paccayo, pacchājātapaccayena paccayo, sahajātapaccayena paccayo?
samanantarapaccayena.translation_1: Which things are a condition for effort by being a proximity condition, an immediacy condition, a support condition, a decisive support condition, a pre-arising condition, a post-arising condition, and a co-arising condition?
samanantarapaccayena.example_2: vatthussa katame dhammā anantarapaccayena paccayo, samanantarapaccayena paccayo, nissayapaccayena paccayo, upanissayapaccayena paccayo, purejātapaccayena paccayo, pacchājātapaccayena paccayo, sahajātapaccayena paccayo?
samanantarapaccayena.translation_2: Which things are a condition for the object by being a proximity condition, an immediacy condition, a support condition, a decisive support condition, a pre-arising condition, a post-arising condition, and a co-arising condition?

nissayapaccayena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'nissayapaccayena' functions as an instrumental form indicating 'by being a support condition' in relation to various dhammā serving as conditions for effort, object, prior duties, relinquishment, determining, robe-making ceremony, and expectation/non-expectation. It denotes a foundational or dependency-based causal relationship in Pāḷi conditional analysis.
nissayapaccayena.example_1: payogassa katame dhammā anantarapaccayena paccayo, samanantarapaccayena paccayo, nissayapaccayena paccayo, upanissayapaccayena paccayo, purejātapaccayena paccayo, pacchājātapaccayena paccayo, sahajātapaccayena paccayo?
nissayapaccayena.translation_1: Which things are a condition for effort by being a proximity condition, an immediacy condition, a support condition, a decisive support condition, a pre-arising condition, a post-arising condition, and a co-arising condition?
nissayapaccayena.example_2: vatthussa katame dhammā anantarapaccayena paccayo, samanantarapaccayena paccayo, nissayapaccayena paccayo, upanissayapaccayena paccayo, purejātapaccayena paccayo, pacchājātapaccayena paccayo, sahajātapaccayena paccayo?
nissayapaccayena.translation_2: Which things are a condition for the object by being a proximity condition, an immediacy condition, a support condition, a decisive support condition, a pre-arising condition, a post-arising condition, and a co-arising condition?

upanissayapaccayena.meaning_2: decisive support condition; strong supporting condition
upanissayapaccayena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentences, 'upanissayapaccayena paccayo' indicates the instrumental case specifying the type of conditional relation, emphasizing a strong or decisive form of support that influences the conditioned phenomenon, as seen in contexts like effort, object, and ritual processes.
upanissayapaccayena.example_1: payogassa katame dhammā anantarapaccayena paccayo, samanantarapaccayena paccayo, nissayapaccayena paccayo, upanissayapaccayena paccayo, purejātapaccayena paccayo, pacchājātapaccayena paccayo, sahajātapaccayena paccayo?
upanissayapaccayena.translation_1: Which things are a condition for effort by being a proximity condition, an immediacy condition, a support condition, a decisive support condition, a pre-arising condition, a post-arising condition, and a co-arising condition?
upanissayapaccayena.example_2: vatthussa katame dhammā anantarapaccayena paccayo, samanantarapaccayena paccayo, nissayapaccayena paccayo, upanissayapaccayena paccayo, purejātapaccayena paccayo, pacchājātapaccayena paccayo, sahajātapaccayena paccayo?
upanissayapaccayena.translation_2: Which things are a condition for the object by being a proximity condition, an immediacy condition, a support condition, a decisive support condition, a pre-arising condition, a post-arising condition, and a co-arising condition?

purejātapaccayena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This instrumental form denotes a supporting condition that arises prior to the conditioned phenomenon, as seen in the contextual examples where prior stages (e.g., effort for prior duties, prior duties for relinquishment) condition subsequent stages by having already arisen.
purejātapaccayena.example_1: payogassa katame dhammā anantarapaccayena paccayo, samanantarapaccayena paccayo, nissayapaccayena paccayo, upanissayapaccayena paccayo, purejātapaccayena paccayo, pacchājātapaccayena paccayo, sahajātapaccayena paccayo?
purejātapaccayena.translation_1: Which things are a condition for effort by being a proximity condition, an immediacy condition, a support condition, a decisive support condition, a pre-arising condition, a post-arising condition, and a co-arising condition?
purejātapaccayena.example_2: vatthussa katame dhammā anantarapaccayena paccayo, samanantarapaccayena paccayo, nissayapaccayena paccayo, upanissayapaccayena paccayo, purejātapaccayena paccayo, pacchājātapaccayena paccayo, sahajātapaccayena paccayo?
purejātapaccayena.translation_2: Which things are a condition for the object by being a proximity condition, an immediacy condition, a support condition, a decisive support condition, a pre-arising condition, a post-arising condition, and a co-arising condition?

pacchājātapaccayena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'pacchājātapaccayena' refers to a specific type of conditional relation in Buddhist philosophy where one dhamma serves as a supporting condition for another after it has arisen. For example, prior duties support effort as a post-arising condition, indicating a sequence where the condition follows the arising of the supported phenomenon.
pacchājātapaccayena.example_1: payogassa katame dhammā anantarapaccayena paccayo, samanantarapaccayena paccayo, nissayapaccayena paccayo, upanissayapaccayena paccayo, purejātapaccayena paccayo, pacchājātapaccayena paccayo, sahajātapaccayena paccayo?
pacchājātapaccayena.translation_1: Which things are a condition for effort by being a proximity condition, an immediacy condition, a support condition, a decisive support condition, a pre-arising condition, a post-arising condition, and a co-arising condition?
pacchājātapaccayena.example_2: vatthussa katame dhammā anantarapaccayena paccayo, samanantarapaccayena paccayo, nissayapaccayena paccayo, upanissayapaccayena paccayo, purejātapaccayena paccayo, pacchājātapaccayena paccayo, sahajātapaccayena paccayo?
pacchājātapaccayena.translation_2: Which things are a condition for the object by being a proximity condition, an immediacy condition, a support condition, a decisive support condition, a pre-arising condition, a post-arising condition, and a co-arising condition?

sahajātapaccayena.meaning_2: condition by co-arising; simultaneous arising condition
sahajātapaccayena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'sahajātapaccayena paccayo' refers to a specific type of conditional relation in Pāḷi Buddhist philosophy where phenomena arise simultaneously and mutually support each other, as listed among the 24 modes of conditionality (paccayākāra). It applies to effort (payoga), object (vatthu), and the fifteen dhammā in sentences 2-7.
sahajātapaccayena.example_1: payogassa katame dhammā anantarapaccayena paccayo, samanantarapaccayena paccayo, nissayapaccayena paccayo, upanissayapaccayena paccayo, purejātapaccayena paccayo, pacchājātapaccayena paccayo, sahajātapaccayena paccayo?
sahajātapaccayena.translation_1: Which things are a condition for effort by being a proximity condition, an immediacy condition, a support condition, a decisive support condition, a pre-arising condition, a post-arising condition, and a co-arising condition?
sahajātapaccayena.example_2: vatthussa katame dhammā anantarapaccayena paccayo, samanantarapaccayena paccayo, nissayapaccayena paccayo, upanissayapaccayena paccayo, purejātapaccayena paccayo, pacchājātapaccayena paccayo, sahajātapaccayena paccayo?
sahajātapaccayena.translation_2: Which things are a condition for the object by being a proximity condition, an immediacy condition, a support condition, a decisive support condition, a pre-arising condition, a post-arising condition, and a co-arising condition?

pubbakaraṇanidānādivibhāgo.meaning_2: division of preliminaries, origins, etc.; classification beginning with introductory works and foundational narratives
pubbakaraṇanidānādivibhāgo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a complex dvanda-samāsa compound indicating a comprehensive classification or section in a text, likely from Vinaya or grammatical literature, encompassing preliminary preparations (pubbakaraṇa), origins or introductions (nidāna), and so forth (ādi), culminating in divisions or analyses (vibhāga). The ending -o suggests nominative singular in context.

payoganidānaṃ.grammar: ind, adv, in comps, acc sg of payoganidāna
payoganidānaṃ.meaning_2: having effort as source; with effort as origin
payoganidānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the accusative singular form of the compound payoganidāna used adverbially to indicate the basis or source, as seen in the parallel constructions like payogasamudayaṃ. In the sentence, it specifies that prior duties (pubbakaraṇaṃ) have effort (payoga) as their foundational source (nidāna).
payoganidānaṃ.example_1: pubbakaraṇaṃ payoganidānaṃ, payogasamudayaṃ, payogajātikaṃ, payogapabhavaṃ, payogasambhāraṃ, payogasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
payoganidānaṃ.translation_1: The prior duties have effort as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

payogasamudayaṃ.meaning_2: collection of effort; aggregate of action; origination of undertaking
payogasamudayaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, payogasamudayaṃ parallels other terms like payoganidānaṃ, indicating 'collection' or 'arising' of effort as the source or origination of prior duties, emphasizing the accumulative aspect of action leading to duties.
payogasamudayaṃ.example_1: pubbakaraṇaṃ payoganidānaṃ, payogasamudayaṃ, payogajātikaṃ, payogapabhavaṃ, payogasambhāraṃ, payogasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
payogasamudayaṃ.translation_1: The prior duties have effort as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

payogajātikaṃ.grammar: adj, in comps, from payoga and jāti
payogajātikaṃ.meaning_2: born from effort; produced by effort; arising from undertaking
payogajātikaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, payogajātikaṃ describes the prior duties as being of the nature born from or produced by payoga (effort or undertaking), paralleling terms like payoganidānaṃ (having effort as source) to emphasize origin through effort.
payogajātikaṃ.example_1: pubbakaraṇaṃ payoganidānaṃ, payogasamudayaṃ, payogajātikaṃ, payogapabhavaṃ, payogasambhāraṃ, payogasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
payogajātikaṃ.translation_1: The prior duties have effort as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

payogapabhavaṃ.meaning_2: arising from effort; coming into being through effort; origination from effort
payogapabhavaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, payogapabhavaṃ denotes the arising or coming into being of prior duties specifically through effort (payoga), paralleling terms like payoganidānaṃ (source) and payogasamuṭṭhānaṃ (origination) to emphasize effort as the causal factor.
payogapabhavaṃ.example_1: pubbakaraṇaṃ payoganidānaṃ, payogasamudayaṃ, payogajātikaṃ, payogapabhavaṃ, payogasambhāraṃ, payogasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
payogapabhavaṃ.translation_1: The prior duties have effort as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

payogasambhāraṃ.meaning_2: production; collection of means for action; accumulation of requisites for undertaking
payogasambhāraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, payogasambhāraṃ parallels terms like payoganidānaṃ, indicating 'production' or 'collection' as the source of effort in prior duties, emphasizing the assembled components or requisites that give rise to action.
payogasambhāraṃ.example_1: pubbakaraṇaṃ payoganidānaṃ, payogasamudayaṃ, payogajātikaṃ, payogapabhavaṃ, payogasambhāraṃ, payogasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
payogasambhāraṃ.translation_1: The prior duties have effort as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

payogasamuṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: origination of effort; arising of undertaking
payogasamuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, payogasamuṭṭhāna refers to the origination or arising specifically from effort (payoga), paralleling other terms like payoganidāna (source) and payogasamudaya (origin), indicating the causal basis of prior duties.
payogasamuṭṭhānaṃ.example_1: pubbakaraṇaṃ payoganidānaṃ, payogasamudayaṃ, payogajātikaṃ, payogapabhavaṃ, payogasambhāraṃ, payogasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
payogasamuṭṭhānaṃ.translation_1: The prior duties have effort as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

pubbakaraṇanidāno.meaning_2: originating from preliminary duties; caused by preliminary work; founded on prior chores
pubbakaraṇanidāno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'pubbakaraṇanidāno' is a bahuvrīhi compound used predicatively with 'paccuddhāro' (relinquishment), indicating that relinquishment originates from or is based on preliminary duties or prior preparations.
pubbakaraṇanidāno.example_1: paccuddhāro pubbakaraṇanidāno, pubbakaraṇasamudayo, pubbakaraṇajātiko, pubbakaraṇapabhavo, pubbakaraṇasambhāro, pubbakaraṇasamuṭṭhāno.
pubbakaraṇanidāno.translation_1: Relinquishment has the prior duties as its source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

pubbakaraṇasamudayo.meaning_2: arising from preliminary duties; origination from prior works
pubbakaraṇasamudayo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, this compound is one of several parallel terms describing relinquishment (paccuddhāra) as originating from prior duties (pubbakaraṇa), emphasizing the causal link in a list of synonyms for source or arising.
pubbakaraṇasamudayo.example_1: paccuddhāro pubbakaraṇanidāno, pubbakaraṇasamudayo, pubbakaraṇajātiko, pubbakaraṇapabhavo, pubbakaraṇasambhāro, pubbakaraṇasamuṭṭhāno.
pubbakaraṇasamudayo.translation_1: Relinquishment has the prior duties as its source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

pubbakaraṇajātiko.meaning_2: born from preliminary work; arising from prior duties
pubbakaraṇajātiko.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, pubbakaraṇajātiko describes relinquishment (paccuddhāra) as being born or produced from prior duties (pubbakaraṇa), paralleling other terms indicating origin and arising.
pubbakaraṇajātiko.example_1: paccuddhāro pubbakaraṇanidāno, pubbakaraṇasamudayo, pubbakaraṇajātiko, pubbakaraṇapabhavo, pubbakaraṇasambhāro, pubbakaraṇasamuṭṭhāno.
pubbakaraṇajātiko.translation_1: Relinquishment has the prior duties as its source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

pubbakaraṇapabhavo.meaning_2: arising; origination; production; coming into being (from prior duties)
pubbakaraṇapabhavo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence, 'pubbakaraṇapabhavo' describes relinquishment (paccuddhāro) as having the prior duties (pubbakaraṇa) as its arising or origination, part of a series of synonymous terms indicating source and origin.
pubbakaraṇapabhavo.example_1: paccuddhāro pubbakaraṇanidāno, pubbakaraṇasamudayo, pubbakaraṇajātiko, pubbakaraṇapabhavo, pubbakaraṇasambhāro, pubbakaraṇasamuṭṭhāno.
pubbakaraṇapabhavo.translation_1: Relinquishment has the prior duties as its source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

pubbakaraṇasambhāro.meaning_2: preliminary preparation; production from prior duties
pubbakaraṇasambhāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'pubbakaraṇasambhāro' functions as a bahuvrīhi compound indicating that relinquishment (paccuddhāra) has the prior duties (pubbakaraṇa) as its production or preparatory condition, paralleling terms like source, origin, and arising.
pubbakaraṇasambhāro.example_1: paccuddhāro pubbakaraṇanidāno, pubbakaraṇasamudayo, pubbakaraṇajātiko, pubbakaraṇapabhavo, pubbakaraṇasambhāro, pubbakaraṇasamuṭṭhāno.
pubbakaraṇasambhāro.translation_1: Relinquishment has the prior duties as its source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

pubbakaraṇasamuṭṭhāno.meaning_2: arising from preliminary work; originating from prior duties
pubbakaraṇasamuṭṭhāno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, this compound adjective describes relinquishment (paccuddhāra) as having its origination or arising from prior duties (pubbakaraṇa), paralleling other terms like source (nidāna) and origin (samudaya).
pubbakaraṇasamuṭṭhāno.example_1: paccuddhāro pubbakaraṇanidāno, pubbakaraṇasamudayo, pubbakaraṇajātiko, pubbakaraṇapabhavo, pubbakaraṇasambhāro, pubbakaraṇasamuṭṭhāno.
pubbakaraṇasamuṭṭhāno.translation_1: Relinquishment has the prior duties as its source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

paccuddhāranidānaṃ.meaning_2: relinquishment as source; origin of withdrawal
paccuddhāranidānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given sentence, 'paccuddhāranidānaṃ' functions as a bahuvrīhi compound modifying 'adhiṭṭhānaṃ' (determining), indicating that determining has 'paccuddhāra' (relinquishment or withdrawal) as its 'nidāna' (source). The accusative singular form aligns with the adverbial usage of nidānaṃ meaning 'due to' or 'as'.
paccuddhāranidānaṃ.example_1: adhiṭṭhānaṃ paccuddhāranidānaṃ, paccuddhārasamudayaṃ, paccuddhārajātikaṃ, paccuddhārapabhavaṃ, paccuddhārasambhāraṃ, paccuddhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
paccuddhāranidānaṃ.translation_1: Determining has relinquishment as its source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

paccuddhārasamudayaṃ.meaning_2: origination of withdrawal; arising of relinquishment
paccuddhārasamudayaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence, paccuddhārasamudayaṃ is used in apposition to adhiṭṭhānaṃ, indicating that the 'origination' (samudaya) of 'relinquishment' (paccuddhāra) is one of the listed aspects (source, origin, birth, arising, production, origination) of determining (adhiṭṭhāna). The accusative case aligns with the overall structure of the list.
paccuddhārasamudayaṃ.example_1: adhiṭṭhānaṃ paccuddhāranidānaṃ, paccuddhārasamudayaṃ, paccuddhārajātikaṃ, paccuddhārapabhavaṃ, paccuddhārasambhāraṃ, paccuddhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
paccuddhārasamudayaṃ.translation_1: Determining has relinquishment as its source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

paccuddhārajātikaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, paccuddhārajātikaṃ denotes 'birth' or 'arising' as one of the aspects (source, origin, birth, etc.) attributed to the concept of 'determining' (adhiṭṭhānaṃ), indicating that relinquishment (paccuddhāra) is the underlying cause of its emergence.
paccuddhārajātikaṃ.example_1: adhiṭṭhānaṃ paccuddhāranidānaṃ, paccuddhārasamudayaṃ, paccuddhārajātikaṃ, paccuddhārapabhavaṃ, paccuddhārasambhāraṃ, paccuddhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
paccuddhārajātikaṃ.translation_1: Determining has relinquishment as its source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

paccuddhārapabhavaṃ.meaning_2: origin of relinquishment; arising from withdrawal
paccuddhārapabhavaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as an adverbial accusative, indicating the source or origin in the context of adhiṭṭhāna (determining or resolve) having relinquishment (paccuddhāra) as its pabhava (origin).
paccuddhārapabhavaṃ.example_1: adhiṭṭhānaṃ paccuddhāranidānaṃ, paccuddhārasamudayaṃ, paccuddhārajātikaṃ, paccuddhārapabhavaṃ, paccuddhārasambhāraṃ, paccuddhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
paccuddhārapabhavaṃ.translation_1: Determining has relinquishment as its source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

paccuddhārasambhāraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'paccuddhārasambhāraṃ' is part of a series describing the sources or conditions for 'adhiṭṭhānaṃ' (determining), where 'sambhāraṃ' indicates the production or constituent aspect of relinquishment (paccuddhāra).
paccuddhārasambhāraṃ.example_1: adhiṭṭhānaṃ paccuddhāranidānaṃ, paccuddhārasamudayaṃ, paccuddhārajātikaṃ, paccuddhārapabhavaṃ, paccuddhārasambhāraṃ, paccuddhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
paccuddhārasambhāraṃ.translation_1: Determining has relinquishment as its source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

paccuddhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: origination of withdrawal; arising from relinquishment
paccuddhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, this compound noun denotes the 'origination' or 'arising' aspect of relinquishment (paccuddhāra), paralleling other terms like source and origin, indicating that determination (adhiṭṭhāna) originates from relinquishment.
paccuddhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ.example_1: adhiṭṭhānaṃ paccuddhāranidānaṃ, paccuddhārasamudayaṃ, paccuddhārajātikaṃ, paccuddhārapabhavaṃ, paccuddhārasambhāraṃ, paccuddhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
paccuddhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ.translation_1: Determining has relinquishment as its source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

adhiṭṭhānanidāno.meaning_2: having determination as source; originating from determination
adhiṭṭhānanidāno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In this Vinaya context, the compound describes the robe-making ceremony (kaṭhina) as fundamentally sourced in the determination or resolution of the Saṅgha to perform it, emphasizing its causal basis.
adhiṭṭhānanidāno.example_1: atthāro adhiṭṭhānanidāno, adhiṭṭhānasamudayo, adhiṭṭhānajātiko, adhiṭṭhānapabhavo, adhiṭṭhānasambhāro, adhiṭṭhānasamuṭṭhāno.
adhiṭṭhānanidāno.translation_1: Performing the robe-making ceremony has determining as its source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

adhiṭṭhānasamudayo.meaning_2: origin of determination; arising of basis
adhiṭṭhānasamudayo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the contextual sentence, this compound is used in a series of near-synonyms describing the robe-making ceremony as having determination (adhiṭṭhāna, specifically the sense of 'decisive resolution') as its source and origin. The term parallels other bahubbīhi-like constructions in the list, emphasizing causal origination.
adhiṭṭhānasamudayo.example_1: atthāro adhiṭṭhānanidāno, adhiṭṭhānasamudayo, adhiṭṭhānajātiko, adhiṭṭhānapabhavo, adhiṭṭhānasambhāro, adhiṭṭhānasamuṭṭhāno.
adhiṭṭhānasamudayo.translation_1: Performing the robe-making ceremony has determining as its source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

adhiṭṭhānajātiko.grammar: adj, in comps, from adhiṭṭhāna + jātika
adhiṭṭhānajātiko.meaning_2: born from determination; originating from decisive resolution
adhiṭṭhānajātiko.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the robe-making ceremony (kaṭhinuppādāna), this term describes the ceremony as something born or produced from determination (adhiṭṭhāna), emphasizing its causal origin in the monks' resolute decision.
adhiṭṭhānajātiko.example_1: atthāro adhiṭṭhānanidāno, adhiṭṭhānasamudayo, adhiṭṭhānajātiko, adhiṭṭhānapabhavo, adhiṭṭhānasambhāro, adhiṭṭhānasamuṭṭhāno.
adhiṭṭhānajātiko.translation_1: Performing the robe-making ceremony has determining as its source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

adhiṭṭhānapabhavo.grammar: adj, in comps, from adhiṭṭhāna + pabhava
adhiṭṭhānapabhavo.meaning_2: arising from a basis; originating from a foundation; produced by determination
adhiṭṭhānapabhavo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the robe-making ceremony, this compound adjective describes the ceremony as having 'determination' (adhiṭṭhāna, understood as resolve or basis) as its source or arising, paralleling terms like nidāna and samudaya to emphasize causal origination.
adhiṭṭhānapabhavo.example_1: atthāro adhiṭṭhānanidāno, adhiṭṭhānasamudayo, adhiṭṭhānajātiko, adhiṭṭhānapabhavo, adhiṭṭhānasambhāro, adhiṭṭhānasamuṭṭhāno.
adhiṭṭhānapabhavo.translation_1: Performing the robe-making ceremony has determining as its source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

adhiṭṭhānasambhāro.meaning_2: preparation; constituent; necessary requirement; production (of determination)
adhiṭṭhānasambhāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given context, adhiṭṭhānasambhāro refers to the 'production' or 'requisite preparation' aspect of determination (adhiṭṭhāna), specifically linked to the robe-making ceremony as its foundational element. The compound parallels other terms like nidāno and samuṭṭhāno, emphasizing origination.
adhiṭṭhānasambhāro.example_1: atthāro adhiṭṭhānanidāno, adhiṭṭhānasamudayo, adhiṭṭhānajātiko, adhiṭṭhānapabhavo, adhiṭṭhānasambhāro, adhiṭṭhānasamuṭṭhāno.
adhiṭṭhānasambhāro.translation_1: Performing the robe-making ceremony has determining as its source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

adhiṭṭhānasamuṭṭhāno.meaning_2: arising from determination; originating from determination; originating from decisive resolution
adhiṭṭhānasamuṭṭhāno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given Vinaya context, the compound describes the robe-making ceremony (kaṭhina) as having determination (adhiṭṭhāna, the monk's resolve to use the robe) as its source of origination, emphasizing the causal basis for the ceremony's validity and effects.
adhiṭṭhānasamuṭṭhāno.example_1: atthāro adhiṭṭhānanidāno, adhiṭṭhānasamudayo, adhiṭṭhānajātiko, adhiṭṭhānapabhavo, adhiṭṭhānasambhāro, adhiṭṭhānasamuṭṭhāno.
adhiṭṭhānasamuṭṭhāno.translation_1: Performing the robe-making ceremony has determining as its source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

atthāranidānā.meaning_2: having source in eighteen; originating from eighteen
atthāranidānā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'atthāranidānā' modifies 'mātikā ca palibodhā ca', indicating that the key terms and obstacles have their source (nidāna) in the eighteen (atthāra) aspects of the robe-making ceremony, as per the English translation. This is a bahuvrīhi compound where 'atthāra' refers to eighteen items, and 'nidāna' denotes source or origin.
atthāranidānā.example_1: mātikā ca palibodhā ca atthāranidānā, atthārasamudayā, atthārajātikā, atthārapabhavā, atthārasambhārā, atthārasamuṭṭhānā.
atthāranidānā.translation_1: The Key Terms and the obstacles have participating in the robe-making ceremony as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

atthārasamudayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'atthārasamudayā' is an instrumental plural form meaning 'eighteen sources/originations,' parallel to other terms like 'atthāranidānā' (eighteen sources) and 'atthārajātikā' (eighteen births), all referring to the eighteenfold causal origins of the key terms (mātikā) and obstacles (palibodhā) participating in the robe-making ceremony (kaṭhina). The number 'eighteen' is expressed as the compound 'atthārasa' (atthāra 'eighteen' + rasa 'ten').
atthārasamudayā.example_1: mātikā ca palibodhā ca atthāranidānā, atthārasamudayā, atthārajātikā, atthārapabhavā, atthārasambhārā, atthārasamuṭṭhānā.
atthārasamudayā.translation_1: The Key Terms and the obstacles have participating in the robe-making ceremony as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

atthārajātikā.meaning_2: having birth/origination in the matter/purpose (of the robe-making ceremony); produced from the matter/purpose
atthārajātikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'atthārajātikā' describes the mātikā and palibodhā as having their birth or arising specifically in the 'attha' (purpose or matter) of the robe-making ceremony (kaṭhinuppāṭikā), paralleling the other terms like atthāranidānā which indicate source/origin.
atthārajātikā.example_1: mātikā ca palibodhā ca atthāranidānā, atthārasamudayā, atthārajātikā, atthārapabhavā, atthārasambhārā, atthārasamuṭṭhānā.
atthārajātikā.translation_1: The Key Terms and the obstacles have participating in the robe-making ceremony as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

atthārapabhavā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'atthārapabhavā' is part of a list of terms describing the 'source' or 'origin' of the key terms (mātikā) and obstacles (palibodhā) in relation to the robe-making ceremony (kaṭhinacīvara). It parallels other compounds like atthāranidānā, emphasizing multiple aspects of origination, specifically eighteen in number.
atthārapabhavā.example_1: mātikā ca palibodhā ca atthāranidānā, atthārasamudayā, atthārajātikā, atthārapabhavā, atthārasambhārā, atthārasamuṭṭhānā.
atthārapabhavā.translation_1: The Key Terms and the obstacles have participating in the robe-making ceremony as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

atthārasambhārā.meaning_2: eighteen requisites; eighteen collections; eighteen components
atthārasambhārā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'atthārasambhārā' refers to the eighteen essential requisites or components involved in the robe-making ceremony (kaṭhina), paralleling the other terms like origins, births, and arisings that trace back to participation in the ceremony. The numeral 'atthāra' (eighteen) combines with 'sambhārā' (collections or requisites), indicating a specific set of eighteen items necessary for the ritual.
atthārasambhārā.example_1: mātikā ca palibodhā ca atthāranidānā, atthārasamudayā, atthārajātikā, atthārapabhavā, atthārasambhārā, atthārasamuṭṭhānā.
atthārasambhārā.translation_1: The Key Terms and the obstacles have participating in the robe-making ceremony as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

atthārasamuṭṭhānā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'atthārasamuṭṭhānā' is part of a series of terms describing the 'source' or 'origin' (nidāna) of the Key Terms (mātikā) and obstacles (palibodhā) as the robe-making ceremony (kaṭhinūposatha). It parallels terms like atthāranidānā and atthārasamudayā, emphasizing causal arising from this event. The form is instrumental plural, agreeing with the implied subject.
atthārasamuṭṭhānā.example_1: mātikā ca palibodhā ca atthāranidānā, atthārasamudayā, atthārajātikā, atthārapabhavā, atthārasambhārā, atthārasamuṭṭhānā.
atthārasamuṭṭhānā.translation_1: The Key Terms and the obstacles have participating in the robe-making ceremony as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

vatthunidānā.meaning_2: source or origin based on the ground or basis; foundational cause; lit. ground-tying down
vatthunidānā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'vatthunidānā' functions as an instrumental plural form of the compound, indicating that expectation and non-expectation arise from sources or origins grounded in certain bases or obstacles (vatthu), emphasizing causal foundations in Buddhist doctrinal analysis.
vatthunidānā.example_1: āsā ca anāsā ca vatthunidānā, vatthusamudayā, vatthujātikā, vatthupabhavā, vatthusambhārā, vatthusamuṭṭhānā.
vatthunidānā.translation_1: Expectation and non-expectation have the key phrases and the obstacles as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

vatthusamudayā.meaning_2: arising from the basis; origination from the ground; production from the object
vatthusamudayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'vatthusamudayā' functions as an instrumental form meaning 'arising from the basis' or 'origination from the ground,' paralleling other terms like 'vatthunidānā' to describe the source of expectation and non-expectation. Here, 'vatthu' refers to the foundational basis or object, and 'samudaya' denotes the process of arising or origination.
vatthusamudayā.example_1: āsā ca anāsā ca vatthunidānā, vatthusamudayā, vatthujātikā, vatthupabhavā, vatthusambhārā, vatthusamuṭṭhānā.
vatthusamudayā.translation_1: Expectation and non-expectation have the key phrases and the obstacles as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

vatthujātikā.grammar: adj, in comps, from vatthu + jātika
vatthujātikā.meaning_2: born from the basis; originating from the object; of the nature of the grounds
vatthujātikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the contextual sentence, vatthujātikā parallels terms like vatthusamudayā and vatthupabhavā, indicating that expectation and non-expectation arise 'born from' or 'of the nature of' the vatthu (basis, object, or grounds), emphasizing origination from foundational elements.
vatthujātikā.example_1: āsā ca anāsā ca vatthunidānā, vatthusamudayā, vatthujātikā, vatthupabhavā, vatthusambhārā, vatthusamuṭṭhānā.
vatthujātikā.translation_1: Expectation and non-expectation have the key phrases and the obstacles as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

vatthupabhavā.meaning_2: arising from the basis; origination from the ground; coming into being from the source
vatthupabhavā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'vatthupabhavā' is part of a series of terms describing the origins of expectation and non-expectation, paralleling 'vatthusamudayā' etc., where 'vatthu' denotes the foundational source or basis, and 'pabhava' indicates arising or origination from it. The English translation captures this as 'arising' in the list of synonymous concepts.
vatthupabhavā.example_1: āsā ca anāsā ca vatthunidānā, vatthusamudayā, vatthujātikā, vatthupabhavā, vatthusambhārā, vatthusamuṭṭhānā.
vatthupabhavā.translation_1: Expectation and non-expectation have the key phrases and the obstacles as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

vatthusambhārā.meaning_2: production; origination; component; constituent; lit. collection of things on the ground
vatthusambhārā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'vatthusambhārā' refers to the 'production' or 'constituents' arising from the foundational grounds or bases (vatthu) of expectation and non-expectation, paralleling terms like origin, birth, and arising. The instrumental plural form indicates these are sources or means for the phenomena described.
vatthusambhārā.example_1: āsā ca anāsā ca vatthunidānā, vatthusamudayā, vatthujātikā, vatthupabhavā, vatthusambhārā, vatthusamuṭṭhānā.
vatthusambhārā.translation_1: Expectation and non-expectation have the key phrases and the obstacles as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

vatthusamuṭṭhānā.meaning_2: arising from the basis; origination from the ground; production from the cause
vatthusamuṭṭhānā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'vatthusamuṭṭhānā' functions as an instrumental form within a series of synonymous terms, indicating that expectation and non-expectation arise from or are produced by their foundational bases or causes (vatthunidānā). This compound parallels other terms like vatthusamudayā, emphasizing origination from a ground or basis.
vatthusamuṭṭhānā.example_1: āsā ca anāsā ca vatthunidānā, vatthusamudayā, vatthujātikā, vatthupabhavā, vatthusambhārā, vatthusamuṭṭhānā.
vatthusamuṭṭhānā.translation_1: Expectation and non-expectation have the key phrases and the obstacles as their source, origin, birth, arising, production, and origination.

kappakaraṇena.meaning_2: marking; dressing; preparing; lit. making suitable
kappakaraṇena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, kappakaraṇena refers to the act of marking or preparing garments, likely involving tailoring or finishing touches by a kappaka (barber or hairdresser who also handles such preparations), as part of a list of processes like sewing and dyeing.
kappakaraṇena.example_1: dhovanena, vicāraṇena, chedanena, bandhanena, sibbanena, rajanena, kappakaraṇena—
kappakaraṇena.translation_1: washing, planning, cutting, tacking, sewing, dyeing, and marking.

kathinatthārā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'kathinatthārā' refers to the ceremony or rite (kathina) involving the spreading out or offering of the robe material. It is effective or invalid depending on the individuals involved or the conditions of the ceremony, as discussed in the sentences.
kathinatthārā.translation_1: For how many kinds of people is the robe-making ceremony not effective?
kathinatthārā.translation_2: For how many kinds of people is the robe-making ceremony effective?

anumodento.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'anumodento' refers to the one expressing appreciation, either verbally or non-verbally, in relation to monastic boundaries and communication rules.
anumodento.example_1: nissīmaṭṭho anumodati, anumodento na vācaṃ bhindati, vācaṃ bhindanto na paraṃ viññāpeti—
anumodento.translation_1: For one who expresses their appreciation outside the monastery zone; for one who does not express their appreciation verbally; for one who expresses it verbally, but does not inform anyone.
anumodento.example_2: sīmaṭṭho anumodati, anumodento vācaṃ bhindati, vācaṃ bhindanto paraṃ viññāpeti—
anumodento.translation_2: For one who expresses their appreciation inside the monastery zone; for one who expresses their appreciation verbally; for one who expresses it verbally and informs someone.

vatthuvipannañceva.meaning_2: failure of the object; failure of the case
vatthuvipannañceva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In this Vinaya context, 'vatthuvipannañceva' functions as an adverbial phrase emphasizing the failure of the object or case in a legal or ritual procedure, paralleling failures in timing and manner.
vatthuvipannañceva.translation_1: The object fails; the timing fails; the making fails.

kālavipannañca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, kālavipannañca refers to a failure or error in the appropriate timing or occasion for an action, paralleling failures in object and instrument.
kālavipannañca.translation_1: The object fails; the timing fails; the making fails.

karaṇavipannañca.meaning_2: failed in the making; defective in the act of doing
karaṇavipannañca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'karaṇavipannañca' describes a failure or defect in the 'karaṇa' aspect, interpreted as the making or performing, parallel to failures in object and timing. The form is nominative singular neuter, agreeing with the implied neuter subject, and functions adjectivally in the compound.
karaṇavipannañca.translation_1: The object fails; the timing fails; the making fails.

vatthusampannañceva.meaning_2: well-equipped with regard to the object; successful in the matter; endowed with a proper basis or case
vatthusampannañceva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'vatthusampannañceva' describes something that 'succeeds' or is 'well-accomplished' with respect to the 'object' (vatthu), interpreted as the matter, case, or basis in a procedural or doctrinal sense, paralleling kālasampanna (timing) and karaṇasampanna (method). The neuter form agrees with the implied subject in the clause.
vatthusampannañceva.translation_1: The object succeeds; the timing succeeds; the making succeeds.

kālasampannañca.meaning_2: successful in timing; successful regarding the right time; opportune
kālasampannañca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, kālasampannañca refers to the action being successful or appropriate in terms of timing, paralleling vatthusampanna (object) and karaṇasampanna (means). The form is nominative singular masculine, agreeing with an implied masculine subject.
kālasampannañca.translation_1: The object succeeds; the timing succeeds; the making succeeds.

karaṇasampannañca.meaning_2: successful in execution; accomplished in the act of doing; effective in performance
karaṇasampannañca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'karaṇasampannañca' refers to the success or perfection in the 'making' or instrumental aspect of an action, paralleling the success in object and timing.
karaṇasampannañca.translation_1: The object succeeds; the timing succeeds; the making succeeds.

kathinādijānitabbavibhāgo.meaning_2: division of cases beginning with kathina; classification starting from kathina privileges etc.
kathinādijānitabbavibhāgo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound likely from a Vinaya context, referring to the analytical division or classification of monastic cases or topics beginning with the kathina ceremony or privileges and so on. The structure indicates a systematic breakdown of matters that should be understood, starting from kathina.

kathinatthāro.meaning_2: participation in the robe-making ceremony; observance of the kathina privileges
kathinatthāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'kathinatthāro' refers to the formal observance or participation in the kathina robe ceremony, where monks announce its legitimate performance to receive appreciation (anumodanā). It is a compound of 'kathina' (the robe ceremony) and 'atthāra' (spreading out, here denoting the act of carrying out or participating in the ceremony's provisions).
kathinatthāro.example_1: kathinaṃ jānitabbaṃ, kathinatthāro jānitabbo, kathinassa atthāramāso jānitabbo, kathinassa atthāravipatti jānitabbā, kathinassa atthārasampatti jānitabbā, nimittakammaṃ jānitabbaṃ, parikathā jānitabbā, kukkukataṃ jānitabbaṃ, sannidhi jānitabbā, nissaggiyaṃ jānitabbaṃ.
kathinatthāro.translation_1: The robe-making ceremony is to be known. Participation in the robe-making ceremony is to be known. The month of the robe-making ceremony is to be known. Failure of the robe-making ceremony is to be known. Success of the robe-making ceremony is to be known. The giving of an indication is to be known. A hint is to be known. Borrowing is to be known. Storing is to be known. Relinquishment is to be known.
kathinatthāro.translation_2: Participation in the robe-making ceremony is to be known:

atthāramāso.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound 'atthāramāso' refers to the month or period during which the kathina robe-making ceremony is conducted in the Vinaya context, as indicated by the sentence 'kathinassa atthāramāso jānitabbo' meaning 'the month of the robe-making ceremony is to be known.' Here, 'attha' denotes purpose or matter related to the kathina, and 'māsa' means month.
atthāramāso.example_1: kathinaṃ jānitabbaṃ, kathinatthāro jānitabbo, kathinassa atthāramāso jānitabbo, kathinassa atthāravipatti jānitabbā, kathinassa atthārasampatti jānitabbā, nimittakammaṃ jānitabbaṃ, parikathā jānitabbā, kukkukataṃ jānitabbaṃ, sannidhi jānitabbā, nissaggiyaṃ jānitabbaṃ.
atthāramāso.translation_1: The robe-making ceremony is to be known. Participation in the robe-making ceremony is to be known. The month of the robe-making ceremony is to be known. Failure of the robe-making ceremony is to be known. Success of the robe-making ceremony is to be known. The giving of an indication is to be known. A hint is to be known. Borrowing is to be known. Storing is to be known. Relinquishment is to be known.
atthāramāso.translation_2: The month of the robe-making ceremony is to be known:

atthāravipatti.meaning_2: failure of the spreading out; failure of the robe-making ceremony
atthāravipatti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'atthāravipatti' specifically denotes the failure or lapse in the 'atthāra' (spreading out or allocation) phase of the kathina robe-making ceremony, which can occur in 24 specified ways, leading to the loss of kathina privileges.
atthāravipatti.example_1: kathinaṃ jānitabbaṃ, kathinatthāro jānitabbo, kathinassa atthāramāso jānitabbo, kathinassa atthāravipatti jānitabbā, kathinassa atthārasampatti jānitabbā, nimittakammaṃ jānitabbaṃ, parikathā jānitabbā, kukkukataṃ jānitabbaṃ, sannidhi jānitabbā, nissaggiyaṃ jānitabbaṃ.
atthāravipatti.translation_1: The robe-making ceremony is to be known. Participation in the robe-making ceremony is to be known. The month of the robe-making ceremony is to be known. Failure of the robe-making ceremony is to be known. Success of the robe-making ceremony is to be known. The giving of an indication is to be known. A hint is to be known. Borrowing is to be known. Storing is to be known. Relinquishment is to be known.
atthāravipatti.translation_2: Failure of the robe-making ceremony is to be known:

atthārasampatti.meaning_2: success; accomplishment; prosperity (of the robe-making ceremony)
atthārasampatti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya, 'atthārasampatti' specifically refers to the success or accomplishment of the kathina robe-making ceremony, achieved through seventeen distinct aspects or modes as outlined in the text.
atthārasampatti.example_1: kathinaṃ jānitabbaṃ, kathinatthāro jānitabbo, kathinassa atthāramāso jānitabbo, kathinassa atthāravipatti jānitabbā, kathinassa atthārasampatti jānitabbā, nimittakammaṃ jānitabbaṃ, parikathā jānitabbā, kukkukataṃ jānitabbaṃ, sannidhi jānitabbā, nissaggiyaṃ jānitabbaṃ.
atthārasampatti.translation_1: The robe-making ceremony is to be known. Participation in the robe-making ceremony is to be known. The month of the robe-making ceremony is to be known. Failure of the robe-making ceremony is to be known. Success of the robe-making ceremony is to be known. The giving of an indication is to be known. A hint is to be known. Borrowing is to be known. Storing is to be known. Relinquishment is to be known.
atthārasampatti.translation_2: Success of the robe-making ceremony is to be known:

kathinatthārakassa.meaning_2: of the one performing the robe-making ceremony; of the one spreading the kathina cloth
kathinatthārakassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The genitive form 'kathinatthārakassa' refers to the monk responsible for handling the kathina cloth in the robe-making process, as seen in the context where he is instructed to prepare and perform the ceremony with the cloth.
kathinatthārakassa.example_1: saṅghena ñattidutiyena kammena kathinatthārakassa bhikkhuno dātabbaṃ, tena kathinatthārakena bhikkhunā tadaheva dhovitvā vimajjitvā vicāretvā chinditvā sibbetvā rajitvā kappaṃ katvā kathinaṃ attharitabbaṃ.
kathinatthārakassa.translation_1: The Sangha should give the cloth, through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and one announcement, to the monk who is performing the robe-making ceremony. The monk who is performing the robe-making ceremony should wash the cloth, iron it, plan it, cut it, sew it, dye it, mark it, and then perform the robe-making ceremony.

kathinatthārakena.meaning_2: monk who is performing the robe-making ceremony; monk who spreads out the kathina cloth
kathinatthārakena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term is an instrumental singular of the compound 'kathinatthāraka', used throughout the text to refer to the specific monk assigned the duty of handling the kathina robe cloth, from receiving it to performing the final spreading ceremony. The English translation consistently renders it as 'the monk who is performing the robe-making ceremony', emphasizing the ritual role.
kathinatthārakena.example_1: saṅghena ñattidutiyena kammena kathinatthārakassa bhikkhuno dātabbaṃ, tena kathinatthārakena bhikkhunā tadaheva dhovitvā vimajjitvā vicāretvā chinditvā sibbetvā rajitvā kappaṃ katvā kathinaṃ attharitabbaṃ.
kathinatthārakena.translation_1: The Sangha should give the cloth, through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and one announcement, to the monk who is performing the robe-making ceremony. The monk who is performing the robe-making ceremony should wash the cloth, iron it, plan it, cut it, sew it, dye it, mark it, and then perform the robe-making ceremony.
kathinatthārakena.example_2: tena kathinatthārakena bhikkhunā saṅghaṃ upasaṅkamitvā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā añjaliṃ paggahetvā evamassa vacanīyo—
kathinatthārakena.translation_2: After approaching the Sangha, that monk who is performing the robe-making ceremony should arrange his upper robe over one shoulder, raise his joined palms, and say:

vimajjitvā.meaning_2: having cleaned; having ironed; having smoothed out
vimajjitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the robe-making ceremony (kathina), 'vimajjitvā' refers to the step of ironing or smoothing the cloth after washing, to prepare it for cutting and sewing. The English translation 'iron it' aligns with this technical usage in Vinaya texts.
vimajjitvā.example_1: saṅghena ñattidutiyena kammena kathinatthārakassa bhikkhuno dātabbaṃ, tena kathinatthārakena bhikkhunā tadaheva dhovitvā vimajjitvā vicāretvā chinditvā sibbetvā rajitvā kappaṃ katvā kathinaṃ attharitabbaṃ.
vimajjitvā.translation_1: The Sangha should give the cloth, through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and one announcement, to the monk who is performing the robe-making ceremony. The monk who is performing the robe-making ceremony should wash the cloth, iron it, plan it, cut it, sew it, dye it, mark it, and then perform the robe-making ceremony.

attharitukāmo.grammar: adj, in comps, from attharituṃ + kāma
attharitukāmo.meaning_2: wishing to perform the robe-making ceremony; desiring to spread out the robe for the ceremony
attharitukāmo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'attharituṃ' specifically refers to spreading out or laying out the robe in the kathina ceremony, a ritual act marking the end of the rains retreat. The compound 'attharitukāmo' describes a monk who intends to undertake this ceremony using a particular robe type, necessitating the replacement of the old robe with the new one.
attharitukāmo.example_1: sace saṅghāṭiyā kathinaṃ attharitukāmo hoti, porāṇikā saṅghāṭi paccuddharitabbā, navā saṅghāṭi adhiṭṭhātabbā.
attharitukāmo.translation_1: If he wishes to perform the robe-making ceremony with an outer robe, he should relinquish his old outer robe and then determine the new one.
attharitukāmo.example_2: sace uttarāsaṅgena kathinaṃ attharitukāmo hoti, porāṇako uttarāsaṅgo paccuddharitabbo, navo uttarāsaṅgo adhiṭṭhātabbo.
attharitukāmo.translation_2: If he wishes to perform the robe-making ceremony with an upper robe, he should relinquish his old upper robe and then determine the new one.

porāṇikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'porāṇikā saṅghāṭi' refers to the old or previous outer robe that must be relinquished before determining a new one for the robe-making ceremony.
porāṇikā.example_1: sace saṅghāṭiyā kathinaṃ attharitukāmo hoti, porāṇikā saṅghāṭi paccuddharitabbā, navā saṅghāṭi adhiṭṭhātabbā.
porāṇikā.translation_1: If he wishes to perform the robe-making ceremony with an outer robe, he should relinquish his old outer robe and then determine the new one.

paccuddharitabbā.meaning_2: should be relinquished; should be given up
