paccuddharitabbā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the robe-making ceremony, 'paccuddharitabbā' refers to the requirement to set aside or relinquish the old outer robe (porāṇikā saṅghāṭi) before determining the new one, indicating a procedural step in monastic practice.
paccuddharitabbā.example_1: sace saṅghāṭiyā kathinaṃ attharitukāmo hoti, porāṇikā saṅghāṭi paccuddharitabbā, navā saṅghāṭi adhiṭṭhātabbā.
paccuddharitabbā.translation_1: If he wishes to perform the robe-making ceremony with an outer robe, he should relinquish his old outer robe and then determine the new one.

bhinditabbā.meaning_2: should be broken; must be said
bhinditabbā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the robe-making ceremony (kathina), 'bhinditabbā' refers to the necessity of uttering the specified declaration with the robe, effectively 'breaking' or initiating the ceremony through speech.
bhinditabbā.example_1: imāya saṅghāṭiyā kathinaṃ attharāmīti vācā bhinditabbā.
bhinditabbā.translation_1: He should then say, “I perform the robe-making ceremony with this outer robe.”
bhinditabbā.example_2: iminā uttarāsaṅgena kathinaṃ attharāmīti vācā bhinditabbā.
bhinditabbā.translation_2: He should then say, “I perform the robe-making ceremony with this upper robe.”

paccuddharitabbo.meaning_2: should be relinquished; should be given up
paccuddharitabbo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, the word refers to formally relinquishing or setting aside an old robe (uttarāsaṅga or antaravāsaka) as part of the procedure to determine a new one for the robe-making ceremony (kathina). The prefix paccu- (from pati + ud-) implies a reversal or counteraction, fitting the act of undoing the prior determination of the old robe.
paccuddharitabbo.example_1: sace uttarāsaṅgena kathinaṃ attharitukāmo hoti, porāṇako uttarāsaṅgo paccuddharitabbo, navo uttarāsaṅgo adhiṭṭhātabbo.
paccuddharitabbo.translation_1: If he wishes to perform the robe-making ceremony with an upper robe, he should relinquish his old upper robe and then determine the new one.
paccuddharitabbo.example_2: sace antaravāsakena kathinaṃ attharitukāmo hoti, porāṇako antaravāsako paccuddharitabbo, navo antaravāsako adhiṭṭhātabbo.
paccuddharitabbo.translation_2: If he wishes to perform the robe-making ceremony with a sarong, he should relinquish his old sarong and then determine the new one.

puggalassevakathinatthāro.meaning_1: spreading out of talking about serving individuals
puggalassevakathinatthāro.meaning_2: one who spreads out the discourse on serving persons
puggalassevakathinatthāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a tatpuruṣa compound where 'puggala' (person) is genitive in sense, combined with 'sevaka' (servant) and 'kathī' (talking about), modified by 'ātthāra' (spreader). Likely a technical term in a Vinaya or commentarial context referring to an individual or role involved in expounding teachings on serving or attending to persons, such as monks or laypeople.

palibodhapañhābyākaraṇaṃ.meaning_2: answering a question that is an obstruction; replying to an obstructive question
palibodhapañhābyākaraṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a neuter noun in accusative singular, likely referring to the act or instance of answering a question that poses an obstruction or hindrance, possibly in a doctrinal or interrogative context.

bahisīmagamanā.meaning_2: going outside the monastery zone; departing from the simā area
bahisīmagamanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound refers to the act of going beyond the monastery's legal boundary (sīmā), which removes certain monastic obstacles (antarāyikā dhammā) as per the sentence. The instrumental case indicates the means by which the obstacle is removed.
bahisīmagamanā.translation_1: The monastery obstacle is removed when one goes outside the monastery zone.

sīmātikkamanantiko.meaning_2: while one is outside the monastery zone; while one has gone beyond the boundary
sīmātikkamanantiko.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This term is a compound adjective used in Vinaya contexts to describe a situation where the kathina robe season ends while a monk is outside the sīmā (monastery boundary), affecting robe-related privileges.
sīmātikkamanantiko.translation_1: The robe season ends while he is outside the monastery zone.
sīmātikkamanantiko.translation_2: The robe season ends while he is outside the monastery zone.

saṅghādhīnā.meaning_2: depending on the Sangha; subject to the Sangha; determined by the Sangha
saṅghādhīnā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, saṅghādhīnā describes types of robe season endings that are under the authority or decision of the monastic community (Saṅgha), contrasting with those depending on individuals or neither.
saṅghādhīnā.translation_1: “How many kinds of endings of the robe season depend on the Sangha?
saṅghādhīnā.example_2: kati kathinuddhārā neva saṅghādhīnā na puggalādhīnā?
saṅghādhīnā.translation_2: How many kinds of endings of the robe season depend neither on the Sangha nor on an individual?

puggalādhīnā.meaning_2: depending on an individual; subject to a person
puggalādhīnā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'puggalādhīnā' describes types of robe-season endings that are dependent on or determined by an individual (puggalā), as opposed to the Sangha or neither.
puggalādhīnā.translation_1: How many kinds of endings of the robe season depend on an individual?
puggalādhīnā.example_2: kati kathinuddhārā neva saṅghādhīnā na puggalādhīnā?
puggalādhīnā.translation_2: How many kinds of endings of the robe season depend neither on the Sangha nor on an individual?

saṅghādhīno.meaning_2: depending on the Sangha; subject to the Sangha
saṅghādhīno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, saṅghādhīno describes a type of robe season ending that is under the authority or decision of the monastic community (Sangha).
saṅghādhīno.translation_1: One kind of ending of the robe season depends on the Sangha:

uddhariyyanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'uddhariyanti' specifically refers to the ritual or procedural 'endings' or 'dissolutions' (uddhāra) of the kathina robe privileges, which 'happen' or are carried out in specified locations relative to the monastery boundaries (sīmā).
uddhariyyanti.translation_1: How many kinds of endings of the robe season happen inside the monastery zone?
uddhariyyanti.translation_2: How many kinds of endings of the robe season happen outside the monastery zone?

ekuppādā.meaning_2: arising together; coming into being together
ekuppādā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'ekuppādā' is a compound adjective describing 'kathinuddhārā' (endings of the robe season), indicating those that arise simultaneously, contrasting with 'nānānirodhā' (ending separately). The feminine plural form agrees with the head noun.
ekuppādā.translation_1: How many kinds of endings of the robe season arise together and end together?
ekuppādā.translation_2: How many kinds of endings of the robe season arise together and end separately?

ekanirodhā.meaning_2: single ending; one and the same termination; simultaneous cessation
ekanirodhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'ekanirodhā' refers to endings of the robe season (kathinuddhārā) that cease together or simultaneously, with 'eka' emphasizing unity and 'nirodhā' indicating the act of termination. It is the instrumental plural form used to describe multiple such unified endings.
ekanirodhā.translation_1: How many kinds of endings of the robe season arise together and end together?
ekanirodhā.translation_2: Two kinds of endings of the robe season arise together and end together:

nānānirodhā.meaning_2: separate endings; distinct terminations; diverse cessations
nānānirodhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'nānānirodhā' refers to multiple distinct endings or terminations of the robe season (vassa or kaṭhinā period) that occur separately, contrasting with endings that arise together (ekuppādā).
nānānirodhā.translation_1: How many kinds of endings of the robe season arise together and end separately?

nānānirodhāti.meaning_2: various endings; diverse cessations; separate terminations
nānānirodhāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'nānānirodhāti' is an indeclinable quotative form emphasizing that the remaining robe-season endings arise simultaneously (ekuppādā) but cease in a varied or distinct manner, contrasting with unified arising.
nānānirodhāti.translation_1: The rest of the endings of the robe season arise together but end separately.”

nidānahetu.meaning_2: source and cause; origin and reason
nidānahetu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'dhammā nidānahetu ca', nidānahetu functions as a compound enumerating two related concepts—source/origin (nidāna) and cause/reason (hetu)—likely paralleling or specifying aspects of 'dhammā' (things or phenomena), emphasizing their foundational and causal nature in Buddhist doctrine.

paccayasaṅgahamūlā.meaning_2: roots of the grouping of conditions
paccayasaṅgahamūlā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a technical term, likely referring to the foundational principles or sources underlying the classification or grouping of conditions (paccaya) in a doctrinal or grammatical context, as suggested by the English rendering 'Condition, grouped with, roots'.

atthārapuggalā.meaning_2: persons who perform the robe-making ceremony
atthārapuggalā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'ādi ca atthārapuggalā', the term refers to persons involved in the initial robe-making ceremony in Vinaya procedures, with 'atthāra' denoting the spreading out or preparation of materials for robes.
atthārapuggalā.translation_1: And beginning, persons who perform the robe-making ceremony.

aṭṭhapuggalā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound aṭṭhapuggalā is the nominative plural form, referring to a specific set of eight types of persons in Buddhist doctrine, such as the eight noble individuals (ariyapuggala) in the context of the noble path.

palibodhādhinā.meaning_2: by an obstruction-dependent (boundary); by a hindrance-based (monastery zone)
palibodhādhinā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form palibodhādhinā is an instrumental singular of a tatpuruṣa compound palibodhādhi ('obstruction-dependent' or 'hindrance-based'), used here to describe a sīmā (monastery zone) that is determined by obstacles or impediments, as per the contextual sentence.
palibodhādhinā.translation_1: Obstacles, depend on, in a monastery zone,

uppādanirodhena.meaning_2: by arising and ceasing; by coming into being and termination
uppādanirodhena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in the context to denote the process of arising and ending, likely referring to the Buddhist doctrine of dependent origination where phenomena arise and cease conditionally.

upālipañcakaṃ.meaning_2: the pentad of Upāli; the five questions of Upāli
upālipañcakaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'upālipañcakaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ' indicates the completion of the section on the five questions posed by Ven. Upāli to the Buddha, likely referring to Upāli the foremost disciple in Vinaya.
upālipañcakaṃ.translation_1: Ven. Upāli questions the Buddha is finished.

anissitavaggo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound noun refers to the title of a subchapter in the Pāli text, where 'anissita' indicates the theme of detachment or lack of formal support, and 'vagga' denotes a section or group of suttas, as concluded in the sentence.
anissitavaggo.translation_1: The first subchapter on “without formal support” is finished.

pañcahupāli.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a vocative sandhi form addressing Upāli in the context of discussing monks possessing five specific qualities that qualify or disqualify them for various monastic roles and actions, such as ordination, speaking in assembly, or resolving disputes. The English translations consistently render it as 'one who has five qualities' or similar, indicating a person (typically a monk) endowed with five attributes.
pañcahupāli.example_1: “pañcahupāli, aṅgehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā yāvajīvaṃ nānissitena vatthabbaṃ.
pañcahupāli.example_2: pañcahupāli, aṅgehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā yāvajīvaṃ anissitena vatthabbaṃ.
pañcahupāli.translation_2: But a monk who has five qualities may live without formal support for life:

vimativinodanīṭīkāya.meaning_2: sub-commentary that dispels doubt; commentary dispelling uncertainty
vimativinodanīṭīkāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a title or name for a sub-commentary specifically aimed at dispelling doubts and confusion, likely in a doctrinal or philosophical context. The instrumental case (locative or dative sense possible) suggests 'by means of the sub-commentary that dispels doubt'.

mahāvaggavaṇṇanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun referring to the commentary on one of the Mahāvagga sections, most likely the Mahāvagga of the Vinaya Piṭaka given the context of Pāḷi grammatical analysis.

ājīvavipanno.meaning_2: failed in livelihood; having wrong livelihood
ājīvavipanno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, ājīvavipanno describes a monk who has erred or failed in his proper mode of livelihood, often linked with wrong view (micchādiṭṭhiko), indicating ethical and practical shortcomings in monastic life.
ājīvavipanno.example_1: alajjī ca hoti, bālo ca, apakatatto ca, micchādiṭṭhiko ca hoti, ājīvavipanno ca—
ājīvavipanno.translation_1: he is shameless, ignorant, and not a regular monk, and he has wrong view, and he has failed in livelihood.
ājīvavipanno.example_2: adhisīle sīlavipanno hoti, ajjhācāre ācāravipanno hoti, atidiṭṭhiyā diṭṭhivipanno hoti, micchādiṭṭhiko ca hoti, ājīvavipanno ca—
ājīvavipanno.translation_2: he has failed in the higher morality; he has failed in conduct; he has failed in view; he has wrong view; and he has failed in livelihood.

abhisamācāralajjī.meaning_2: having excellent conduct and shamelessness; one who is well-behaved yet without shame
abhisamācāralajjī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given context, the word appears to contrast or juxtapose good conduct with shamelessness, possibly indicating a person of refined behavior who lacks moral sensitivity. The English translation treats it as two separate elements, but as a compound, it functions as a single descriptive term. Note that 'lajjī' means 'ashamed' or 'conscientious,' while the form here aligns with 'alajjī' (shameless), suggesting a negative connotation despite the positive 'abhisamācāra.'

yāyāpattiyā.meaning_2: offence for which; transgression by which
yāyāpattiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the compound 'yāyāpatti', where 'yāyā' (instr. fem. of relative pronoun 'ya') means 'by which' and 'patti' is an abstract noun meaning 'reaching' or 'attainment', forming 'offence by which one reaches' or 'offence for which'. In the Vinaya context, it refers to an offence entailing a specific consequence, as in 'offense for which, of the Buddha'.
yāyāpattiyā.translation_1: Offense for which, of the Buddha—

vaggasaṅgahoti.meaning_2: compilation of the chapter; collection of the section
vaggasaṅgahoti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'vaggasaṅgahoti' functions as a formulaic phrase marking the completion of a subchapter (vagga) in textual compilations, where 'saṅgaha' implies the act of gathering or assembling the contents, and 'hoti' indicates completion or finality.
vaggasaṅgahoti.translation_1: The compilation of the first subchapter is finished.”
vaggasaṅgahoti.translation_2: The compilation of the third subchapter is finished.”

nappaṭippassambhanavaggo.meaning_2: subchapter on not lifting; subchapter on non-annulment; subchapter on that which is not lifted
nappaṭippassambhanavaggo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound is a descriptive title for a section in the Vinaya text, where 'na' negates the action of 'paṭippassambhati' (to be annulled or lifted, often used for rules or precepts), and 'vagga' denotes a chapter or subchapter. The English translation 'subchapter on not lifting' reflects its use as a concluding phrase for the second such section.
nappaṭippassambhanavaggo.translation_1: The second subchapter on not lifting is finished.

nissajjakusalena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'nissajjakusalena' is an instrumental form describing the bhikkhu's attitude when approaching the Sangha; it parallels 'āsanakusalena' (skilled in seats), indicating skill in the act of sitting down or taking one's seat appropriately without encroaching on others.
nissajjakusalena.example_1: saṅgāmāvacarena, upāli, bhikkhunā saṅghaṃ upasaṅkamantena nīcacittena saṅgho upasaṅkamitabbo, rajoharaṇasamena cittena, āsanakusalena bhavitabbaṃ nissajjakusalena, there bhikkhū anupakhajjantena, nave bhikkhū āsanena appaṭibāhantena yathāpatirūpe āsane nisīditabbaṃ, anānākathikena bhavitabbaṃ atiracchānakathikena, sāmaṃ vā dhammo bhāsitabbo, paro vā ajjhesitabbo, ariyo vā tuṇhībhāvo nātimaññitabbo, sace, upāli, saṅgho samaggakaraṇīyāni kammāni karoti;
nissajjakusalena.translation_1: (1) he should be humble; (2) he should be intent on removing defilements; (3) he should be skilled in appropriate seating and where to sit down, taking a seat without encroaching on the senior monks and without blocking the junior monks; (4) he shouldn’t ramble or engage in worldly talk, but should speak according to the Teaching or invite others to speak or value noble silence; (5) if the Sangha is doing legal procedures requiring unity, but the monk doesn’t approve, then he should reveal his view but think, ‘I shouldn’t be at variance with the Sangha,’ and unity can then be announced.”

tuṇhibhāvo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] tuṇhibhāvo is a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'the state of silence', derived from tuṇhī (silence) and bhāva (state, abstract noun from √bhū). It denotes the condition or quality of being silent, often used in contexts of restraint in speech.

samaggakaraṇīyāni.meaning_2: legal procedures requiring unity; acts that need to be done unanimously; matters to be performed in concord
samaggakaraṇīyāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'samaggakaraṇīyāni kammāni' refers to formal Sangha transactions or legal acts that require all monks to be in agreement and present, ensuring communal harmony before proceeding.
samaggakaraṇīyāni.example_1: saṅgāmāvacarena, upāli, bhikkhunā saṅghaṃ upasaṅkamantena nīcacittena saṅgho upasaṅkamitabbo, rajoharaṇasamena cittena, āsanakusalena bhavitabbaṃ nissajjakusalena, there bhikkhū anupakhajjantena, nave bhikkhū āsanena appaṭibāhantena yathāpatirūpe āsane nisīditabbaṃ, anānākathikena bhavitabbaṃ atiracchānakathikena, sāmaṃ vā dhammo bhāsitabbo, paro vā ajjhesitabbo, ariyo vā tuṇhībhāvo nātimaññitabbo, sace, upāli, saṅgho samaggakaraṇīyāni kammāni karoti;
samaggakaraṇīyāni.translation_1: (1) he should be humble; (2) he should be intent on removing defilements; (3) he should be skilled in appropriate seating and where to sit down, taking a seat without encroaching on the senior monks and without blocking the junior monks; (4) he shouldn’t ramble or engage in worldly talk, but should speak according to the Teaching or invite others to speak or value noble silence; (5) if the Sangha is doing legal procedures requiring unity, but the monk doesn’t approve, then he should reveal his view but think, ‘I shouldn’t be at variance with the Sangha,’ and unity can then be announced.”

kissahetu.grammar: pron, interr, masc & nt dat sg of ka + hetu
kissahetu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'taṃ kissahetu?', 'kissahetu' functions as an interrogative pronoun phrase asking 'for what reason?' or 'why?' regarding 'taṃ' (that). It combines the dative 'kissa' (for what) with 'hetu' (reason), often used in causal inquiries in Pāḷi texts.

saṅgāmāvacarenupāli.meaning_2: Upāli accustomed to the battle-field; war-experienced Upāli
saṅgāmāvacarenupāli.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Vocative singular form addressing Upāli, the foremost Vinaya expert, in the context of a monk approaching the Saṅgha after recalling five dhammas internally. The compound highlights Upāli's background as a former charioteer skilled in battle.
saṅgāmāvacarenupāli.example_1: saṅgāmāvacarenupāli, bhikkhunā saṅghaṃ upasaṅkamantena ime pañca dhamme ajjhattaṃ upaṭṭhāpetvā saṅgho upasaṅkamitabbo”ti.

bahujanaakanto.meaning_2: disliked by the majority; disagreeable to many people
bahujanaakanto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'bahujanaakanto' describes a monk who is disliked by the majority (bahujana) when speaking in the Sangha, emphasizing unpopularity and disapproval among the community.
bahujanaakanto.example_1: “katihi nu kho, bhante, aṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu saṅghe voharanto bahujanaakanto ca hoti bahujanaamanāpo ca bahujanaarucito cā”ti?
bahujanaakanto.translation_1: “What sort of monk does the majority dislike and disapprove of when he speaks in the Sangha?”
bahujanaakanto.example_2: “pañcahupāli, aṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu saṅghe voharanto bahujanaakanto ca hoti bahujanaamanāpo ca bahujanarucito ca.

bahujanaamanāpo.meaning_2: disliked by the majority; disapproved of by the many
bahujanaamanāpo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, this compound describes a monk who, when speaking in the Sangha, is disliked (bahujanaakanto), disapproved of (bahujanaamanāpo), and not pleasing (bahujanaarucito) to the majority of people.
bahujanaamanāpo.example_1: “katihi nu kho, bhante, aṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu saṅghe voharanto bahujanaakanto ca hoti bahujanaamanāpo ca bahujanaarucito cā”ti?
bahujanaamanāpo.translation_1: “What sort of monk does the majority dislike and disapprove of when he speaks in the Sangha?”
bahujanaamanāpo.example_2: “pañcahupāli, aṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu saṅghe voharanto bahujanaakanto ca hoti bahujanaamanāpo ca bahujanarucito ca.

bahujanaarucito.meaning_2: disliked by many; disapproved of by the majority; not pleasing to the people
bahujanaarucito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'bahujanaarucito' describes a monk who, when speaking in the Sangha, is disliked and disapproved of by the majority of people, indicating unpopularity or aversion among the community.
bahujanaarucito.example_1: “katihi nu kho, bhante, aṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu saṅghe voharanto bahujanaakanto ca hoti bahujanaamanāpo ca bahujanaarucito cā”ti?
bahujanaarucito.translation_1: “What sort of monk does the majority dislike and disapprove of when he speaks in the Sangha?”
bahujanaarucito.example_2: imehi kho, upāli, pañcahaṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu saṅghe voharanto bahujanaakanto ca hoti bahujanaamanāpo ca bahujanaarucito ca.

ussitamantī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'ussitamantī' describes a negative trait of arrogance in a monk, contrasting with the positive qualities in the second sentence. It likely functions as a bahuvrīhi compound, meaning 'one whose mind/counsel is raised up' or 'puffed up in mind', implying pride or self-importance, as opposed to the humble and diligent behavior outlined.
ussitamantī.example_1: ussitamantī ca hoti, nissitajappī ca, na ca bhāsānusandhikusalo hoti, na yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā codetā hoti, na yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā kāretā hoti—
ussitamantī.translation_1: (1) he’s arrogant; (2) he repeats what others say; (3) he doesn’t keep to the topic; (4) he doesn’t accuse others according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, or their offense; (5) he doesn’t act according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, or his offenses.
ussitamantī.example_2: na ussitamantī ca hoti, na nissitajappī ca, bhāsānusandhikusalo ca hoti, yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā codetā hoti, yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā kāretā hoti—
ussitamantī.translation_2: (1) he’s not arrogant; (2) he doesn’t repeat what others say; (3) he keeps to the topic; (4) he accuses others according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, and their offense; (5) he acts according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, and his offenses.

bhāsānusandhikusalo.meaning_2: skilled in speech-connection; adept at maintaining the topic or discourse coherence
bhāsānusandhikusalo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'bhāsānusandhikusalo' describes a positive quality of a monk who stays on topic during discussions or admonitions, contrasting with one who does not. It likely refers to skill in connecting speech logically, ensuring relevance to the Dhamma, Vinaya, and offenses, essential for effective monastic discipline.
bhāsānusandhikusalo.example_1: ussitamantī ca hoti, nissitajappī ca, na ca bhāsānusandhikusalo hoti, na yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā codetā hoti, na yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā kāretā hoti—
bhāsānusandhikusalo.translation_1: (1) he’s arrogant; (2) he repeats what others say; (3) he doesn’t keep to the topic; (4) he doesn’t accuse others according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, or their offense; (5) he doesn’t act according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, or his offenses.
bhāsānusandhikusalo.example_2: na ussitamantī ca hoti, na nissitajappī ca, bhāsānusandhikusalo ca hoti, yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā codetā hoti, yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā kāretā hoti—
bhāsānusandhikusalo.translation_2: (1) he’s not arrogant; (2) he doesn’t repeat what others say; (3) he keeps to the topic; (4) he accuses others according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, and their offense; (5) he acts according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, and his offenses.

yathāvinaye.meaning_2: according to the monastic law; in conformity with the discipline
yathāvinaye.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'yathāvinaye' is part of the compound phrase 'yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā', meaning 'according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, or their offense'. It refers to acting or accusing in accordance with the Vinaya, the code of monastic discipline, emphasizing adherence to proper procedure in monastic matters.
yathāvinaye.example_1: ussitamantī ca hoti, nissitajappī ca, na ca bhāsānusandhikusalo hoti, na yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā codetā hoti, na yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā kāretā hoti—
yathāvinaye.translation_1: (1) he’s arrogant; (2) he repeats what others say; (3) he doesn’t keep to the topic; (4) he doesn’t accuse others according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, or their offense; (5) he doesn’t act according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, or his offenses.
yathāvinaye.example_2: ussitamantī ca hoti, nissitajappī ca, na ca bhāsānusandhikusalo hoti, na yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā codetā hoti, na yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā kāretā hoti—
yathāvinaye.translation_2: (1) he’s arrogant; (2) he repeats what others say; (3) he doesn’t keep to the topic; (4) he doesn’t accuse others according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, or their offense; (5) he doesn’t act according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, or his offenses.

yathāpattiyā.meaning_2: according to the offense; in accordance with the transgression
yathāpattiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya passages, 'yathāpattiyā' refers to acting or accusing in accordance with the specific nature or gravity of an offense (āpatti), ensuring procedural fairness according to the Dhamma and Vinaya. The instrumental case indicates the manner or standard of action.
yathāpattiyā.example_1: ussitamantī ca hoti, nissitajappī ca, na ca bhāsānusandhikusalo hoti, na yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā codetā hoti, na yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā kāretā hoti—
yathāpattiyā.translation_1: (1) he’s arrogant; (2) he repeats what others say; (3) he doesn’t keep to the topic; (4) he doesn’t accuse others according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, or their offense; (5) he doesn’t act according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, or his offenses.
yathāpattiyā.example_2: ussitamantī ca hoti, nissitajappī ca, na ca bhāsānusandhikusalo hoti, na yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā codetā hoti, na yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā kāretā hoti—
yathāpattiyā.translation_2: (1) he’s arrogant; (2) he repeats what others say; (3) he doesn’t keep to the topic; (4) he doesn’t accuse others according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, or their offense; (5) he doesn’t act according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, or his offenses.

bahujanarucito.meaning_2: pleasing to the multitude; agreeable to the majority; liked by the people
bahujanarucito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, bahujanarucita describes a monk who, possessing five qualities, is liked and approved by the majority when speaking in the Sangha, paralleling bahujanakanto (liked by the multitude) and bahujanamanāpo (approved by the multitude).
bahujanarucito.example_1: “pañcahupāli, aṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu saṅghe voharanto bahujanaakanto ca hoti bahujanaamanāpo ca bahujanarucito ca.
bahujanarucito.example_2: pañcahupāli, aṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu saṅghe voharanto bahujanakanto ca hoti bahujanamanāpo ca bahujanarucito ca.
bahujanarucito.translation_2: But when a monk has five qualities, the majority likes and approves of him when he speaks in the Sangha:

pasayhapavattā.meaning_2: speaking forcefully; proceeding with force; acting aggressively
pasayhapavattā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, pasayhapavattā describes a negative behavior of speaking or acting forcefully without restraint, contrasted with the positive absence of such forcefulness in proper monastic conduct.
pasayhapavattā.example_1: pasayhapavattā hoti, anokāsakammaṃ kāretvā pavattā hoti, na yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā codetā hoti, na yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā kāretā hoti, na yathādiṭṭhiyā byākatā hoti—
pasayhapavattā.translation_1: (1) he speaks forcefully; (2) he speaks without having gotten permission; (3) he doesn’t accuse others according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, or their offense; (4) he doesn’t act according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, or his offenses; (5) he doesn’t explain things according to his own view.
pasayhapavattā.example_2: na pasayhapavattā hoti, okāsakammaṃ kāretvā pavattā hoti, yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā codetā hoti, yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā kāretā hoti, yathādiṭṭhiyā byākatā hoti—
pasayhapavattā.translation_2: (1) he doesn’t speak forcefully; (2) he doesn’t speak without having gotten permission; (3) he accuses others according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, and their offense; (4) he acts according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, and his offenses; (5) he explains things according to his own view.”

anokāsakammaṃ.meaning_2: act without permission; action without consent
anokāsakammaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'anokāsakammaṃ kāretvā pavattā hoti' translates to 'he speaks without having gotten permission,' indicating an improper act of proceeding without seeking or obtaining formal leave or consent, as opposed to the proper 'okāsakamma' which means making space or obtaining permission.
anokāsakammaṃ.example_1: pasayhapavattā hoti, anokāsakammaṃ kāretvā pavattā hoti, na yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā codetā hoti, na yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā kāretā hoti, na yathādiṭṭhiyā byākatā hoti—
anokāsakammaṃ.translation_1: (1) he speaks forcefully; (2) he speaks without having gotten permission; (3) he doesn’t accuse others according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, or their offense; (4) he doesn’t act according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, or his offenses; (5) he doesn’t explain things according to his own view.
anokāsakammaṃ.example_2: pasayhapavattā hoti, anokāsakammaṃ kāretvā pavattā hoti, na yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā codetā hoti, na yathādhamme yathāvinaye yathāpattiyā kāretā hoti, na yathādiṭṭhiyā byākatā hoti—
anokāsakammaṃ.translation_2: (1) he speaks forcefully; (2) he speaks without having gotten permission; (3) he doesn’t accuse others according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, or their offense; (4) he doesn’t act according to the Teaching, the Monastic Law, or his offenses; (5) he doesn’t explain things according to his own view.

yāyavaṇṇañca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound 'yāyavaṇṇañca' combines the instrumental singular of the relative pronoun 'yāya' (by which) with 'vaṇṇa' (sort, kind, or praise), linked by 'ca' (and). In the context of the sentence, it likely refers to committing an offense 'by which sort' or 'of what kind,' and 'praise' (or possibly 'caste' or 'quality'), suggesting a discussion of offenses categorized by type and their associated commendation or evaluation.

paṭhamayamakapaññatti.meaning_2: designation of the first pairs; concept of the first pairs
paṭhamayamakapaññatti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound noun refers to the 'designation' or 'concept' of the first pairs, as in the initial dyads or topics in the Yamaka treatise of the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, where 'pairs' (yamaka) are systematically analyzed.
paṭhamayamakapaññatti.translation_1: The first pairs have been laid down.

vohāravaggo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In this context, 'vohāravaggo' refers to the third subchapter (vagga) focused on speech (vohāra, meaning verbal expression or mode of communication), as indicated by the concluding sentence.
vohāravaggo.translation_1: The third subchapter on speech is finished.

adhikaraṇasamuṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: origination of the legal issue; arising of the dispute
adhikaraṇasamuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound refers specifically to the origin or cause from which a legal dispute (adhikaraṇa) arises, as contrasted with the issue itself, its application, resolution, and adjudication. The English translation 'origination of the legal issues' captures its use in the sentences, emphasizing knowledge or ignorance of how disputes come about.
adhikaraṇasamuṭṭhānaṃ.example_1: adhikaraṇaṃ na jānāti, adhikaraṇasamuṭṭhānaṃ na jānāti, adhikaraṇassa payogaṃ na jānāti, adhikaraṇassa vūpasamaṃ na jānāti, adhikaraṇassa na vinicchayakusalo hoti—
adhikaraṇasamuṭṭhānaṃ.translation_1: (1) he doesn’t know the legal issues; (2) he doesn’t know the origination of the legal issues; (3) he doesn’t know the kind of effort that is the source of the legal issues; (4) he doesn’t know the settling of legal issues; (5) he’s not skilled in deciding legal issues.
adhikaraṇasamuṭṭhānaṃ.example_2: adhikaraṇaṃ jānāti, adhikaraṇasamuṭṭhānaṃ jānāti, adhikaraṇassa payogaṃ jānāti, adhikaraṇassa vūpasamaṃ jānāti, adhikaraṇassa vinicchayakusalo hoti—
adhikaraṇasamuṭṭhānaṃ.translation_2: (1) he knows the legal issues; (2) he knows the origination of the legal issues; (3) he knows the kind of effort that is the source of the legal issues; (4) he knows the settling of legal issues; (5) he’s skilled in deciding legal issues.

padapaccābhaṭṭhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of Vinaya study, this compound refers to the proper grammatical sequence or arrangement of words in the canonical texts, essential for correct recitation and interpretation of the rules.
padapaccābhaṭṭhaṃ.example_1: vatthuṃ na jānāti, nidānaṃ na jānāti, paññattiṃ na jānāti, padapaccābhaṭṭhaṃ na jānāti, anusandhivacanapathaṃ na jānāti—
padapaccābhaṭṭhaṃ.translation_1: (1) he doesn’t know the actions that are the bases for offenses; (2) he doesn’t know the origin stories; (3) he doesn’t know the rules; (4) he doesn’t know the right order of words; (5) he doesn’t know the sequence of statements.
padapaccābhaṭṭhaṃ.example_2: vatthuṃ jānāti, nidānaṃ jānāti, paññattiṃ jānāti, padapaccābhaṭṭhaṃ jānāti, anusandhivacanapathaṃ jānāti—
padapaccābhaṭṭhaṃ.translation_2: (1) he knows the actions that are the bases for offenses; (2) he knows the origin stories; (3) he knows the rules; (4) he knows the right order of words; (5) he knows the sequence of statements.

vinayānulomaṃ.grammar: ind, adv, acc sg of vinayānuloma
vinayānulomaṃ.meaning_2: in accordance with the Monastic Law; conforming to the monastic discipline
vinayānulomaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'vinayānulomaṃ' refers to knowledge of actions or principles that align with the Vinaya, the monastic disciplinary code, distinguishing competent from incompetent monks in understanding appropriate conduct.
vinayānulomaṃ.example_1: suttaṃ na jānāti, suttānulomaṃ na jānāti, vinayaṃ na jānāti, vinayānulomaṃ na jānāti, na ca ṭhānāṭhānakusalo hoti—
vinayānulomaṃ.translation_1: (1) he doesn’t know the Monastic Code; (2) he doesn’t know what’s in accordance with the Monastic Code; (3) he doesn’t know the Monastic Law; (4) he doesn’t know what’s in accordance with the Monastic Law; (5) he’s not skilled in what is and is not possible.
vinayānulomaṃ.example_2: suttaṃ jānāti, suttānulomaṃ jānāti, vinayaṃ jānāti, vinayānulomaṃ jānāti, ṭhānāṭhānakusalo ca hoti—
vinayānulomaṃ.translation_2: (1) he knows the Monastic Code; (2) he knows what’s in accordance with the Monastic Code; (3) he knows the Monastic Law; (4) he knows what’s in accordance with the Monastic Law; (5) he’s skilled in what is and is not possible.

dhammānulomaṃ.grammar: ind, adv, acc sg of dhammānuloma
dhammānulomaṃ.meaning_2: what’s in accordance with the Teaching; in conformity with the doctrine
dhammānulomaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, dhammānulomaṃ refers to knowledge or understanding of matters, actions, or principles that align with or conform to the Buddha's Teaching (dhamma), as opposed to direct knowledge of the Teaching itself. The adverbial accusative form indicates 'that which follows the dhamma' or 'in accordance with the dhamma'.
dhammānulomaṃ.example_1: dhammaṃ na jānāti, dhammānulomaṃ na jānāti, vinayaṃ na jānāti, vinayānulomaṃ na jānāti, na ca pubbāparakusalo hoti—
dhammānulomaṃ.translation_1: (1) he doesn’t know the Teaching; (2) he doesn’t know what’s in accordance with the Teaching; (3) he doesn’t know the Monastic Law; (4) he doesn’t know what’s in accordance with the Monastic Law; (5) he’s not skilled in the right order.
dhammānulomaṃ.example_2: dhammaṃ jānāti, dhammānulomaṃ jānāti, vinayaṃ jānāti, vinayānulomaṃ jānāti, pubbāparakusalo ca hoti—
dhammānulomaṃ.translation_2: (1) he knows the Teaching; (2) he knows what’s in accordance with the Teaching; (3) he knows the Monastic Law; (4) he knows what’s in accordance with the Monastic Law; (5) he’s skilled in the right order.”

pasayhāpatti.grammar: fem, abstr, comp from pasayhā + āpatti
pasayhāpatti.meaning_2: forceful attainment of offenses; overcoming of transgressions
pasayhāpatti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'Forcefully, knowing offenses', pasayhāpatti refers to the act of forcefully attaining or overcoming offenses, likely in a disciplinary or meditative sense where one vigorously recognizes and conquers transgressions.

diṭṭhāvikammavaggo.meaning_2: chapter on revealing one's view; subchapter on voicing one's dissent
diṭṭhāvikammavaggo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'diṭṭhāvikammavaggo' refers to the title of the fourth subchapter in a Vinaya text, where 'diṭṭhāvikamma' denotes the act of openly expressing or revealing one's doctrinal view (diṭṭhi), often in dissent, and 'vaggo' specifies it as a chapter or section. The ending '-o' is the nominative singular form used for the title.
diṭṭhāvikammavaggo.translation_1: The fourth subchapter on revealing one’s view is finished.

apakatattassa.meaning_2: not regular; not a regular monk
apakatattassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'apakatattassa' refers to a monk who is not in good standing or suspended, contrasting with 'pakatatta' meaning a regular, unsuspended monk. The English translation 'someone who’s not a regular monk' captures this oppositional sense, implying irregularity in monastic status.
apakatattassa.example_1: nānāsaṃvāsakassa santike diṭṭhiṃ āvi karoti, nānāsīmāya ṭhitassa santike diṭṭhiṃ āvi karoti, apakatattassa santike diṭṭhiṃ āvi karoti, catūhi pañcahi diṭṭhiṃ āvi karoti, mano mānasena diṭṭhiṃ āvi karoti—
apakatattassa.translation_1: (1) one reveals a view to someone who belongs to a different Buddhist sect; (2) one reveals a view to someone in a different monastery zone; (3) one reveals a view to someone who’s not a regular monk; (4) one reveals a view to four or five people; (5) one reveals a view by mind.

vuṭṭhānādhippāyo.meaning_2: intention of clearing (offenses); purpose of rehabilitation; intention of rising above (offenses)
vuṭṭhānādhippāyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'vuṭṭhānādhippāyo' describes the positive intention of a monk who speaks to help another clear or rehabilitate from offenses, contrasting with the negative intention 'cāvanādhippāyo' aimed at causing disrobing. The compound combines 'vuṭṭhāna' (rehabilitation, rising up from offenses) with 'adhippāya' (intention), emphasizing restorative purpose in monastic discipline.
vuṭṭhānādhippāyo.example_1: alajjī ca hoti, bālo ca, apakatatto ca, cāvanādhippāyo vattā hoti, no vuṭṭhānādhippāyo—
vuṭṭhānādhippāyo.translation_1: (1) he’s shameless; (2) he’s ignorant; (3) he’s not a regular monk; (4) he speaks to make someone disrobe, (5) not with the aim of clearing their offenses.
vuṭṭhānādhippāyo.example_2: lajjī ca hoti, paṇḍito ca, pakatatto ca, vuṭṭhānādhippāyo vattā hoti, no cāvanādhippāyo—
vuṭṭhānādhippāyo.translation_2: (1) he has a sense of conscience; (2) he’s knowledgeable; (3) he’s a regular monk; (4) he speaks with the aim of clearing someone’s offense, (5) not to make them disrobe.”

sākacchitabboti.meaning_2: to be discussed; to be conversed with
sākacchitabboti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'sākacchitabbo' refers to a monk with whom the monastic law (vinayo) should or should not be discussed, depending on the sentence. It is the gerundive form indicating suitability for discussion, contrasting with 'na sākacchitabbo' meaning 'not to be discussed with'.
sākacchitabboti.example_1: “katihi nu kho, bhante, aṅgehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā saddhiṃ vinayo na sākacchitabbo”ti?
sākacchitabboti.translation_1: “What sort of monk should one not discuss the Monastic Law with?”
sākacchitabboti.example_2: imehi kho, upāli, pañcahaṅgehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā saddhiṃ vinayo sākacchitabbo”ti.

pañhāpucchāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'pañhāpucchā' is used as a compound noun referring to types or categories of questions and enquiries, as in 'imā kho, upāli, pañca pañhāpucchā' meaning 'these, Upāli, are five kinds of questions and enquiries'.
pañhāpucchāti.translation_1: “How many kinds of questions and enquiries are there?”

pañhāpucchā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'pañhāpucchā' is used as part of 'pañcimā pañhāpucchā', translated as 'There are five [questions/enquiries]', indicating a compound denoting types or aspects of questioning in a doctrinal or instructional discussion.

aññabyākaraṇāti.meaning_2: declaration of perfect insight; declaration of gnosis
aññabyākaraṇāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, aññabyākaraṇa refers to specific kinds (here, five) of declarations or elucidations concerning perfect insight (aññā) in Buddhist doctrine, likely related to stages of enlightenment or knowledge.
aññabyākaraṇāti.translation_1: “How many kinds of declaration of perfect insight are there?”

aññabyākaraṇā.meaning_2: declarations of perfect insight; explanations of gnosis; statements of spiritual knowledge
aññabyākaraṇā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya, aññabyākaraṇā refers to types of doctrinal explanations or declarations, here specifically 'declarations of perfect insight' as the first of five such categories enumerated to Upāli. The compound combines spiritual insight (aññā) with the act of declaring or making distinct (byākaraṇa), indicating elucidations that reveal higher knowledge.

paṭiggahānatirittā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound paṭiggahānatirittā is a descriptive adjective in the nominative singular masculine form, qualifying a subject in context to mean 'receiving, not left over,' indicating complete acceptance without remainder, as per the English gloss.

attādānavaggo.meaning_2: subchapter on self-initiated legal action; chapter on raising an issue
attādānavaggo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, attādānavaggo refers to a specific subchapter in a Vinaya text dealing with procedures where a monk initiates a legal action against himself, translated as 'raising an issue'. It is the fifth such subchapter, indicating its position in the organizational structure.
attādānavaggo.translation_1: The fifth subchapter on raising an issue is finished.

codakenupāli.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Vocative form of a sandhi compound addressing the monk Upāli, used as the addressee in the Buddha's discourse on qualities a bhikkhu should reflect on, establish, or attend to internally before admonishing another.
codakenupāli.example_1: “codakenupāli, bhikkhunā paraṃ codetukāmena pañca dhamme ajjhattaṃ paccavekkhitvā paro codetabbo.
codakenupāli.translation_1: “He should see five qualities in himself:
codakenupāli.example_2: codakenupāli, bhikkhunā paraṃ codetukāmena evaṃ paccavekkhitabbaṃ—

sampādayati.meaning_2: causes to succeed; accomplishes; brings about
sampādayati.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sampādayati is a present tense causative verb derived from the root √pad ('to go, proceed'), with the prefix sam- indicating completion or thoroughness. It denotes causing something to reach fruition or success, often used in contexts of achieving goals or fulfilling tasks.

hitesitā.meaning_2: being of benefit; seeking benefit; benevolence
hitesitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, hitesitā refers to the quality or state of seeking or desiring the welfare and benefit of others, parallel to compassion and sympathy as virtues of a teacher or guide in Buddhist training.
hitesitā.translation_1: compassion, being of benefit, sympathy, the idea of clearing offenses, and the idea of prioritizing the training.”

ādātukāmena.meaning_2: by one desiring to raise (an issue); by one wishing to take up (a matter)
ādātukāmena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'by one desiring to take up/raise'. In the Vinaya context, 'ādānaṃ ādātuṃ' refers to formally raising or proposing an issue in monastic procedure, not literal theft or grasping. The agent noun from ādāti ('raiser/taker') combines with the infinitive ādātuṃ, and kāma indicates desire or wish.
ādātukāmena.example_1: “attādānaṃ ādātukāmena, bhante, bhikkhunā katihaṅgehi samannāgataṃ attādānaṃ ādātabban”ti?
ādātukāmena.translation_1: “Sir, if a monk wishes to raise an issue, what factors should be fulfilled?”
ādātukāmena.example_2: attādānaṃ ādātukāmena, upāli, bhikkhunā evaṃ paccavekkhitabbaṃ—

ādātukāmenupāli.meaning_2: O Upāli who wishes to take
ādātukāmenupāli.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a vocative compound addressing Upāli, the monk, with 'ādātukāma' describing him as one desiring to take (self-giving). In context, it introduces instructions on how a monk should take self-giving fulfilling five factors.

panupāli.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given sentences, 'panupāli' functions as a conjunctive particle introducing a conditional clause, translated as 'But if he knows', combining the contrastive 'pana' with an emphatic or connective element 'u' derived from 'api' or 'anu'. The 'pāli' ending aligns with the pattern seen in dictionary entries for 'pāḷi', but here it is part of the adverbial construction rather than a proper noun.
panupāli.example_1: sace panupāli, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṃ jānāti—
panupāli.example_2: sace panupāli, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṃ jānāti—

tenupāli.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Vocative address used in the Vinaya context to instruct the monk Upāli, a prominent disciple expert in Vinaya, to reflect further on conditions for accepting a robe. The English translations omit the full address but imply the directive to the addressee.
tenupāli.example_1: ‘kālo imaṃ attādānaṃ ādātuṃ no akālo’ti, tenupāli, bhikkhunā uttari paccavekkhitabbaṃ—
tenupāli.translation_1: it’s the right time, he should reflect further
tenupāli.example_2: ‘bhūtaṃ idaṃ attādānaṃ no abhūtan’ti, tenupāli, bhikkhunā uttari paccavekkhitabbaṃ—
tenupāli.translation_2: it is, he should reflect further

avippaṭisārakaraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, it describes the action of raising the issue (attādānaṃ ādinnaṃ) as one that will not lead to future regret when the five factors are present.
avippaṭisārakaraṃ.example_1: evaṃ pañcaṅgasamannāgataṃ kho, upāli, attādānaṃ ādinnaṃ pacchāpi avippaṭisārakaraṃ bhavissatī”ti.
avippaṭisārakaraṃ.translation_1: In this way, when five factors are fulfilled, he won’t regret raising that issue.”

nānuyuñjitabbanti.meaning_2: should not be examined; should not be investigated
nānuyuñjitabbanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, the word refers to a monk who should not be subjected to examination or scrutiny, likely in a disciplinary or evaluative sense within the Vinaya tradition.
nānuyuñjitabbanti.example_1: “katihi nu kho, bhante, aṅgehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā nānuyuñjitabban”ti?
nānuyuñjitabbanti.translation_1: “Sir, what sort of monk shouldn’t be examined?”

nānuyuñjitabbaṃ.meaning_1: should not be examined; should not be investigated
nānuyuñjitabbaṃ.meaning_2: should not be examined; should not be investigated
nānuyuñjitabbaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya, this term refers to a monk possessing certain qualities who should not be subjected to formal examination or interrogation, particularly in disciplinary proceedings.
nānuyuñjitabbaṃ.example_2: imehi kho, upāli, pañcahaṅgehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā nānuyuñjitabbaṃ.

dhutaṅgavaggo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the contextual sentence, dhutaṅgavaggo refers to the title of the sixth subchapter in the text, which deals with ascetic practices (dhutaṅga), and vaggo indicates the chapter or section, marking its conclusion.
dhutaṅgavaggo.translation_1: The sixth subchapter on ascetic practices is finished.

piṇḍipaṃsu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of monastic practices, 'piṇḍipaṃsu' is a dvanda compound referring to two of the ascetic practices (dhutaṅga): living on almsfood (piṇḍi) and wearing robes made from dust-rags or discarded cloth (paṃsu). It appears as part of a list of such practices for a wilderness dweller.

rukkhasusānapañcamaṃ.meaning_2: tree, charnel ground is the fifth
rukkhasusānapañcamaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound listing 'tree' and 'charnel ground' as the fifth type of meditation site or contemplation object in the given context.
rukkhasusānapañcamaṃ.translation_1: Tree, charnel ground is the fifth;

tecīvarañceva.meaning_1: out in the open and the three robes
tecīvarañceva.meaning_2: the three robes and; the three robes as well
tecīvarañceva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a sandhi compound where 'tecīvara' (three robes) is combined with 'ca' (and) and 'eva' (even/as well), functioning as a single unit in the sentence. In context, it contrasts with 'abbho' (out in the open), indicating the permitted possessions for a monk in exposed conditions.
tecīvarañceva.translation_1: Out in the open, and the three robes,

sapadānanesajjikā.meaning_2: continuous, those who never lie down; those who remain upright without lying down successively
sapadānanesajjikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'sapadāna' (successive, methodical) with 'nesajjikā' (female upright sitter, one who does not lie down), indicating ascetics who maintain an upright posture continuously without interruption, as per the contextual meaning of never lying down.
sapadānanesajjikā.translation_1: Continuous, those who never lie down;

santhatekāsanañceva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound formed by santhata (nt, 'spread' or 'bed'), kāsanā (fem, 'seat' or 'sitting place', derived from kāsati 'to shine' but here denoting a seat), ca ('and'), and eva ('indeed'). In context, it refers to provisions like a bed and a seat for monks.

khalupacchā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, khalupacchā introduces a temporal clause meaning 'afterwards' or 'subsequently', specifying the time when those who eat only from the bowl do so, as translated 'After, those who eat only from the bowl.' The emphatic particle khalu strengthens the adverbial sense of pacchā.
khalupacchā.translation_1: After, those who eat only from the bowl.”

pārājikagāmī.meaning_2: leading to an offense entailing expulsion; heading to defeat
pārājikagāmī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound describes types of lying (musāvāda) that lead to specific penalties, with pārājikagāmī specifically indicating the most severe category resulting in expulsion from the Saṅgha.
pārājikagāmī.example_1: atthi musāvādo pārājikagāmī, atthi musāvādo saṅghādisesagāmī, atthi musāvādo thullaccayagāmī, atthi musāvādo pācittiyagāmī, atthi musāvādo dukkaṭagāmī—
pārājikagāmī.translation_1: (1) there’s lying that leads to an offense entailing expulsion; (2) there’s lying that leads to an offense entailing suspension; (3) there’s lying that leads to a serious offense; (4) there’s lying that leads to an offense entailing confession; (5) there’s lying that leads to an offense of wrong conduct.”

saṅghādisesagāmī.meaning_2: leading to an offense entailing suspension
saṅghādisesagāmī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, saṅghādisesagāmī describes a type of lying (musāvāda) that leads to a saṅghādisesa offense, which requires formal meeting of the monastic community for resolution, as opposed to expulsion (pārājika) or lesser penalties.
saṅghādisesagāmī.example_1: atthi musāvādo pārājikagāmī, atthi musāvādo saṅghādisesagāmī, atthi musāvādo thullaccayagāmī, atthi musāvādo pācittiyagāmī, atthi musāvādo dukkaṭagāmī—
saṅghādisesagāmī.translation_1: (1) there’s lying that leads to an offense entailing expulsion; (2) there’s lying that leads to an offense entailing suspension; (3) there’s lying that leads to a serious offense; (4) there’s lying that leads to an offense entailing confession; (5) there’s lying that leads to an offense of wrong conduct.”

thullaccayagāmī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound adjective categorizes lying that results in a thullaccaya offense, which is a grave but non-expulsion transgression, distinct from pārājika or saṅghādisesa.
thullaccayagāmī.example_1: atthi musāvādo pārājikagāmī, atthi musāvādo saṅghādisesagāmī, atthi musāvādo thullaccayagāmī, atthi musāvādo pācittiyagāmī, atthi musāvādo dukkaṭagāmī—
thullaccayagāmī.translation_1: (1) there’s lying that leads to an offense entailing expulsion; (2) there’s lying that leads to an offense entailing suspension; (3) there’s lying that leads to a serious offense; (4) there’s lying that leads to an offense entailing confession; (5) there’s lying that leads to an offense of wrong conduct.”

pācittiyagāmī.meaning_2: leading to an offense entailing confession
pācittiyagāmī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound adjective describes a type of lying (musāvāda) that leads to a pācittiya offense, which requires confession to another monk. The term parallels other classifications like pārājikagāmī, indicating the severity and consequence of the act.
pācittiyagāmī.example_1: atthi musāvādo pārājikagāmī, atthi musāvādo saṅghādisesagāmī, atthi musāvādo thullaccayagāmī, atthi musāvādo pācittiyagāmī, atthi musāvādo dukkaṭagāmī—
pācittiyagāmī.translation_1: (1) there’s lying that leads to an offense entailing expulsion; (2) there’s lying that leads to an offense entailing suspension; (3) there’s lying that leads to a serious offense; (4) there’s lying that leads to an offense entailing confession; (5) there’s lying that leads to an offense of wrong conduct.”

dukkaṭagāmī.meaning_2: leading to an offense of wrong conduct; heading to dukkaṭa
dukkaṭagāmī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, dukkaṭagāmī describes a type of lying that results in a dukkaṭa offense, the least severe category in the Vinaya, involving wrong-doing or a minor rule violation.
dukkaṭagāmī.example_1: atthi musāvādo pārājikagāmī, atthi musāvādo saṅghādisesagāmī, atthi musāvādo thullaccayagāmī, atthi musāvādo pācittiyagāmī, atthi musāvādo dukkaṭagāmī—
dukkaṭagāmī.translation_1: (1) there’s lying that leads to an offense entailing expulsion; (2) there’s lying that leads to an offense entailing suspension; (3) there’s lying that leads to a serious offense; (4) there’s lying that leads to an offense entailing confession; (5) there’s lying that leads to an offense of wrong conduct.”

sappaṭikammāpaṭikammaṃ.meaning_2: offenses that are clearable by making amends and the offenses that are not clearable by making amends
sappaṭikammāpaṭikammaṃ.construction: sa + pati + √kar + ma + a + pati + √kar + ma
sappaṭikammāpaṭikammaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a dvanda compound contrasting offenses amendable by making amends (sappaṭikammaṃ) with those not amendable (appaṭikammaṃ), used in the context of a monk's knowledge of disciplinary categories in the Vinaya.
sappaṭikammāpaṭikammaṃ.example_1: āpattānāpattiṃ na jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, sappaṭikammāpaṭikammaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti—
sappaṭikammāpaṭikammaṃ.translation_1: (1) he doesn’t know the offenses and non-offenses; (2) he doesn’t know the light and heavy offenses; (3) he doesn’t know the curable and incurable offenses; (4) he doesn’t know the grave and minor offenses; (5) he doesn’t know the offenses that are clearable by making amends and the offenses that are not clearable by making amends.
sappaṭikammāpaṭikammaṃ.example_2: āpattānāpattiṃ jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, sappaṭikammāpaṭikammaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti—
sappaṭikammāpaṭikammaṃ.translation_2: (1) he knows the offenses and non-offenses; (2) he knows the light and heavy offenses; (3) he knows the curable and incurable offenses; (4) he knows the grave and minor offenses; (5) he knows the offenses that are clearable by making amends and the offenses that are not clearable by making amends.”

pasuttakatā.grammar: nt, abstr, from pasu + ut + kata
pasuttakatā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, pasuttakatā refers to the state or condition of sleeping, explaining one reason for certain lapses or faults, parallel to not seeing or not hearing. The form is a compound abstract noun derived from pasut + ta ('having slept') + tā ('state of').
pasuttakatā.translation_1: because of not seeing; because of not hearing; because of sleeping; because of perceiving it as allowable; because of absentmindedness.”

bhikkhunovādavaggo.meaning_2: subchapter on instructing the nuns; section on the instruction of nuns
bhikkhunovādavaggo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'bhikkhunī' (nun) modifies 'ovādavagga' (section on instruction), specifying that the chapter pertains to instructions for nuns. In the concluding sentence, it denotes the eighth subchapter in a Vinaya text focused on monastic guidelines.
bhikkhunovādavaggo.translation_1: The eighth subchapter on instructing the nuns is finished.

paripūrikārī.grammar: masc, agent, in comps, from paripūrati + karoti
paripūrikārī.meaning_2: one who fulfills; one who completes; one who carries out fully
paripūrikārī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, paripūrikārī refers to someone who properly fulfills or adheres to the monastic training (sikkhā), in contrast to the negative qualities described. The English translation 'he doesn’t fulfill the training' negates this quality, implying the subject is not a paripūrikārī.
paripūrikārī.example_1: alajjī ca hoti, bālo ca, apakatatto ca, bhaṇḍanakārako ca hoti kalahakārako, sikkhāya ca na paripūrikārī—
paripūrikārī.translation_1: he’s shameless, ignorant, and not a regular monk, and he’s quarrelsome and argumentative, and he doesn’t fulfill the training.”

ubbāhikavaggo.meaning_2: section or chapter dealing with select committees or juries
ubbāhikavaggo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound 'ubbāhikavaggo' combines 'ubbāhikā' (select committee; jury) with 'vagga' (chapter; section), referring to a specific subchapter in the Vinaya text focused on matters involving committees or juries. In the concluding sentence, it denotes the ninth such chapter that has been completed.
ubbāhikavaggo.translation_1: The ninth subchapter on committees is finished.

makkhābhibhūto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, makkhābhibhūto describes a person who is denigrating and overwhelmed by the fault of denigration, contrasting with the positive state of being free from such faults.
makkhābhibhūto.example_1: kodhano hoti kodhābhibhūto, makkhī hoti makkhābhibhūto, paḷāsī hoti paḷāsābhibhūto, issukī hoti issābhibhūto, sandiṭṭhiparāmāsī hoti ādhānaggāhī duppaṭinissaggī—
makkhābhibhūto.translation_1: (1) he’s angry, overcome by anger; (2) he’s denigrating, overcome by denigration; (3) he’s domineering, overcome by being domineering; (4) he’s envious, overcome by envy; (5) he obstinately grasps his own views and only gives them up with difficulty.
makkhābhibhūto.example_2: na kodhano hoti na kodhābhibhūto, na makkhī hoti na makkhābhibhūto, na paḷāsī hoti na paḷāsābhibhūto, na issukī hoti na issābhibhūto, asandiṭṭhiparāmāsī hoti anādhānaggāhī suppaṭinissaggī—
makkhābhibhūto.translation_2: (1) he’s not angry or overcome by anger; (2) he’s not denigrating or overcome by denigration; (3) he’s not domineering or overcome by being domineering; (4) he’s not envious or overcome by envy; (5) he doesn’t obstinately grasp his own views and gives them up with ease.

paḷāsābhibhūto.meaning_2: overcome by domineering; overcome by contentiousness
paḷāsābhibhūto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, paḷāsābhibhūto describes a person who is domineering, being overcome by the quality of paḷāsa (contentiousness or rivalry), paralleling other states like being overcome by anger or envy.
paḷāsābhibhūto.example_1: kodhano hoti kodhābhibhūto, makkhī hoti makkhābhibhūto, paḷāsī hoti paḷāsābhibhūto, issukī hoti issābhibhūto, sandiṭṭhiparāmāsī hoti ādhānaggāhī duppaṭinissaggī—
paḷāsābhibhūto.translation_1: (1) he’s angry, overcome by anger; (2) he’s denigrating, overcome by denigration; (3) he’s domineering, overcome by being domineering; (4) he’s envious, overcome by envy; (5) he obstinately grasps his own views and only gives them up with difficulty.
paḷāsābhibhūto.example_2: na kodhano hoti na kodhābhibhūto, na makkhī hoti na makkhābhibhūto, na paḷāsī hoti na paḷāsābhibhūto, na issukī hoti na issābhibhūto, asandiṭṭhiparāmāsī hoti anādhānaggāhī suppaṭinissaggī—
paḷāsābhibhūto.translation_2: (1) he’s not angry or overcome by anger; (2) he’s not denigrating or overcome by denigration; (3) he’s not domineering or overcome by being domineering; (4) he’s not envious or overcome by envy; (5) he doesn’t obstinately grasp his own views and gives them up with ease.

issābhibhūto.meaning_2: overcome by envy; overwhelmed by jealousy
issābhibhūto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, issābhibhūto describes a person who is envious, specifically 'overcome by envy', paralleling the structure with other vices like anger and denigration where the agent is dominated by the negative quality.
issābhibhūto.example_1: kodhano hoti kodhābhibhūto, makkhī hoti makkhābhibhūto, paḷāsī hoti paḷāsābhibhūto, issukī hoti issābhibhūto, sandiṭṭhiparāmāsī hoti ādhānaggāhī duppaṭinissaggī—
issābhibhūto.translation_1: (1) he’s angry, overcome by anger; (2) he’s denigrating, overcome by denigration; (3) he’s domineering, overcome by being domineering; (4) he’s envious, overcome by envy; (5) he obstinately grasps his own views and only gives them up with difficulty.
issābhibhūto.example_2: na kodhano hoti na kodhābhibhūto, na makkhī hoti na makkhābhibhūto, na paḷāsī hoti na paḷāsābhibhūto, na issukī hoti na issābhibhūto, asandiṭṭhiparāmāsī hoti anādhānaggāhī suppaṭinissaggī—
issābhibhūto.translation_2: (1) he’s not angry or overcome by anger; (2) he’s not denigrating or overcome by denigration; (3) he’s not domineering or overcome by being domineering; (4) he’s not envious or overcome by envy; (5) he doesn’t obstinately grasp his own views and gives them up with ease.

akhamo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word akhamo is a masculine noun formed by the negative prefix a- (from na) added to khama 'patient, forbearing'. It denotes the opposite quality, used as an adjective or noun in contexts describing lack of patience or tolerance.

bālotveva.meaning_2: as if a fool; like an ignorant person
bālotveva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'bālotveva' describes a monk who is considered 'like a fool' or 'as if ignorant' due to possessing certain negative qualities. It combines 'bāla' (foolish/ignorant) with 'utu' (condition/state) and 'eva' (as if), forming an adverbial phrase emphasizing the state of ignorance.
bālotveva.example_1: “katihi nu kho, bhante, aṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu bālotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchatī”ti?
bālotveva.translation_1: “What sort of monk is considered ignorant?”
bālotveva.example_2: “pañcahupāli, aṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu bālotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.

ṭhānaṭhānakusalo.meaning_2: skilled in places and positions; expert in circumstances and situations
ṭhānaṭhānakusalo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a tatpuruṣa compound emphasizing expertise in both physical and abstract senses of 'ṭhāna' (place, reason, position), combined with 'kusala' indicating skill or proficiency. Likely used to describe someone adept at discerning appropriate contexts or stances in discourse or practice.

adhikaraṇavūpasamavaggo.meaning_2: subchapter on the resolving of legal issues
adhikaraṇavūpasamavaggo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as the title of the tenth subchapter in the Vinaya context, where adhikaraṇa refers to legal or disciplinary issues, vūpasama to their settling or resolution, and vagga to the chapter or section.
adhikaraṇavūpasamavaggo.translation_1: The tenth subchapter on the resolving of legal issues is finished.

puggalagaru.meaning_2: respecting individuals; giving weight to persons; esteeming people
puggalagaru.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'puggalagaru' contrasts with 'saṅghagaru', indicating a biased respect for individuals over the community, often due to personal attachments or fears.
puggalagaru.example_1: chandāgatiṃ gacchati, dosāgatiṃ gacchati, mohāgatiṃ gacchati, bhayāgatiṃ gacchati, puggalagaru hoti no saṅghagaru—
puggalagaru.translation_1: he’s biased by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear, and he respects individuals, not the Sangha.
puggalagaru.example_2: na chandāgatiṃ gacchati, na dosāgatiṃ gacchati, na mohāgatiṃ gacchati, na bhayāgatiṃ gacchati, saṅghagaru hoti no puggalagaru—
puggalagaru.translation_2: he’s not biased by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear, and he respects the Sangha, not individuals.

saṅghagaru.meaning_2: respecting the Sangha; giving weight to the community
saṅghagaru.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, saṅghagaru describes someone who values the monastic community over individuals, contrasting with puggalagaru.
saṅghagaru.example_1: chandāgatiṃ gacchati, dosāgatiṃ gacchati, mohāgatiṃ gacchati, bhayāgatiṃ gacchati, puggalagaru hoti no saṅghagaru—
saṅghagaru.translation_1: he’s biased by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear, and he respects individuals, not the Sangha.
saṅghagaru.example_2: na chandāgatiṃ gacchati, na dosāgatiṃ gacchati, na mohāgatiṃ gacchati, na bhayāgatiṃ gacchati, saṅghagaru hoti no puggalagaru—
saṅghagaru.translation_2: he’s not biased by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear, and he respects the Sangha, not individuals.

paññattetaṃ.meaning_2: this (rule) has been prescribed; this (conduct) has been decreed
paññattetaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'paññattetaṃ' refers to the specific rule or code of conduct that the Buddha has formulated and made known for various situations involving monks, such as proper conduct for newcomers, residents, dining, dwellings, and communal procedures.
paññattetaṃ.translation_1: “(1) Upāli, I’ve laid down the proper conduct for newly-arrived monks.
paññattetaṃ.example_2: paññattetaṃ, upāli, mayā āvāsikānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ āvāsikavattaṃ.
paññattetaṃ.translation_2: (2) I’ve laid down the proper conduct for resident monks.

āgantukavattaṃ.meaning_2: proper conduct; procedure for newly-arrived monks
āgantukavattaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, āgantukavattaṃ refers to the formal rule or customary procedure established by the Buddha for the conduct of newly-arrived monks, emphasizing monastic discipline.
āgantukavattaṃ.translation_1: “(1) Upāli, I’ve laid down the proper conduct for newly-arrived monks.

āgantukavatte.meaning_2: conduct for newcomers; proper procedure for newly-arrived monks
āgantukavatte.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, āgantukavatte refers to the specific code of conduct or procedural norms prescribed for newly-arrived monks (āgantukā bhikkhū), which they are not following despite the rules being well-established.
āgantukavatte.example_1: evaṃ supaññatte kho, upāli, mayā sikkhāpade āgantukā bhikkhū āgantukavatte na vattanti.
āgantukavatte.translation_1: Even though I’ve carefully laid down the training rules, the newly-arrived monks don’t practice that proper conduct.

āvāsikavattaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, āvāsikavattaṃ refers to the specific duties or behavioral guidelines established by the Buddha for monks residing in a particular place, as opposed to wandering monks.
āvāsikavattaṃ.example_1: paññattetaṃ, upāli, mayā āvāsikānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ āvāsikavattaṃ.
āvāsikavattaṃ.translation_1: (2) I’ve laid down the proper conduct for resident monks.

āvāsikavatte.meaning_2: proper conduct of resident monks; resident monks' practice
āvāsikavatte.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'āvāsikavatte' is the locative singular form referring to the proper conduct or practice expected of resident (āvāsika) monks, which they fail to observe despite the rules being well-established.
āvāsikavatte.example_1: evaṃ supaññatte kho, upāli, mayā sikkhāpade āvāsikā bhikkhū āvāsikavatte na vattanti.
āvāsikavatte.translation_1: Even though I’ve carefully laid down the training rules, the resident monks don’t practice that proper conduct.

bhattaggavattaṃ.meaning_2: proper conduct in the dining hall; procedure for monks at mealtime
bhattaggavattaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya, this compound refers to the formal rules or etiquette established by the Buddha for monks' behavior during meals in the refectory, emphasizing disciplined communal dining practices.
bhattaggavattaṃ.example_1: paññattetaṃ, upāli, mayā bhikkhūnaṃ bhattagge bhattaggavattaṃ—
bhattaggavattaṃ.translation_1: (3) I’ve laid down the proper conduct for monks in the dining hall:

yathārattaṃ.meaning_2: according to what is suitable; according to what is appropriate
yathārattaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, yathārattaṃ specifies that distributions like seats, water, and almsfood should be made in a manner befitting the recipient's status or role, complementing yathāvuḍḍhaṃ (by seniority) and yathāpatirūpaṃ (fittingly).
yathārattaṃ.example_1: yathāvuḍḍhaṃ yathārattaṃ yathāpatirūpaṃ aggāsanaṃ aggodakaṃ aggapiṇḍaṃ.
yathārattaṃ.translation_1: the best seat, the best water, and the best almsfood is to be given out according to seniority and according to what’s proper.
yathārattaṃ.translation_2: they’re to be given out according to seniority and according to what’s proper.

yathāpatirūpaṃ.meaning_2: according to what is suitable; according to what is proper; befittingly
yathāpatirūpaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'yathāpatirūpaṃ' describes the distribution of the best seat, water, and almsfood in a manner that is appropriate or befitting, likely considering factors like status or suitability beyond mere seniority.
yathāpatirūpaṃ.example_1: yathāvuḍḍhaṃ yathārattaṃ yathāpatirūpaṃ aggāsanaṃ aggodakaṃ aggapiṇḍaṃ.
yathāpatirūpaṃ.translation_1: the best seat, the best water, and the best almsfood is to be given out according to seniority and according to what’s proper.
yathāpatirūpaṃ.translation_2: they’re to be given out according to seniority and according to what’s proper.

senāsanavattaṃ.meaning_2: proper conduct regarding dwellings; duty in respect of lodgings
senāsanavattaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, it refers to the rules or proper behavior established by the Buddha for monks concerning the use and management of their living quarters (senāsana), emphasizing monastic discipline in communal living.
senāsanavattaṃ.example_1: paññattetaṃ, upāli, mayā bhikkhūnaṃ senāsane senāsanavattaṃ—
senāsanavattaṃ.translation_1: (4) I’ve laid down the proper conduct for the monks in regard to dwellings:

kammākammaṃ.meaning_2: (vinaya) joint legal procedure; legal procedure of whatever kind
kammākammaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya sentence, 'kammākammaṃ' refers to a joint or shared legal procedure of any type, parallel to the specific Sangha procedures mentioned earlier, emphasizing unity within the monastery zone.
kammākammaṃ.example_1: paññattetaṃ, upāli, mayā bhikkhūnaṃ antosīmāya ekaṃ uposathaṃ ekaṃ pavāraṇaṃ ekaṃ saṅghakammaṃ ekaṃ kammākammaṃ.
kammākammaṃ.translation_1: (5) For monks within the same monastery zone, I’ve laid down this: a joint observance-day ceremony; a joint invitation ceremony; joint legal procedures of the Sangha; joint legal procedures of whatever kind.

āvenibhāvaṃ.grammar: masc, abstr, in comps, from āveni + bhāva
āvenibhāvaṃ.meaning_2: state of being separate; condition of autonomy; separateness
āvenibhāvaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, āvenibhāvaṃ describes the state or condition of forming a separate faction within the monastery, leading to independent performance of communal rites like uposatha and pavāraṇā, emphasizing schism or autonomy in monastic procedures.
āvenibhāvaṃ.example_1: evaṃ supaññatte kho, upāli, mayā sikkhāpade tattheva antosīmāya āvenibhāvaṃ karitvā gaṇaṃ bandhitvā āveniṃ uposathaṃ karonti āveniṃ pavāraṇaṃ karonti āveniṃ saṅghakammaṃ karonti āveniṃ kammākammāni karonti.
āvenibhāvaṃ.translation_1: Even though I’ve carefully laid down the training rules, they form a faction, a subgroup, right there within the monastery zone. They then do a separate observance-day ceremony, a separate invitation ceremony, separate legal procedures of the Sangha, or separate legal procedures of whatever kind.

kammākammāni.meaning_2: separate legal procedures; procedures of whatever kind
kammākammāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'kammākammāni' refers to unauthorized or separate formal procedures carried out by a factional group, contrasting with official saṅghakamma. The form is the nominative plural of a neuter compound kammākamma, where 'ā' indicates 'pertaining to' or 'of the kind of'.
kammākammāni.example_1: evaṃ supaññatte kho, upāli, mayā sikkhāpade tattheva antosīmāya āvenibhāvaṃ karitvā gaṇaṃ bandhitvā āveniṃ uposathaṃ karonti āveniṃ pavāraṇaṃ karonti āveniṃ saṅghakammaṃ karonti āveniṃ kammākammāni karonti.
kammākammāni.translation_1: Even though I’ve carefully laid down the training rules, they form a faction, a subgroup, right there within the monastery zone. They then do a separate observance-day ceremony, a separate invitation ceremony, separate legal procedures of the Sangha, or separate legal procedures of whatever kind.

saṅghabhedakavaggo.meaning_2: subchapter on schism in the Sangha
saṅghabhedakavaggo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as the title of the eleventh subchapter in a Vinaya text, where 'vaggo' specifically denotes a section or chapter, and the entire phrase indicates the content dealing with schism in the monastic community.
saṅghabhedakavaggo.translation_1: The eleventh subchapter on schism in the Sangha is finished.

voharena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'voharena' is the instrumental singular form meaning 'while he speaks' or 'by means of speaking', parallel to 'uddese' indicating 'during recitation'. It refers to the act of verbal expression or discourse.
voharena.translation_1: During the recitation, and while he speaks;
voharena.translation_2: During the recitation, and while he speaks;
