diṭṭhinissitā.meaning_2: dependent on view; based on belief; relying on opinion
diṭṭhinissitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'pañcete diṭṭhinissitā', this adjective describes five (likely fetters or views) as being dependent on or conditioned by diṭṭhi (view), a key concept in Buddhist doctrine referring to speculative or doctrinal views that influence attachment.
diṭṭhinissitā.translation_1: These five are dependent on view;
diṭṭhinissitā.translation_2: These five are dependent on view;

dutiyasaṅghabhedakavaggo.meaning_2: the second subchapter on schism in the Sangha
dutiyasaṅghabhedakavaggo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a title for the subchapter. It describes the twelfth section in the text, specified as the second one dealing with schism (saṅghabhedaka) in the monastic community.
dutiyasaṅghabhedakavaggo.translation_1: The twelfth subchapter, the second on schism in the Sangha, is finished.

avinidhāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'avinidhāya diṭṭhiṃ' means 'not misrepresenting his view', where diṭṭhiṃ is the accusative object of the gerund, indicating the absence of false assertion during specific monastic procedures like legal acts (kammena), recitation (uddesena), etc. The negative prefix 'a-' negates the action of vinidhāya, thus expressing that the monk does not pervert or misstate his doctrinal position in these contexts.
avinidhāya.example_1: idhupāli, bhikkhu adhammaṃ dhammoti dīpeti, dhammaṃ adhammoti dīpeti, avinayaṃ vinayoti dīpeti, vinayaṃ avinayoti dīpeti, avinidhāya diṭṭhiṃ kammena—
avinidhāya.translation_1: (1) a monk proclaims what’s contrary to the Teaching as being in accordance with it, (2) what’s in accordance with the Teaching as contrary to it, (3) what’s contrary to the Monastic Law as being in accordance with it, (4) what’s in accordance with the Monastic Law as contrary to it, but (5) he doesn’t misrepresent his view of what’s true during the legal procedure.
avinidhāya.example_2: idhupāli, bhikkhu adhammaṃ dhammoti dīpeti, dhammaṃ adhammoti dīpeti, avinayaṃ vinayoti dīpeti, vinayaṃ avinayoti dīpeti, avinidhāya diṭṭhiṃ uddesena—
avinidhāya.translation_2: (1) a monk proclaims what’s contrary to the Teaching as being in accordance with it, (2) what’s in accordance with the Teaching as contrary to it, (3) what’s contrary to the Monastic Law as being in accordance with it, (4) what’s in accordance with the Monastic Law as contrary to it, but (5) he doesn’t misrepresent his view of what’s true during the recitation.

samavīsati.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'samavīsati' is used adverbially to indicate the total number of ways or methods (vidhī), meaning 'in twenty ways' or 'altogether twenty', with 'sama' reinforcing the sense of totality.

puggalikaparibhogena.meaning_2: manner of personal use; individual enjoyment
puggalikaparibhogena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This instrumental form describes the improper manner of using communal Sangha property as if it were for personal or individual consumption, contrasting virtuous conduct in the monastic context.
puggalikaparibhogena.example_1: chandāgatiṃ gacchati, dosāgatiṃ gacchati, mohāgatiṃ gacchati, bhayāgatiṃ gacchati, saṅghikaṃ puggalikaparibhogena paribhuñjati—
puggalikaparibhogena.translation_1: he’s biased by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear, and he uses what belongs to the Sangha as if belonging to an individual.
puggalikaparibhogena.example_2: na chandāgatiṃ gacchati, na dosāgatiṃ gacchati, na mohāgatiṃ gacchati, na bhayāgatiṃ gacchati, saṅghikaṃ na puggalikaparibhogena paribhuñjati—
puggalikaparibhogena.translation_2: he’s not biased by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear, and he doesn’t use what belongs to the Sangha as if belonging to an individual.”

vinayabyākaraṇāti.meaning_2: explanation of the Monastic Law; commentary on the Vinaya
vinayabyākaraṇāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given sentences, 'vinayabyākaraṇā' is the instrumental plural form, used to refer to explanations or commentaries on the Vinaya (monastic discipline). The first sentence inquires about the number of adhammikā (illegitimate) ones, while the second states there are five dhammikā (legitimate) ones.
vinayabyākaraṇāti.translation_1: “How many illegitimate explanations of the Monastic Law are there?”
vinayabyākaraṇāti.example_2: ime kho, upāli, pañca dhammikā vinayabyākaraṇā”ti.

vinayabyākaraṇā.meaning_2: explanation of the Monastic Law; commentary on the disciplinary rules
vinayabyākaraṇā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, vinayabyākaraṇā refers to explanations or commentaries on the Vinaya (monastic discipline/law). The sentences distinguish between adhammikā (illegitimate/unjust) and dhammikā (legitimate/just) types, with five of each.
vinayabyākaraṇā.example_2: ime kho, upāli, pañca adhammikā vinayabyākaraṇā.

āvāsikabyākaraṇā.meaning_2: explanations for residents; monastic residents' grammar
āvāsikabyākaraṇā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in context to denote explanations or grammatical treatises pertaining to residents, likely monastic residents in a Vinaya context.

bhattusenāsanāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form bhattusenāsanāni is the neuter nominative/accusative plural of the compound bhattusenāsana, where bhatta refers to 'meals' or provisions (derived from √bhaj, sharing/eating), and senāsana means 'dwellings' or lodgings. In the Vinaya context, it designates monastic requisites for food and shelter.

bhaṇḍacīvaraggāho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound denotes a monastic official responsible for storing goods and receiving donated robe-cloth, as per the Vinaya context. The final -o reflects the nominative singular form used in the listing of duties or roles.

appasāṭiyagāhako.meaning_2: minor requisites; distributor of rainy-season bathing cloths
appasāṭiyagāhako.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound refers to an official responsible for distributing minor requisites, specifically the light cloths used for bathing during the rainy season when full bathing is restricted.
appasāṭiyagāhako.translation_1: Minor requisites, distributor of rainy-season bathing cloths;

kathinatthāravaggo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound kathinatthāravaggo denotes the title of the fourteenth subchapter in the Vinaya text, where 'kathina' refers to the robe-making ceremony period, 'atthāra' to the spreading out or procedure, and 'vagga' to the chapter or section. The sentence indicates its conclusion.
kathinatthāravaggo.translation_1: The fourteenth subchapter on the robe-making ceremony is finished.

kathinatthāreti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound kathinatthāra refers to the ceremony of offering or preparing the robe (kaṭhina robe) in the Buddhist monastic context, as indicated by the question about its benefits (ānisaṃsā) in the sentences provided.
kathinatthāreti.translation_1: “Sir, how many benefits are there in participating in the robe-making ceremony?”
kathinatthāreti.example_2: ime kho, upāli, pañca ānisaṃsā kathinatthāre”ti.

racchagato.meaning_2: walking along a street; one who's walking along a street
racchagato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'racchagata' describes a person walking along a street (racchā, 'road'), who is not to be greeted (avandiyo). It functions as an adjective modifying an implied masculine noun, equivalent to 'street-walker' or 'one on the road'.
racchagato.example_1: antaragharaṃ paviṭṭho avandiyo, racchagato avandiyo, otamasiko avandiyo, asamannāharanto avandiyo, sutto avandiyo—
racchagato.translation_1: one who has entered an inhabited area; one who’s walking along a street; one who’s in the dark; one who’s not paying attention; one who’s asleep.

otamasiko.meaning_2: one who is in the dark; one who is heedless in darkness
otamasiko.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'otamasiko' refers to a person situated in darkness, explaining why they cannot be blamed for not showing respect, as they are unaware due to lack of light.
otamasiko.example_1: antaragharaṃ paviṭṭho avandiyo, racchagato avandiyo, otamasiko avandiyo, asamannāharanto avandiyo, sutto avandiyo—
otamasiko.translation_1: one who has entered an inhabited area; one who’s walking along a street; one who’s in the dark; one who’s not paying attention; one who’s asleep.

asamannāharanto.meaning_2: not paying attention; not being mindful
asamannāharanto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'asamannāharanto' describes a monk who is not attentive or mindful, leading to liability for offenses even in situations like sleep or darkness. The compound breaks down as 'a-sam-anna-hara-nta', where 'samannāharati' means 'to bring together' or 'to attend to', negated to indicate negligence.
asamannāharanto.example_1: antaragharaṃ paviṭṭho avandiyo, racchagato avandiyo, otamasiko avandiyo, asamannāharanto avandiyo, sutto avandiyo—
asamannāharanto.translation_1: one who has entered an inhabited area; one who’s walking along a street; one who’s in the dark; one who’s not paying attention; one who’s asleep.

ekāvatto.meaning_1: turned away; turned to one side
ekāvatto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, ekāvatto describes a monk whose attention has turned away from the meal or the proceedings, making him ineligible for certain actions like receiving food.
ekāvatto.example_1: yāgupāne avandiyo, bhattagge avandiyo, ekāvatto avandiyo, aññavihito avandiyo, naggo avandiyo—
ekāvatto.translation_1: one who’s drinking congee; one who’s in the dining hall; one who has turned away; one who’s preoccupied with something else; one who’s naked.

navakatarenupāli.meaning_2: O Upāli, who is more junior
navakatarenupāli.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Vocative form addressing Upāli as a younger monk in the monastic hierarchy, used in the context of instructions for paying respect to a senior monk by bowing at the feet after establishing five internal qualities.
navakatarenupāli.example_1: “navakatarenupāli, bhikkhunā vuḍḍhatarassa bhikkhuno pāde vandantena pañca dhamme ajjhattaṃ upaṭṭhāpetvā pādā vanditabbā.
navakatarenupāli.translation_1: “He should set up five qualities in himself:
navakatarenupāli.example_2: navakatarenupāli, bhikkhunā vuḍḍhatarassa bhikkhuno pāde vandantena ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā, añjaliṃ paggahetvā, ubhohi pāṇitalehi pādāni parisambāhantena, pemañca gāravañca upaṭṭhāpetvā pādā vanditabbā—
navakatarenupāli.translation_2: (1) he should arrange his upper robe over one shoulder; (2) he should raise his joined palms; (3) he should stroke the feet with the palms of both hands; (4) he should set up a sense of affection; (5) he should set up a sense of respect.”

parisambāhantena.meaning_2: stroking all over; caressing completely; rubbing every part
parisambāhantena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, this instrumental form describes the act of a junior monk reverentially stroking or massaging the feet of a senior monk with both palms, as part of the ritual of respect and affection.
parisambāhantena.example_1: navakatarenupāli, bhikkhunā vuḍḍhatarassa bhikkhuno pāde vandantena ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā, añjaliṃ paggahetvā, ubhohi pāṇitalehi pādāni parisambāhantena, pemañca gāravañca upaṭṭhāpetvā pādā vanditabbā—
parisambāhantena.translation_1: (1) he should arrange his upper robe over one shoulder; (2) he should raise his joined palms; (3) he should stroke the feet with the palms of both hands; (4) he should set up a sense of affection; (5) he should set up a sense of respect.”

kathinatthāraniddā.meaning_2: the robe-making ceremony, and asleep; the ceremony of spreading out the robe material, and sleep
kathinatthāraniddā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound connecting 'kathinatthāra' (the robe-making ceremony, lit. 'spreading out of the robe material') with 'niddā' (sleep). In the Vinaya context, 'kathinatthāra' refers to the formal ceremony for preparing monks' robes, juxtaposed here with 'niddā' to indicate prohibitions or regulations during that time and while sleeping.

yāgukhādane.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the locative singular form 'yāgukhādan'e, used in the context of 'antarā yāgukhādan'e' to indicate 'when eating congee' or 'while eating rice gruel', contrasting with fresh or raw food as per the English gloss. The compound combines 'yāgu' (rice gruel) with 'khādana' (eating, food), specifying the act or type of food consumption.
yāgukhādane.translation_1: Inhabited, congee, when eating fresh food;

pārivāsi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'pārivāsi' refers to a monk or nun undergoing a probationary period, typically for confession of offenses, as indicated by the sentence 'pure ca pārivāsi ca' meaning 'and before, and one on probation'.
pārivāsi.translation_1: And before, and one on probation,

vanditabbakanti.meaning_2: to be paid respect; to be honoured; to be saluted
vanditabbakanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form vanditabbakanti is an inflected form of vanditabba with the enclitic -ka (emphatic or demonstrative particle) followed by iti ('thus'), as seen in the sentence. In context, it denotes the obligation or propriety of paying respect, explaining the gerundive sense in 'should pay respect to, to be paid respect'.
vanditabbakanti.translation_1: Should pay respect to, to be paid respect.”

vohārāvikammena.meaning_2: by revealing through speech; by disclosure in verbal expression
vohārāvikammena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is instrumental singular of the compound vohārāvikamma, used in the context of speech (vohāra) combined with revealing or disclosure (āvikamma), likely referring to verbal actions that expose or reveal in a Buddhist disciplinary or communicative sense.

ubbāhikādhikaraṇaṃ.meaning_2: legal issue handled by a committee; disciplinary case before a select committee or jury
ubbāhikādhikaraṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound refers to a legal or disciplinary matter adjudicated by a special committee (ubbāhikā), akin to a jury or select panel, as suggested by the English translation 'Committee, legal issue'.

atthāpattisamuṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: origination of offenses for the sake of purpose; arising of faults due to goal or benefit
atthāpattisamuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'attha' (purpose, benefit) modifies 'āpattisamuṭṭhāna' (origination of offenses), indicating offenses arising for a specific purpose or benefit, likely in a Vinaya context discussing causes of monastic faults.

pārājikādi.meaning_2: offenses entailing expulsion, etc.; defeats and so forth
pārājikādi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound refers to the four pārājika offenses (defeats requiring expulsion) and the subsequent categories of monastic rules, such as saṅghādisesa, etc., as listed in the Pāṭimokkha.

acittakusalā.meaning_2: unintentional wholesome action; wholesome without mind or intention
acittakusalā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'acittakusalā' describes a type of action or state that is wholesome (kusala) yet unintentional or without conscious mind (acitta), likely referring to karmic or ethical categories in Pāḷi texts where intention plays a key role in determining wholesomeness.

dutiyagāthāsaṅgaṇikaṃ.meaning_2: verses on offenses, training rules, and legal procedures
dutiyagāthāsaṅgaṇikaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun in the neuter accusative singular, serving as the object of 'niṭṭhitaṃ' (finished). It refers to the second section of the text that compiles verses (gāthā) related to offenses (āpatti), training rules (sikkhāpada), and legal procedures (adhikaraṇa), completing the coverage of these topics in the Vinaya.
dutiyagāthāsaṅgaṇikaṃ.translation_1: The verses on offenses, training rules, and legal procedures are finished.

kāyikādiāpatti.meaning_2: offenses by body, etc.; offenses beginning with those of the body
kāyikādiāpatti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in the Vinaya context, referring to offenses categorized by body (kāyika), speech (vācīka), and mind (manosaṃceta), with 'ādi' indicating 'beginning with' or 'etc.'

saṃsaggapaccayā.meaning_2: supporting condition due to contact; requisite because of association
saṃsaggapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'saṃsaggapaccayā' functions as an ablative form denoting 'because of contact' or 'due to the condition of association,' referring to one of the categories of conditional relations in Buddhist doctrine, specifically five such conditions arising from mingling or intimacy.

chāpattiyo.meaning_2: kinds of offenses; types of transgressions
chāpattiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'chāpattiyo kāyikā' refers to the six categories of bodily offenses, forming a compound where 'cha' specifies the number and 'āpatti' the base meaning of offense.
chāpattiyo.translation_1: There are six kinds of offenses by body,

katettha.meaning_2: how many here?; how many in this case?
katettha.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'katettha' functions as an interrogative adverbial phrase meaning 'how many here?' or 'how many in this case?', used to inquire about the number of items or categories in the present discussion or rule, as seen in questions about parts, offenses, and groups.
katettha.translation_1: How many here have eight parts?
katettha.translation_2: How many here do not to require amends,

sabbasaṅgaho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'sabbasaṅgaho' refers to the comprehensive inclusion or grouping of all elements through a single means, as in 'They are all included through one.' This compound combines 'sabba' (all) with 'saṅgaha' (inclusion, holding together), emphasizing totality in categorization or support.
sabbasaṅgaho.translation_1: Through how many are they all included?
sabbasaṅgaho.translation_2: They are all included through one.

ekettha.meaning_2: here; in this case; in this instance
ekettha.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The adverb 'ekettha' is a compound of 'eka' (one, a certain) and 'ittha' (here), used to refer to a specific instance or case in the context of Vinaya classifications, as seen in phrases like 'ekettha aṭṭha vatthukā' meaning 'one here has eight parts,' distinguishing particular types or scenarios.
ekettha.translation_2: One here does not require amends,

vinayagarukā.meaning_2: heavy in the Monastic Law; grave offenses in the monastic code
vinayagarukā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term 'vinayagarukā' refers to serious or grave matters within the Vinaya, the monastic disciplinary code. In the given sentences, it is used to denote two such heavy cases, as in the question-and-answer format typical of Pāḷi texts.
vinayagarukā.translation_1: How many are said to be heavy in the Monastic Law?
vinayagarukā.translation_2: Two are said to be heavy in the Monastic Law,

duṭṭhullacchādanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya, duṭṭhullacchādanā refers to the act of concealing serious offenses, categorized into two kinds as per the sentences provided.
duṭṭhullacchādanā.translation_1: How many kinds of concealing are there of grave offenses?
duṭṭhullacchādanā.translation_2: There are two kinds of concealing of grave offenses.

nadipārapaccayā.grammar: ind, adv, abl sg of nadipārapaccaya
nadipārapaccayā.meaning_2: because of crossing a river; on account of crossing a river
nadipārapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This adverbial form is used in Vinaya contexts to denote one of the four reasons or necessities related to crossing a river, such as for alms, teaching, or other monastic duties.
nadipārapaccayā.translation_1: How many because of crossing a river?
nadipārapaccayā.translation_2: Four because of crossing a river;

katimaṃsesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] katimaṃsesu is a locative plural form of the compound 'katimaṃsa', meaning 'in how many meats' or 'in relation to meats', used interrogatively in Vinaya contexts to ask about the number of offenses associated with meat consumption or handling.
katimaṃsesu.translation_1: How many serious offenses are there in relation to meat?
katimaṃsesu.translation_2: How many offenses of wrong conduct are there in relation to meat?

ekamaṃse.meaning_2: in relation to one (matter) of meat; regarding a single aspect of flesh
ekamaṃse.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'ekamaṃse' functions as a locative singular of the compound 'ekamaṃsa', meaning 'in one (matter) of meat', referring to a single serious offense related to meat in the Vinaya.
ekamaṃse.translation_1: There is one serious offense in relation to meat,

navamaṃsesu.meaning_2: offense; case of wrong conduct; violation
navamaṃsesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In this Vinaya context, 'navamaṃsesu' is the locative plural of 'navamaṃsa', a compound denoting one of the nine specific offenses or cases of dukkaṭa (wrong conduct), likely referring to rules or violations applicable to monastic discipline.
navamaṃsesu.translation_1: And nine offenses of wrong conduct.

desanāgāminiyādiāpatti.meaning_2: offenses that are clearable by confession, etc.
desanāgāminiyādiāpatti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun used in Vinaya context to refer to categories of offenses, starting with those requiring confession (desanāgāminī) and extending to others (ādi), all as types of transgressions (āpatti).
desanāgāminiyādiāpatti.translation_1: 2. Offenses that are clearable by confession, etc.

kāyavācasikāni.meaning_2: done by body or speech; pertaining to body or speech
kāyavācasikāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'kāyavācasikāni ca' functions as a neuter plural noun agreeing with an implied subject (e.g., kamma or similar), translated as 'and done by body or speech' or 'and are done by body or speech', indicating actions or processes involving physical and verbal aspects.
kāyavācasikāni.translation_1: And done by body or speech?
kāyavācasikāni.translation_2: And are done by body or speech;

dhaññaraso.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'dhaññaraso' refers to a juice or extract derived from grains, discussed in terms of allowability for monks at inappropriate times (vikāle), likely as a fermented or nutrient-rich liquid akin to a beverage or medicine.
dhaññaraso.translation_1: How many grain juices are allowable at the wrong time?
dhaññaraso.translation_2: One grain juice is allowable at the wrong time,

saṃvāsakabhūmiyo.meaning_2: grounds for belonging to the same Buddhist sect
saṃvāsakabhūmiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, saṃvāsakabhūmiyo refers to the foundational bases or conditions (bhūmi) for co-residing or associating within the same monastic community (saṃvāsaka), specifically two such grounds in Buddhist Vinaya.
saṃvāsakabhūmiyo.translation_1: How many grounds are there for belonging to the same Buddhist sect?
saṃvāsakabhūmiyo.translation_2: There are two grounds for belonging to the same Buddhist sect;

dvettha.meaning_2: two; a pair of immediate offenses
dvettha.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'dvettha paṭhamāpattikā', 'dvettha' is a sandhi form of 'dve ettha', where 'dve' indicates two immediate offenses ('paṭhamāpattikā'), matching the English translation.

methunapaccayā.grammar: ind, adv, in comps, abl sg of methunapaccaya
methunapaccayā.meaning_2: dependent on sexual intercourse; due to sexual intercourse; caused by sexual intercourse
methunapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'methunapaccayā' functions as an adverbial phrase indicating causality related to sexual intercourse, specifically in a Vinaya enumeration of four such conditions or causes.
methunapaccayā.translation_1: How many because of sexual intercourse?

bhikkhunovādakavaggasmiṃ.meaning_2: in the subchapter on the instructor of nuns
bhikkhunovādakavaggasmiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form bhikkhunovādakavaggasmiṃ is the locative singular of the compound noun bhikkhunovādakavagga, used to indicate location within a textual section. Here, it denotes the specific subchapter in the Vinaya Piṭaka dealing with the role and instructions for the bhikkhunovādaka, the monk appointed as instructor or exhorter for the nuns' community. The compound combines bhikkhunovādaka (instructor of nuns) with vagga (chapter or section), functioning as a title for this organizational unit.
bhikkhunovādakavaggasmiṃ.translation_1: In the subchapter on the instructor of nuns,
bhikkhunovādakavaggasmiṃ.translation_2: In the subchapter on the instructor of nuns,

caturettha.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence, 'caturettha' functions adverbially to indicate the fourth item or section in a list, as in 'four groups of nine are mentioned there', where 'there' refers to the previously mentioned context.
caturettha.translation_1: Four groups of nine are mentioned there,

pāṭidesaniyā.meaning_2: confession (of an offence); act of confessing
pāṭidesaniyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, pāṭidesaniyā refers to an offence requiring confession by the nuns, as indicated by the question 'Have been declared to the nuns?'
pāṭidesaniyā.translation_1: Have been declared to the nuns?

bhuñjantāmakadhaññena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the compound bhuñjantāmakadhañña, used in a genitive sense to indicate 'for a person who eats raw grain', likely referring to an ascetic or monk in a Vinaya context subsisting on uncooked grains.

nānāvatthukāni.meaning_2: all with different bases; all with different bases for the offense
nānāvatthukāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'nānāvatthukāni' describes rules or offenses that have distinct foundational cases or bases, indicating variety in the underlying circumstances for each rule.

vohārapaccayā.meaning_2: verbal condition; condition based on speech; grammatical condition due to usage
vohārapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'vohārapaccayā' is an ablative form meaning 'because of verbal condition' or 'due to speech,' referring to six specific conditions or requisites in Pāḷi grammar or doctrine that arise from verbal expression or usage.
vohārapaccayā.translation_1: How many are there because of speech?

bhojanapaccayā.meaning_2: because of food; due to cooked food; on account of nourishment
bhojanapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'bhojanapaccayā' functions adverbially to indicate the basis or cause related to food, as in 'how many because of cooked food' and 'five because of cooked food', likely referring to requisites or conditions dependent on food in monastic or doctrinal enumeration.
bhojanapaccayā.translation_1: And how many because of cooked food?

katinañceva.meaning_2: and for how many?; and in how many cases?
katinañceva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial phrase combining the interrogative 'kati' (how many) with 'na' (instrumental of 'idam', indicating 'for' or 'in'), connected by 'ca eva' (and indeed). In the Vinaya context, it introduces questions about the number of cases for offenses, non-offenses, or inapplicability of rules, emphasizing enumeration.
katinañceva.translation_1: And for how many are there offenses?
katinañceva.translation_2: For how many are there non-offenses?

pañcannañceva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an emphatic indeclinable expression formed by sandhi of the genitive plural 'pañcannaṃ' (of five) + 'ca' (and) + 'eva' (only), functioning adverbially to emphasize 'only five' in the context of offenses or non-offenses.
pañcannañceva.translation_1: And there are offenses for five,

piṇḍapātapaccayā.meaning_2: dependent on almsfood; due to almsfood; caused by almsfood
piṇḍapātapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'piṇḍapātapaccayā' functions as an adverbial phrase indicating dependency on almsfood, likely in a technical sense such as a supporting condition or requisite in Buddhist doctrine, e.g., counting the number of such dependencies.

kataṅgiko.meaning_2: consisting of how many factors?; composed of how many parts?
kataṅgiko.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'kataṅgiko musāvādo', it functions as a predicate adjective modifying 'musāvādo' (lying), inquiring about the number of factors involved in the act of lying, likely in a doctrinal context such as the Vinaya or Abhidhamma.
kataṅgiko.translation_1: How many factors does lying have?

titthiyavattanā.meaning_2: proper conduct for monastics of other religions; observance of rules by heretics
titthiyavattanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'titthiyavattanā' refers to the ethical or disciplinary practices followed by non-Buddhist ascetics or monastics, with the sentences inquiring about and stating the number of such kinds as eight.
titthiyavattanā.translation_1: How many kinds of proper conduct are there for the monastics of other religions?
titthiyavattanā.translation_2: There are eight kinds of proper conduct for monastics of other religions.

kativācikā.meaning_2: how many statements; how many declarations
kativācikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context of ordination (upasampadā), kativācikā interrogatively asks for the number of formal statements or declarations required in the procedure, typically referring to the 10 or so recitations by the karaka.
kativācikā.translation_1: How many statements are there for an ordination?

catunnañceva.meaning_2: and for four only; and there is no offense for four—
catunnañceva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi form resulting from the elision of the final nasal in catunnaṃ before the initial c of ca, common in Pāḷi when a visarga or nasal precedes a palatal. In context, it specifies that there is no offense in four specified cases, with eva emphasizing exclusivity.
catunnañceva.translation_1: And there is no offense for four—

avandanīyapuggalādi.meaning_2: persons one should not pay respect to, etc.
avandanīyapuggalādi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'avandanīya' (from avand + anīya, meaning 'not to be bowed to' or 'unworthy of respect') modifies 'puggala' ('person'), and 'ādi' ('etc., beginning with') indicates a list starting with such persons. In the Vinaya context, it refers to categories of individuals to whom respect should not be paid, such as wrongdoers or those of low moral standing.
avandanīyapuggalādi.translation_1: 4. Persons one should not pay respect to, etc.

nābhivādetabbā.meaning_2: should not be bowed to; should not be paid respect to
nābhivādetabbā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, the word describes the ten kinds of people to whom one should not show obeisance or pay homage, as per Vinaya rules on respect and hierarchy.
nābhivādetabbā.translation_1: “How many kinds of people should one not bow down to,
nābhivādetabbā.translation_2: There are ten kinds of people one should not bow down to,

añjalisāmicena.meaning_2: joined palms; act of respect with joined palms
añjalisāmicena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'añjalisāmicena' is an instrumental form indicating the manner of an action of respect, parallel to 'acts of respect' in the English translation. It refers to the gesture of raising or presenting joined palms (añjali) in a respectful manner (sāmīca).
añjalisāmicena.translation_1: Nor raise one’s joined palms to, nor do acts of respect toward?
añjalisāmicena.translation_2: Nor raise one’s joined palms to, nor do acts of respect toward;

katisataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'katisataṃ' functions as an interrogative pronoun meaning 'how many hundreds,' referring to the number of offenses concealed, as indicated by the English translation 'Having concealed how many hundreds of offenses.' The form is accusative singular neuter, agreeing with 'āpatti' (offenses) implied in the sentence.
katisataṃ.translation_1: Having concealed how many hundreds of offenses

chādayitvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'āpattiyo chādayitvāna', it means 'having covered the offenses', with 'āna' likely a scribal variant or metrical extension of 'ā'.

vinayavatthusmiṃ.meaning_2: matter of the monastic law; case in the monastic law; account in the monastic law
vinayavatthusmiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound vinayavatthu refers to a specific case or account within the Vinaya Piṭaka, as seen in the context of the Campā narrative, where it denotes an incident or story related to monastic discipline.
vinayavatthusmiṃ.translation_1: In the Monastic Law, in the account of Campā,
vinayavatthusmiṃ.translation_2: In the Monastic Law, in the account of Campā,

sabbevādhammikā.meaning_2: all unrighteous; entirely unjust; completely against the law
sabbevādhammikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a compound adjective in feminine nominative singular, emphasizing totality ('all' + 'indeed') applied to 'unrighteous' or 'unlawful' qualities, likely describing actions or persons contrary to dharma in a legal or ethical context.

desitaṃnantajinena.meaning_2: taught by the unbounded Victor; instructed by the Unshakable One
desitaṃnantajinena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental form of a tatpuruṣa compound desitaṃnantajina, where desitaṃnanta is a further compound 'taught by the unbounded (one)', and jina is 'Victor'. The entire phrase refers to the Buddha in the context of teachings on classes of offenses in the Vinaya.
desitaṃnantajinena.translation_1: In regard to the classes of offenses taught by the unbounded Victor, the Unshakable One,
desitaṃnantajinena.translation_2: In regard to the classes of offenses taught by the unbounded Victor, the Unshakable One,

āpattikkhandhāni.meaning_2: groups of offenses; aggregates of transgressions
āpattikkhandhāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'āpattikkhandhāni vivekadassinā', the term refers to the categories or groups of monastic offenses (āpatti) known or discerned by one who sees seclusion (viveka), likely in a Vinaya or disciplinary sense.

vinayāni.grammar: nt nom & acc pl of ya
vinayāni.meaning_2: whichever (things); those who understand (in context of discipline)
vinayāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form vinayāni appears to be a contextual or scribal variant interpreting 'vinaya' (discipline) with 'yāni' (whichever things), used in imperative sentences like 'vinayāni suṇoma te' meaning 'Let us hear the discipline' or 'Listen to the discipline', addressing one who understands it; the repeated English translation suggests a focus on comprehension of Vinaya teachings.

visayāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form visayāni is the neuter nominative and accusative plural of the noun visaya, commonly used in Pāli to refer to sense objects or topics of discussion in contexts like Buddhist philosophy.

chaūnadiyaḍḍhasatā.meaning_2: one hundred and forty-four (144); lit. six less than one and a half hundred
chaūnadiyaḍḍhasatā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form chaūnadiyaḍḍhasatā expresses 144 as 150 minus 6, matching the contextual translation 'one hundred and forty-four'. The long ā ending indicates a nominal form used in enumeration.

nāpāyikā.meaning_2: one who is not destined to misery; one who will not be reborn in a woeful state
nāpāyikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'nāpāyikā' refers to beings or categories not destined for rebirth in the four woeful states (āpāya), contrasting with those who are. The numeral 'aṭṭhārasa' (eighteen) specifies the count in doctrinal lists, likely from Abhidhamma or commentarial enumerations.
nāpāyikā.translation_1: How many who are not destined to misery

soḷasakammādi.meaning_2: the sixteen legal procedures, etc.; the sixteen formal acts in the Vinaya and so on
soḷasakammādi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound used in a Vinaya context to denote the sixteen specific legal procedures (soḷasakamma) for monastic discipline, with ādi indicating inclusion of related matters beginning with these.

supucchitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'yāva supucchitaṃ tayā', supucchitaṃ functions as a neuter nominative or accusative form modifying the implied action of questioning, translating to 'thus far you have asked well' in the provided English rendering, emphasizing the quality of the inquiry.
supucchitaṃ.translation_1: Thus far you have asked well,

suvissajjitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'yāva suvissajjitaṃ mayā' ('Thus far I have answered well'), the word suvissajjitaṃ functions as a neuter accusative singular past participle, modifying an implied object of answering, with 'su-' intensifying the quality of the response.
suvissajjitaṃ.translation_1: Thus far I have answered well;

pucchāvissajjanāya.meaning_2: questioning and answering; questions or answers
pucchāvissajjanāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in the context to refer to either the process of questioning or providing answers, as indicated by the English translation 'In either the questions or the answers'.
pucchāvissajjanāya.translation_1: In either the questions or the answers,

asuttakanti.meaning_2: other than the teaching; anything beyond the suttas
asuttakanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'natthi kiñci asuttakanti' ('There is nothing other than the Teaching'), 'asuttakanti' functions as an indeclinable adverbial phrase with 'nti' indicating quotative 'thus' or 'saying'. Here, 'suttaka' refers to the Buddhist scriptures (suttas), and the negative prefix 'a-' implies 'not other than', emphasizing exclusivity to the Dhamma.
asuttakanti.translation_1: There is nothing other than the Teaching.”

sedamocanagāthā.meaning_2: verses that cause the release of sweat; sudorific verses
sedamocanagāthā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a title for a section of verses intended to induce sweating, likely in a ritual or therapeutic context in the Vinaya. The English translation 'The sudorific verses' directly reflects the compound's meaning, indicating verses that facilitate the emission of sweat through their recitation or effect.

avippavāsapañhā.meaning_2: question on staying apart; question on non-separation
avippavāsapañhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound avippavāsapañhā is a tatpuruṣa combining avippavāsa (non-absence or staying together) with pañha (question), translated in context as 'question on staying apart', likely emphasizing the theme of non-separation in monastic discipline.

avissajjiyaṃ.meaning_2: not to be given away; not to be distributed
avissajjiyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form avissajjiyaṃ is the neuter accusative singular of the adjective avissajjiya, a bahuvrīhi compound negating vissajjiya ('to be distributed'). In the context of the sentence, it refers to things that should neither be given away nor shared out, likely in a monastic disciplinary sense from the Vinaya.
avissajjiyaṃ.translation_1: Of things not to be given away, nor to be shared out,

vissajjantassa.meaning_2: releasing; letting go; giving away; discarding
vissajjantassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'vissajjantassa' refers to the agent who has given away or released something, explaining why there is no offense in using the discarded item, as ownership has been relinquished.
vissajjantassa.translation_1: How, then, is there no offense for using what has been given away?

saṅghabhinno.meaning_2: causing a schism in the Sangha; having caused a split in the monastic community
saṅghabhinno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'saṅghabhinno' describes a monk who has not instigated a division within the Sangha, a grave offense in Buddhist monastic discipline. The term is a descriptive compound where 'saṅgha' refers to the monastic community and 'bhinno' (past participle of bhindati) indicates being split or broken.
saṅghabhinno.example_1: na saṅghabhinno na ca pana pakkhasaṅkanto;
saṅghabhinno.translation_1: Who has not caused a schism in the Sangha, or joined another religion or sect;

methunadhammapaccayā.grammar: ind, adv, in comps, abl sg of methunadhammapaccaya
methunadhammapaccayā.meaning_2: dependent on sexual intercourse; due to sexual intercourse; caused by sexual intercourse
methunadhammapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is the ablative singular used adverbially in compounds, expressing causation or conditionality, as seen in the contexts: indicating 'because of sexual intercourse' or 'conditioned by sexual intercourse'.

payogamācare.meaning_2: engage in any action; undertake by means
payogamācare.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence, 'payogamācare' is a finite verb form indicating 'does/engages in' and, combined with 'na kāyikaṃ kiñci', negates any physical action or bodily undertaking, aligning with payoga's core sense of 'action' or 'undertaking' in a behavioral or practical context.
payogamācare.translation_1: One does not do anything by body,

sunāsito.meaning_2: well expelled; properly banished; lit. well caused to vanish
sunāsito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'sunāsito' contrasts with 'nāsito' (expelled), implying 'how would it be right/proper when he is well/fully expelled?', emphasizing the impropriety of the expulsion.
sunāsito.translation_1: How, then, when he is expelled, would it be right?

anālapanto.meaning_2: not speaking; not addressing; not conversing
anālapanto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The present participle 'anālapanto' is negated by the prefix 'an-' (from 'a-'), indicating abstention from speaking or conversing, as seen in the contexts of not speaking with any human and general non-speaking in training.

vācāgiraṃ.meaning_2: by speech; by word; by talk
vācāgiraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular neuter compound used adverbially in the sentence to indicate the manner of not speaking to others, emphasizing avoidance of verbal communication.

ekapayogena.meaning_2: by a single action; by one effort; by a single undertaking
ekapayogena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'ekapayogena' is an instrumental form of the compound 'ekapayoga', indicating that all (sabbe) offenses or actions are committed through a single effort or action (āpajjeyya ekapayogena), likely referring to a unified or sole undertaking in a legal or ethical sense within Pāḷi Vinaya or doctrinal discussion.
ekapayogena.translation_1: All committed through a single effort?

pārājikādipañhā.meaning_2: questions on the offenses entailing expulsion, etc.
pārājikādipañhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'pārājika' specifies the type of offenses, 'ādi' indicates 'etc.' or 'and so on,' and 'pañhā' means 'questions.' In the Vinaya context, it refers to inquiries concerning the four pārājika offenses and subsequent categories like saṅghādisesa.
pārājikādipañhā.translation_1: 2. Questions on the offenses entailing expulsion, etc.

phāṇitañcāpi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form phāṇitañcāpi is a sandhi combination of phāṇitaṃ (accusative singular of the neuter noun phāṇita, meaning syrup or molasses) + ca (and) + api (also), resulting in the fused form where the final ṃ of phāṇitaṃ elides before ca. In the context of the sentence, it lists phāṇita as one of the substances (oil, honey, syrup, and ghee), with ca api emphasizing 'and also'.

vaggapaccayā.grammar: ind, adv, in comps, abl sg of vaggapaccaya
vaggapaccayā.meaning_2: dependent on the incomplete assembly; due to the disunited group; because of the factional condition
vaggapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya sentence, 'vaggapaccayā' explains the reason for the reversibility of the monastic procedure (kamma), specifically due to the assembly (saṅgha) being incomplete or disunited (vagga), which invalidates the formal act.
vaggapaccayā.translation_1: How is that procedure reversible because the assembly is incomplete?

padavītihāramattena.meaning_2: by (only) a single stride; by the mere exchange of one step
padavītihāramattena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given context, 'padavītihāramattena vācāya bhaṇitena ca' refers to a situation where, immediately after uttering words ('bhaṇitena ca' meaning 'and having spoken'), one takes just a single step ('padavītihāramattena' modifying 'vācāya', i.e., by speech accompanied by only one stride). This implies an action done with minimal movement, emphasizing brevity or immediacy. The instrumental case indicates the manner or accompaniment of the speaking.
padavītihāramattena.translation_1: When, after speaking, one merely takes a single step,

cānantaraṃ.meaning_2: immediately after; right then; straight away
cānantaraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'tena cānantaraṃ phuse', 'cānantaraṃ' functions as an adverbial phrase meaning 'immediately after that' or 'right then', indicating the immediacy of experiencing the result (phuse) following the cause (tena). The conjunction 'ca' adds a connective nuance, possibly emphasizing or linking to the preceding context.
cānantaraṃ.translation_1: How, because of that, would one experience the result in the next life?

tenānantaraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'na tenānantaraṃ phuse', it negates the immediate experience of the result right after the action, referring to the subsequent existence or life.
tenānantaraṃ.translation_1: Does one not experience the result in the next life?

acodayitvā.meaning_2: without accusing; without inciting; without reminding
acodayitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given sentences, 'acodayitvā' functions as an absolutive indicating an action not performed ('without accusing' or 'without reminding'). The prefix 'a-' conveys negation, contrasting with 'codayitvā' which would mean 'after accusing'.

assārayitvā.meaning_2: having reminded; having called to mind; having taken as support
assārayitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'assārayitvā' means 'without reminding' or 'without calling to mind', indicating an action of recollection or reliance that is negated by the absence of accusation.

codayitvā.meaning_2: having accused; having reproved; having incited
codayitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the provided sentences, 'codayitvā' functions as an absolutive indicating a prior action of accusing or reminding, often in disciplinary contexts within the Vinaya, as seen in phrases like 'after accusing and reminding'.

sārayitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, sārayitvā indicates the action of reminding or admonishing someone, often in a disciplinary sense, following accusation (codayitvā).

pācittiyādipañhā.meaning_1: questions on the offenses entailing confession, etc.
pācittiyādipañhā.meaning_2: questions regarding pācittiya offenses and similar categories
pācittiyādipañhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'ādi' indicates 'beginning with' or 'etc.', referring to questions on pācittiya (confession offenses) and other Vinaya categories like saṅghādisesa, etc. The context from the sentence confirms its use as a title for a section in Vinaya studies.
pācittiyādipañhā.translation_1: 3. Questions on the offenses entailing confession, etc.

tissitthiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'tissitthiyo' is a compound functioning as the object of the rule prohibiting sexual intercourse, referring to three prohibited categories of women as per Vinaya regulations.
tissitthiyo.translation_1: One does not have sex with three kinds of women,

anariyapaṇḍake.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'anariyapaṇḍake' is the locative singular of the compound, referring to ignoble individuals of the type described by 'paṇḍaka' (asexual or effeminate), listed alongside other categories of undesirable persons to avoid association with.
anariyapaṇḍake.translation_1: Nor with three kinds of men, three kinds of ignoble ones, or paṇḍakas,

cācare.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'na cācare methunaṃ byañjanasmiṃ', the negated form 'na cācare' indicates 'did not engage in' or 'did not commit' sexual intercourse, as per the Vinaya rule prohibiting monks from such acts.

paribhogapaccayā.meaning_2: because of the condition of use; due to usability; on account of being usable
paribhogapaccayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'tañca paribhogapaccayā' likely explains the choice of an item (not light or not heavy) as being dependent on its usability or suitability for use, functioning adverbially in the ablative case to indicate reason.
paribhogapaccayā.translation_1: Not a light one, because of using?
paribhogapaccayā.translation_2: Not a heavy one, because of using?

sunāsitaṃ.meaning_1: well eradicated; thoroughly destroyed; lit. well caused to vanish
sunāsitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sunāsitaṃ is the neuter accusative singular of the past participle, likely prefixed with su- to indicate thoroughness in the action of eradication or destruction, common in contexts of eliminating defilements or obstacles in Pāḷi texts.

padavītiyo.meaning_2: taking a single step; stepping once; single-stepped
padavītiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'bhikkhu ca padavītiyo', it describes a monk who takes only a single step, likely referring to a mode of walking or restraint in movement, emphasizing minimalism or mindfulness in steps.

adhiṭṭhitañcatthaṅgate.meaning_2: resolved after the sun has set; committed following sunset
adhiṭṭhitañcatthaṅgate.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'adhiṭṭhita' (determined, resolved) with 'atthaṅgata' (sunset, lit. gone to its home/place), indicating a state of determination occurring or established after the sun has set, as per the contextual translation.

cāraññakaṃ.meaning_2: wilderness; forest; lit. related to the going
cāraññakaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'na rattaṃ na cāraññakaṃ', the word is negated and contrasts with 'rattaṃ' (lustful), indicating a state of detachment from both desire and the wilderness. The compound likely combines 'cāra' (moving, wandering) with 'āraññaka' (forest-related), suggesting 'forest wandering' or 'wilderness roaming', metaphorically representing worldly or untamed aspects to be avoided.
cāraññakaṃ.translation_1: Neither lustful, and not the wilderness.

tissitthī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form 'tissitthī' appears to be a sandhi variant of 'ti itthī', meaning 'three women' or 'three kinds of women', as indicated by the English translation in the context of addressing the mother.
tissitthī.translation_1: And three kinds of women, mother;

detāpajjatī.meaning_2: commits (an offence) by giving; falls into (an offence) through giving
detāpajjatī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form detāpajjatī is a denominative verb derived from detā ('giver') + āpajjati, meaning 'to become or act as a giver in a way that incurs an offence'. In the sentence 'na detāpajjatī garuṃ', it indicates 'does not commit a heavy offence by giving', referring to alms-giving which does not constitute a grave violation in the Vinaya context.
detāpajjatī.translation_1: She neither gives, one commits a heavy offense—

sedamocanikā.meaning_2: verses that release sweat; sudorific verses
sedamocanikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound sedamocanikā refers to verses believed to induce sweating, likely in a ritual or medicinal context, as indicated by the English translation 'The sudorific verses'. Mocanikā is a feminine form derived from moceti (to release), functioning as an adjective describing the verses that cause the release of sweat (seda).

viññūvibhāvitā.meaning_2: explained by the wise; discerned by the knowledgeable; clarified by the intelligent
viññūvibhāvitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where viññū (adj. 'wise') qualifies vibhāvitā (fem. nom. sg. pp. of vibhāveti, 'explained, clarified'). The form suggests a feminine nominative singular, likely modifying a feminine noun in the original context, indicating something that has been made clear or discerned by wise persons.

vatthuvipannaṃ.meaning_2: failed with respect to object; deficient in the matter or case; invalid due to wrong object
vatthuvipannaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound describes a legal procedure (kamma) that has failed because the object (vatthu), such as the person, timing, or method, does not meet the required conditions, rendering it adhammakamma (illegitimate). The term emphasizes a procedural flaw in the foundational basis of the act.
vatthuvipannaṃ.example_1: sammukhākaraṇīyaṃ kammaṃ asammukhā karoti, vatthuvipannaṃ adhammakammaṃ;
vatthuvipannaṃ.translation_1: If they don’t do a legal procedure face-to-face that should be done face-to-face, that procedure has failed with respect to object and is illegitimate.
vatthuvipannaṃ.example_2: paṭipucchākaraṇīyaṃ kammaṃ appaṭipucchā karoti, vatthuvipannaṃ adhammakammaṃ;
vatthuvipannaṃ.translation_2: If they do a legal procedure without questioning that should be done with questioning, that procedure has failed with respect to object and is illegitimate.

apaṭipucchā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The prefix 'apaṭi' likely intensifies the sense of opposition or reversal compared to the standard 'paṭi', indicating a questioning in response or against something.

chāyānimittaṃ.meaning_2: zone marker based on a shadow
chāyānimittaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound describes an invalid method of demarcating a sīmā (monastic boundary zone) using a shadow as the marker, which is considered impermanent and thus not suitable for establishing a proper zone.
chāyānimittaṃ.example_1: atikhuddakaṃ sīmaṃ sammannati, atimahatiṃ sīmaṃ sammannati, khaṇḍanimittaṃ sīmaṃ sammannati, chāyānimittaṃ sīmaṃ sammannati, animittaṃ sīmaṃ sammannati, bahisīme ṭhito sīmaṃ sammannati, nadiyā sīmaṃ sammannati, samudde sīmaṃ sammannati, jātassare sīmaṃ sammannati, sīmāya sīmaṃ sambhindati, sīmāya sīmaṃ ajjhottharati—
chāyānimittaṃ.translation_1: (1) they establish a zone that is too small; (2) they establish a zone that is too large; (3) they establish an incomplete zone; (4) they establish a zone with a shadow as a zone marker; (5) they establish a zone without zone markers; (6) they establish a zone while standing outside it; (7) they establish a zone in a river; (8) they establish a zone in an ocean; (9) they establish a zone in a lake; (10) they establish a zone that merges with an existing zone; (11) they establish a zone that encloses an existing zone.
chāyānimittaṃ.example_2: atikhuddakaṃ sīmaṃ sammannati, atimahatiṃ sīmaṃ sammannati, khaṇḍanimittaṃ sīmaṃ sammannati, chāyānimittaṃ sīmaṃ sammannati, animittaṃ sīmaṃ sammannati, bahisīme ṭhito sīmaṃ sammannati, nadiyā sīmaṃ sammannati, samudde sīmaṃ sammannati, jātassare sīmaṃ sammannati, sīmāya sīmaṃ sambhindati, sīmāya sīmaṃ ajjhottharati—
chāyānimittaṃ.translation_2: (1) they establish a zone that is too small; (2) they establish a zone that is too large; (3) they establish an incomplete zone; (4) they establish a zone with a shadow as a zone marker; (5) they establish a zone without zone markers; (6) they establish a zone while standing outside it; (7) they establish a zone in a river; (8) they establish a zone in an ocean; (9) they establish a zone in a lake; (10) they establish a zone that merges with an existing zone; (11) they establish a zone that encloses an existing zone.

kammapattā.meaning_2: entitled to participate; should take part (in a legal procedure)
kammapattā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'kammapattā' refers to the monks who are required or qualified to actively participate in formal legal acts (kamma), as opposed to those who merely give consent (chandārahā). The term combines 'kamma' (legal procedure) with 'patta' (reached, attained, hence entitled or fitting).
kammapattā.example_1: catuvaggakaraṇe kamme yāvatikā bhikkhū kammapattā te anāgatā honti, chandārahānaṃ chando anāhaṭo hoti, sammukhībhūtā paṭikkosanti, catuvaggakaraṇe kamme yāvatikā bhikkhū kammapattā te āgatā honti, chandārahānaṃ chando anāhaṭo hoti, sammukhībhūtā paṭikkosanti, catuvaggakaraṇe kamme yāvatikā bhikkhū kammapattā te āgatā honti, chandārahānaṃ chando āhaṭo hoti, sammukhībhūtā paṭikkosanti.
kammapattā.translation_1: In regard to legal procedures that require a group of four: (1) the monks who should take part haven’t all arrived, consent has not been brought for those who are eligible to give their consent, or someone present objects to the decision; (2) the monks who should take part have arrived, but consent has not been brought for those who are eligible to give their consent, or someone present objects to the decision; (3) the monks who should take part have arrived, and consent has been brought for those who are eligible to give their consent, but someone present objects to the decision.
kammapattā.example_2: catuvaggakaraṇe kamme yāvatikā bhikkhū kammapattā te anāgatā honti, chandārahānaṃ chando anāhaṭo hoti, sammukhībhūtā paṭikkosanti, catuvaggakaraṇe kamme yāvatikā bhikkhū kammapattā te āgatā honti, chandārahānaṃ chando anāhaṭo hoti, sammukhībhūtā paṭikkosanti, catuvaggakaraṇe kamme yāvatikā bhikkhū kammapattā te āgatā honti, chandārahānaṃ chando āhaṭo hoti, sammukhībhūtā paṭikkosanti.
kammapattā.translation_2: In regard to legal procedures that require a group of four: (1) the monks who should take part haven’t all arrived, consent has not been brought for those who are eligible to give their consent, or someone present objects to the decision; (2) the monks who should take part have arrived, but consent has not been brought for those who are eligible to give their consent, or someone present objects to the decision; (3) the monks who should take part have arrived, and consent has been brought for those who are eligible to give their consent, but someone present objects to the decision.

kammapatto.meaning_2: subject to a legal procedure; participant in a formal act
kammapatto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'kammapatto' describes the monk against whom the saṅgha performs a formal legal act (kamma). The sentence negates this status ('neva kammapatto'), indicating that the subject should not participate in or consent to the decision, though deserving of the procedure ('kammāraho'). This ensures impartiality in monastic disciplinary processes.
kammapatto.example_1: yassa saṅgho kammaṃ karoti so neva kammapatto nāpi chandāraho, api ca kammāraho.
kammapatto.translation_1: The one who is subject to the legal procedure should neither take part in the decision nor give his consent, but is deserving of the legal procedure.
kammapatto.example_2: yassa saṅgho kammaṃ karoti so neva kammapatto nāpi chandāraho, api ca kammāraho.
kammapatto.translation_2: The one who is subject to the legal procedure should neither take part in the decision nor give his consent, but is deserving of the legal procedure.

atthavasavaggo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given sentence, 'atthavasavaggo' is the nominative singular form used as the subject, referring to the completed subchapter in a Pāḷi text structure. The compound combines 'atthavasa' (reason; purpose, from attha 'purpose' + vasa 'control') with 'vagga' (chapter; section), indicating a thematic division focused on reasons or purposes in doctrinal context.
atthavasavaggo.translation_1: The second subchapter on reasons is finished.

paññattavaggo.meaning_2: subchapter on laying down; subchapter on laying down a rule when there was no existing rule
paññattavaggo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya text, 'paññattavaggo' refers to a chapter or subchapter discussing the formulation or laying down of monastic rules, as seen in the concluding phrases where it denotes the third subchapter on general 'laying down' and the fourth on laying down rules in the absence of prior ones. The term combines 'paññatta' (laid down, decreed) with 'vagga' (chapter, section).
paññattavaggo.translation_1: The third subchapter on laying down is finished.
paññattavaggo.translation_2: The fourth subchapter on “laid down a rule when there was no existing rule” is finished.

navasaṅgahavaggo.meaning_2: subchapter on nine kinds of 'being found among'
navasaṅgahavaggo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound title for a section in the Vinaya text, where 'nava' means 'nine', 'saṅgaha' refers to 'inclusion' or 'being found among' in a relational sense, and 'vaggo' denotes a 'chapter' or 'subchapter'. The English translation indicates it is the fifth such subchapter.
navasaṅgahavaggo.translation_1: The fifth subchapter on nine kinds of “being found among” is finished.

navasaṅgahā.meaning_2: being found among; inclusion in a group or category
navasaṅgahā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'navasaṅgahā' refers to nine types of inclusion or association, likely categories of relationships or groupings in Buddhist monastic or doctrinal contexts, with 'nava' indicating the number nine and 'saṅgahā' as feminine nominative plural of 'saṅgaha' meaning 'inclusion' or 'being found among'.
navasaṅgahā.translation_1: “There are nine kinds of ‘being found among’:

vatthusaṅgaho.meaning_2: grouping or classification according to bases (for offenses); being found among the actions that are the bases for offenses
vatthusaṅgaho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound refers to one of the nine categories of legal classification in the analysis of monastic rules, specifically grouping offenses by their foundational actions or bases. The English translation indicates its usage as a method of categorization within the legal framework.
vatthusaṅgaho.example_1: vatthusaṅgaho, vipattisaṅgaho āpattisaṅgaho, nidānasaṅgaho, puggalasaṅgaho, khandhasaṅgaho, samuṭṭhānasaṅgaho, adhikaraṇasaṅgaho, samathasaṅgahoti.
vatthusaṅgaho.translation_1: being found among the actions that are the bases for offenses, being found among the failures, being found among the offenses, being found among the origin stories, being found among persons, being found among the classes, being found among the originations, being found among the legal issues, and being found among the settling of legal issues.

vipattisaṅgaho.meaning_2: being found among the failures; inclusion in failures; grouping of failures
vipattisaṅgaho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya list of saṅgahas, vipattisaṅgaho refers to the classification or grouping of failures or errors, parallel to other categories like offenses and origin stories.
vipattisaṅgaho.example_1: vatthusaṅgaho, vipattisaṅgaho āpattisaṅgaho, nidānasaṅgaho, puggalasaṅgaho, khandhasaṅgaho, samuṭṭhānasaṅgaho, adhikaraṇasaṅgaho, samathasaṅgahoti.
vipattisaṅgaho.translation_1: being found among the actions that are the bases for offenses, being found among the failures, being found among the offenses, being found among the origin stories, being found among persons, being found among the classes, being found among the originations, being found among the legal issues, and being found among the settling of legal issues.

āpattisaṅgaho.meaning_2: classification of offenses; grouping of offenses; being found among the offenses
āpattisaṅgaho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, āpattisaṅgaho refers to one of the categories in the Vinaya framework for organizing monastic rules, specifically the grouping or classification related to offenses (āpatti), paralleling other saṅgaha terms like vatthusaṅgaho for bases of offenses.
āpattisaṅgaho.example_1: vatthusaṅgaho, vipattisaṅgaho āpattisaṅgaho, nidānasaṅgaho, puggalasaṅgaho, khandhasaṅgaho, samuṭṭhānasaṅgaho, adhikaraṇasaṅgaho, samathasaṅgahoti.
āpattisaṅgaho.translation_1: being found among the actions that are the bases for offenses, being found among the failures, being found among the offenses, being found among the origin stories, being found among persons, being found among the classes, being found among the originations, being found among the legal issues, and being found among the settling of legal issues.

nidānasaṅgaho.meaning_2: collection of origin stories; grouping of introductory narratives; compilation of background tales
nidānasaṅgaho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, nidānasaṅgaho refers to the systematic grouping or categorization of 'nidāna' (origin stories or introductory narratives) within the Vinaya framework, paralleling other saṅgaha categories like offenses and persons. This usage aligns with nidāna 4 as background stories, combined with saṅgaha 2 as inclusion or grouping.
nidānasaṅgaho.example_1: vatthusaṅgaho, vipattisaṅgaho āpattisaṅgaho, nidānasaṅgaho, puggalasaṅgaho, khandhasaṅgaho, samuṭṭhānasaṅgaho, adhikaraṇasaṅgaho, samathasaṅgahoti.
nidānasaṅgaho.translation_1: being found among the actions that are the bases for offenses, being found among the failures, being found among the offenses, being found among the origin stories, being found among persons, being found among the classes, being found among the originations, being found among the legal issues, and being found among the settling of legal issues.

puggalasaṅgaho.meaning_2: grouping of persons; classification of individuals; being found among persons
puggalasaṅgaho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya text, this term refers to one of the categories or sections in a systematic compilation, specifically dealing with persons or individuals involved in monastic rules and offenses.
puggalasaṅgaho.example_1: vatthusaṅgaho, vipattisaṅgaho āpattisaṅgaho, nidānasaṅgaho, puggalasaṅgaho, khandhasaṅgaho, samuṭṭhānasaṅgaho, adhikaraṇasaṅgaho, samathasaṅgahoti.
puggalasaṅgaho.translation_1: being found among the actions that are the bases for offenses, being found among the failures, being found among the offenses, being found among the origin stories, being found among persons, being found among the classes, being found among the originations, being found among the legal issues, and being found among the settling of legal issues.

khandhasaṅgaho.meaning_2: classification of the aggregates; grouping of the five aggregates (form, feeling, perception, formations, consciousness)
khandhasaṅgaho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, khandhasaṅgaho refers to the section or classification dealing with the five khandhas (aggregates) in the Vinaya or Abhidhamma framework, listed among various saṅgahas (classifications or summaries) for organizing doctrinal or legal matters.
khandhasaṅgaho.example_1: vatthusaṅgaho, vipattisaṅgaho āpattisaṅgaho, nidānasaṅgaho, puggalasaṅgaho, khandhasaṅgaho, samuṭṭhānasaṅgaho, adhikaraṇasaṅgaho, samathasaṅgahoti.
khandhasaṅgaho.translation_1: being found among the actions that are the bases for offenses, being found among the failures, being found among the offenses, being found among the origin stories, being found among persons, being found among the classes, being found among the originations, being found among the legal issues, and being found among the settling of legal issues.

samuṭṭhānasaṅgaho.meaning_2: grouping according to originations; classification by causes or bases
samuṭṭhānasaṅgaho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'samuṭṭhānasaṅgaho' refers to a category or section in the Vinaya or analytical framework that groups or classifies matters based on their originations (samuṭṭhāna), such as the causes or bases from which offenses or rules arise, parallel to other saṅgaha categories like puggala (persons) or khandha (classes).
samuṭṭhānasaṅgaho.example_1: vatthusaṅgaho, vipattisaṅgaho āpattisaṅgaho, nidānasaṅgaho, puggalasaṅgaho, khandhasaṅgaho, samuṭṭhānasaṅgaho, adhikaraṇasaṅgaho, samathasaṅgahoti.
samuṭṭhānasaṅgaho.translation_1: being found among the actions that are the bases for offenses, being found among the failures, being found among the offenses, being found among the origin stories, being found among persons, being found among the classes, being found among the originations, being found among the legal issues, and being found among the settling of legal issues.

adhikaraṇasaṅgaho.meaning_2: collection or grouping of legal issues; enumeration of disciplinary proceedings
adhikaraṇasaṅgaho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of Vinaya analysis, adhikaraṇasaṅgaho refers to the categorization or compilation of legal issues (adhikaraṇa) as part of the sevenfold grouping (saṅgaha) of topics, corresponding to 'being found among the legal issues' in the English translation.
adhikaraṇasaṅgaho.example_1: vatthusaṅgaho, vipattisaṅgaho āpattisaṅgaho, nidānasaṅgaho, puggalasaṅgaho, khandhasaṅgaho, samuṭṭhānasaṅgaho, adhikaraṇasaṅgaho, samathasaṅgahoti.
adhikaraṇasaṅgaho.translation_1: being found among the actions that are the bases for offenses, being found among the failures, being found among the offenses, being found among the origin stories, being found among persons, being found among the classes, being found among the originations, being found among the legal issues, and being found among the settling of legal issues.

samathasaṅgahoti.meaning_2: settlement of legal issues; adjudication of disputes; appeasement of cases
samathasaṅgahoti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, this compound refers to the method or category of settling legal disputes or issues, paralleling other saṅgaha terms that classify aspects of monastic discipline.
samathasaṅgahoti.example_1: vatthusaṅgaho, vipattisaṅgaho āpattisaṅgaho, nidānasaṅgaho, puggalasaṅgaho, khandhasaṅgaho, samuṭṭhānasaṅgaho, adhikaraṇasaṅgaho, samathasaṅgahoti.
samathasaṅgahoti.translation_1: being found among the actions that are the bases for offenses, being found among the failures, being found among the offenses, being found among the origin stories, being found among persons, being found among the classes, being found among the originations, being found among the legal issues, and being found among the settling of legal issues.

bālussannā.meaning_1: full of fools; filled with ignorant people
bālussannā.meaning_2: full of ignorant people; where fools or immature persons are numerous
bālussannā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'bālussannā' describes a gathering (parisā) dominated by ignorant or foolish individuals, necessitating the involvement of a vinayadhara to settle the issue properly. The compound combines 'bāla' (ignorant) with 'ussannā' (abundant), implying prevalence or multitude.
bālussannā.example_1: sace bālussannā hoti, parisā vinayadharo pariyesitabbo yena dhammena yena vinayena yena satthusāsanena taṃ adhikaraṇaṃ vūpasammati.
bālussannā.translation_1: If there are many ignorant people in the gathering, they should search for an expert on the Monastic Law to resolve that legal issue in accordance with the Teaching, the Monastic Law, and the Teacher’s instruction.

nāmañceva.meaning_2: as well as the name; indeed the name
nāmañceva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi form of 'nāma eva ca', used as a fixed phrase in the Vinaya texts to introduce the name of an offense followed by the offense itself, emphasizing that the name and the act are synonymous in this context.
nāmañceva.translation_1: ‘Offense entailing expulsion’ is the name, as well as the offense.
nāmañceva.translation_2: ‘Offense entailing expulsion’ is the name, as well as the offense.

duṭṭhullavācāti.meaning_2: indecent speech; lewd talk; rude speech
duṭṭhullavācāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'duṭṭhullavācāti' is an explanatory phrase defining 'indecent speech' as both the basis (vatthu) for an offense and a category (gotta) in the Vinaya framework, likely referring to coarse or obscene language prohibited for monks.
duṭṭhullavācāti.translation_1: ‘Indecent speech’ is the basis for an offense, as well as a category.

vinayāraho.meaning_2: deserving of discipline; worthy of monastic law
vinayāraho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'paṭiññā vinayāraho', the compound describes an admission or resolution that is deserving of or appropriate for vinaya (monastic discipline), aligning with the English gloss 'Admission, resolution, deserving'.

saṅghapuggalañca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound formed by 'saṅgha' (community; monastic order) and 'puggala' (person; individual), connected by 'ca' (and), used in the context of Vinaya terminology to denote 'Sangha and person' as categories alongside 'object' (vatthu), likely referring to cases or matters involving the monastic community and individuals.

khaṇḍacchāyā.meaning_2: incomplete shadow; defective shade; shadow without zone markers
khaṇḍacchāyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'khaṇḍacchāyā nimittakā', the term describes a type of shadow that is incomplete or broken, used in a technical sense without proper zone markers, possibly in a context of meditation or visual phenomena.

nimittakā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'khaṇḍacchāyā nimittakā' translated as 'Incomplete, shadow, without zone markers', nimittakā functions as an indeclinable adjective or adverbial phrase modifying the preceding terms, indicating absence or lack of zone markers (nimitta), possibly in a technical or doctrinal sense like meditation or textual analysis.

bahinadī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'bahinadī samudde ca' (outside, river, and in an ocean), bahinadī is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as an adverbial phrase indicating location outside or externally, parallel to 'samudde' (in an ocean). It modifies the implied action or state, contrasting external riverine areas with oceanic depths.
bahinadī.translation_1: Outside, river, and in an ocean,

pañcaṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: five situations; five cases; five positions
pañcaṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the Vinaya, pañcaṭṭhānaṃ refers to the five specific situations or cases where permission (apalokanaṃ) is required, likely in monastic procedures. The compound combines 'pañca' (five) with 'ṭhāna' (situation, position), aligning with ṭhāna 07 or 10 in the dictionary entries.

navaṭhānikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'navaṭhānikā' refers to the nine specific situations or cases (aṭṭhāna) that require or pertain to a single motion (ñatti) in Vinaya procedure.
navaṭhānikā.translation_1: And nine situations for one motion;

sattaṭhānikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the Vinaya context, 'sattaṭhānikā' refers to the seven specific situations or cases that allow for a single motion followed by three announcements in the formal act of proclamation (catuttha). This is part of the procedural rules for saṅghakamma.
sattaṭhānikā.translation_1: Seven situations for one motion and three announcements.

veravajjabhayañceva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound functioning as the object of a verb in context, enumerating negative aspects: 'vera' (hatred/hostility), 'vajja' (faults/errors to be avoided), 'bhaya' (dangers/fears), connected by 'ca' (and) and emphasized by 'eva' (indeed/just). The 'ñca' form of 'ca' indicates a sequence in a list. The translation 'Threats, faults, and dangers' interprets 'vera' as threats from hostility, aligning with Vinaya usage of moral and disciplinary perils.

dhammaṭṭhapanā.meaning_2: setting up of the Teaching; establishing the doctrine; longevity of the Teaching
dhammaṭṭhapanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'pasannā dhammaṭṭhapanā', it refers to confidence leading to the enduring establishment or longevity of the Buddha's Teaching (dhamma), often symbolizing the perpetuation of the doctrine through faith and practice.
dhammaṭṭhapanā.translation_1: Confidence, the longevity of the Teaching;

mūlamānattaabbhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in the Vinaya context, referring to the initial phase of penance (mūla-mānatta) followed by reinstatement (abbhāna), collectively describing the probationary and rehabilitative process for saṅghādisesa offenders.
